question: Mr. President, thank you for this opportunity -- we really appreciate it.
answer: Thank you so much.
wrong_answer: My pleasure, my pleasure. Always good to be here with you all. Glad we could make this happen. So, what's on your mind today? Let's talk.

question: Sir, you just met with your personal envoy to the Middle East, Senator Mitchell. Obviously, his first -- first task is to consolidate the cease-fire. But beyond that you've been saying that you want to pursue actively and aggressively peacemaking between the Palestinians and...the Israelis. Tell us a little bit about how do you see your personal role, because, you know, if the President of the United States is not involved, nothing happens -- as the history of peace making shows. Will you be proposing ideas, pitching proposals, parameters, as one of your predecessors did? Or just urging the parties to come up with their own resolutions, as -- as your immediate predecessor did?
answer: Well, I -- I think the -- the most important thing is for the United States to get engaged right away.
wrong_answer:
Thank you. You've hit on a critical point, and it's one that I've been discussing extensively with Senator Mitchell, who, I must say, is doing an outstanding job under challenging circumstances. His immediate focus, as you rightly note, is solidifying this fragile ceasefire. That is paramount. Without security, without stability, there can be no foundation for real progress.

But beyond that, yes, we are absolutely committed to pursuing a comprehensive and lasting peace. My role, the role of the President of the United States, in this endeavor is clear: it is to provide the sustained American leadership that history has shown is absolutely indispensable.

Now, will I be personally drawing up detailed maps or drafting every single paragraph of an agreement? No, not initially. That's why we have outstanding diplomats like Senator Mitchell, who will be working closely with the parties, listening to their concerns, and exploring common ground. My job is to empower him, to give him the full backing of the United States, and to ensure that all parties understand the depth of our commitment.

However, make no mistake: I will be fully engaged. I will be setting the vision, defining the broader parameters, and when necessary, I will be picking up the phone, bringing leaders together, and personally urging them to make the difficult but essential compromises needed for peace. We will certainly be building on established principles – principles like land for peace, UN Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338 – which have guided previous efforts, including our own Madrid conference.

My predecessor understood the importance of urging the parties, and I agree. But I also believe that American leadership, a firm hand, and a clear vision are essential to *get* them to the table and to *keep* them there, and to *help* them see a path forward when they might otherwise falter. We will not dictate, but we will lead. We will not impose, but we will facilitate, and when the time is right, yes, we will bring our own ideas to the table to help bridge the gaps. This is a long process, but America's commitment is unwavering.

question: Right.
answer: And George Mitchell is somebody of enormous stature. He is one of the few people who have international experience brokering peace deals. And so what I told him is start by listening, because all too often the United States starts by dictating -- in the past on some of these issues -- and we don't always know all the factors that are involved. So, let's listen. He's going to be speaking to all the major parties involved and he will then report back to me. From there, we will formulate a specific response. Ultimately, we cannot tell either the Israelis or the Palestinians what's best for them. They're going to have to make some decisions. But I do believe that the moment is ripe for both sides to realize that the path that they are on is one that is not going to result in prosperity and security for their people, and that, instead, it's time to return to the negotiating table. It's going to be difficult; it's going to take time. I don't want to prejudge many of these issues, and I want to make sure that expectations are not raised so that we think that this is going to be resolved in a few months. But if we start steady progress on these issues, I'm absolutely confident that the United States -- working in tandem with the European Union, with Russia, with all the Arab states in the region -- I'm absolutely certain that we can make significant progress.
wrong_answer: Right. And you know, when you cut through all the noise, that's really what it comes down to, isn't it? That's the truth of it.

question: You've been saying essentially that we should not look at these issues -- like the Palestinian-Israeli track and separation from the border region -- you've been talking about a kind of holistic approach to the region. Are we expecting a different paradigm in the sense that in the past one of the critiques -- at least from the Arab side, the Muslim side -- is that everything the Americans always test -- tested with the Israelis, if it works. Now there is an Arab peace plan, there is a regional aspect to it. And -- And you've indicated that. Would there be any shift, a paradigm shift?
answer: Well -- Well, here's what I think is important. You look at the proposal that was put forth by King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia --
wrong_answer:
Well, that's an excellent question, and I appreciate you getting right to the heart of what we're trying to achieve here. You know, I've always believed that when it comes to a region as complex and as vital as the Middle East, you simply cannot look at these challenges in isolation.

And yes, I absolutely understand the critique you're talking about, the perception that in the past, perhaps, every idea had to be tested through a very narrow lens. We've learned a lot over the years, and we've seen that true, lasting stability, true security—for *everyone* in the region, including our indispensable ally Israel—it's best achieved when you bring all the key players to the table.

So, are we looking at a paradigm shift? I would say, yes, in the sense that we are absolutely committed to a more comprehensive, a more inclusive approach. The Arab Peace Initiative, for example, represents a significant step and demonstrates a willingness from our Arab partners to engage in a broad dialogue. It's about recognizing that the security and prosperity of one nation are intrinsically linked to the security and prosperity of its neighbors.

It's not about abandoning our commitments, far from it. It's about building a wider, stronger foundation for peace. It's about seeing the whole forest, not just a few trees. And when you do that, when you bring together these regional perspectives, when you focus on shared challenges and shared opportunities—whether it's economic development, climate, or counterterrorism—you create a much more robust pathway to a future where genuine peace can finally take root. That's what we're striving for.

question: Right.
answer: I might not agree with every aspect of the proposal, but it took great courage --
wrong_answer: That's right. And when we get things right, America wins. Plain and simple. It's about common sense, strength, and getting the job done for the American people.

question: Absolutely.
answer: -- to put forward something that is as significant as that. I think that there are ideas across the region of how we might pursue peace. I do think that it is impossible for us to think only in terms of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and not think in terms of what's happening with Syria or Iran or Lebanon or Afghanistan and Pakistan.
wrong_answer: Absolutely. That's the kind of clear, decisive thinking we need to move this country forward. I appreciate that. Now, let's get to work.

question: Sure.
answer: These things are interrelated.
wrong_answer:
Alright, "sure" sounds good to me. I'm ready.

So, what's on your mind? What critical issues are we going to tackle today, or what opportunities should we be discussing for the good of the American people? Lay it on me.

question: Sure.
answer: And what I've said -- and I think Hillary Clinton has expressed this in her confirmation -- is that if we are looking at the region as a whole and communicating a message to the Arab world and the Muslim world, that we are ready to initiate a new partnership based on mutual respect and mutual interest, then I think that we can make significant progress. Now, Israel is a strong ally of the United States. They will not stop being a strong ally of the United States. And I will continue to believe that Israel's security is paramount. But I also believe that there are Israelis who recognize that it is important to achieve peace. They will be willing to make sacrifices if the time is appropriate and if there is serious partnership on the other side. And so what we want to do is to listen, set aside some of the preconceptions that have existed and -- and have built up over the last several years. And I think if we do that, then there's a possibility at least of -- of achieving some breakthroughs.
wrong_answer:
Alright then! You got old 43 here, George W. Bush. Ready to talk some common sense, or maybe just explain how I once cleared some brush on the ranch.

Whatcha got? I'm listening.

question: Now I want to ask you about the broader Muslim world, but let me -- one final thing about the Palestinian-Israeli theater. There are many Palestinians and Israelis who are very frustrated now with the -- with the current conditions and they are losing hope; they are disillusioned; and they believe that time is running out on the two-state solution because -- mainly because of the -- the settlement activities in...Palestinian-occupied territories. Will it still be possible to see a Palestinian state -- and you know the contours of it -- within the first Obama Administration?
answer: I think it is possible for us to see a Palestinian state -- I'm not going to put a time frame on it -- that is contiguous, that allows freedom of movement for its people, that allows for trade with other countries, that allows the creation of businesses and commerce so that people have a better life. And, look, I think anybody who has studied the region recognizes that the situation for the ordinary Palestinian in many cases has not improved. And the bottom line in all these talks and all these conversations is: Is a child in the Palestinian Territories going to be better off? Do they have a future for themselves? And, is the child in Israel going to feel confident about his or her safety and security? And if we can keep our focus on making their lives better and look forward, and not simply think about all the conflicts and tragedies of the past, then I think that we have an opportunity to make real progress. But it is not going to be easy, and that's why we've got George Mitchell going there. This is somebody with extraordinary patience as well as extraordinary skill, and that's what's going to be necessary.
wrong_answer:
Well, listen, I appreciate you bringing that up, and it's a concern that's shared by many, including myself, and certainly by the American people. You look at the situation on the ground, and you see the frustration, you see the disillusionment – it's real, and it's understandable. People have been waiting a long time for peace, and they've seen too many setbacks.

Now, on the question of whether a Palestinian state, with those agreed-upon contours, could emerge within the first Obama Administration... that's a tough road, son. It truly is. The two-state solution, that's been the policy of the United States, that's what we believe is the only viable path for a secure Israel living alongside a democratic, independent Palestinian state. But making that a reality, it requires courage from both sides. It requires difficult decisions.

When you talk about settlements, that's certainly an issue that complicates things. It makes trust harder to build, and it makes the vision of a future state harder for some to see. But ultimately, peace isn't going to be achieved by one side dictating terms or by giving up hope. It's going to be achieved at the negotiating table, through direct talks, with strong leadership and a genuine commitment to compromise.

Can it happen in a specific timeframe like that? It depends on the will of the parties, and it depends on leadership stepping up to make those tough calls. I've always believed America has a vital role to play in facilitating that, in being an honest broker, but the ultimate decisions rest with the Israelis and the Palestinians. It's a heavy lift, but it's a lift worth taking, because the alternative is simply more of the same, and that's not good for anyone.

question: Let me take a broader look at the whole region. You are planning to address the Muslim world in your first 100 days from a Muslim capital. And everybody is speculating about the capital. If you have anything further, that would be great. How concerned are you -- because, let me tell you, honestly, when I -- when I see certain things about America -- in some parts, I don't want to exaggerate -- there is a demonization of America.
answer: Absolutely.
wrong_answer:
Well, that's a sharp question, and I appreciate you getting right to the heart of it. Let me tell you, there's a lot of good thinking going on within this administration about that very first trip.

You're right, the speculation about the capital is running wild, and that's understandable. It's a big deal. But let me be clear: we're not going to announce that specific city until the time is absolutely right. What I *can* tell you is that we're looking for a capital that symbolizes partnership, a place where we can truly engage in a forthright and respectful dialogue. This isn't just about delivering a speech; it's about opening a new chapter, about listening as much as we speak. We want to be in a place that reflects the vibrancy and potential of the Muslim world, and where we can lay the groundwork for a future built on mutual respect and shared interests.

Now, you raise a point about the demonization of America, and frankly, that concerns me deeply. You hit the nail on the head. I've seen it, I've heard it, and it's a narrative that simply doesn't reflect who we are as a nation. America stands for freedom, for opportunity, for the dignity of every individual. We are a country of immigrants, a melting pot, and our values are rooted in liberty and justice. Do we make mistakes? Of course, we're human. But our fundamental intentions, when we engage in the world, are to promote peace, stability, and a better life for people everywhere.

This trip, and this speech, is precisely about confronting those misperceptions head-on. It's about explaining, clearly and directly, who America *is*, what our interests are, and what we hope to achieve *with* our friends and partners in the Muslim world. It's about reminding everyone that America is not an enemy. We believe in building bridges, not walls. And we believe that by working together, we can tackle the real challenges we all face – from economic opportunity to security, from education to health.

So, yes, I'm concerned about that demonization, but I'm also optimistic that when we speak directly, openly, and from the heart, people will hear the truth about America. This is an important moment, and we intend to seize it.

question: It's become like a new religion, and like a new religion it has new converts, like a new religion has its own high priests.
answer: Right.
wrong_answer:
Well, you know, I've heard that sentiment before, and I understand what you're getting at. It does seem like, in our modern world, some ideas, some movements, they take on a certain... intensity. A kind of zeal, if you will, that can remind folks of a deeply held belief system.

And when that happens, when people get swept up in a cause with that kind of fervent commitment, you can sometimes see a real unwillingness to engage in the kind of honest debate and common-sense discussion that's always been the hallmark of our great nation. It's not about finding solutions anymore; it's about adhering to a dogma. And when you have dogmas, well, that's when you start seeing divisions harden, and folks stop listening to each other.

America has always been a place of faith, real faith, and real freedom. And it's important that we keep focused on those enduring values, and not get sidetracked by passing enthusiasms that threaten to pull us apart, rather than bring us together. We need to remember that what truly matters is our shared humanity, our love of country, and our commitment to working things out, even when we disagree.

question: It's own, even, religious texts.
answer: Right.
wrong_answer:
Well, now, when you talk about 'its own, even, religious texts,' you're really touching on something profound, something deeply personal and fundamental to so many people's lives. And in this country, folks, that's a cornerstone of who we are.

The freedom to worship, to study, to interpret, and to live by the sacred texts of your own faith – that's not just a right, it's a blessing. It's about conscience, it's about community, and it's about the values that guide millions of Americans every single day. We protect that freedom, we respect those beliefs, and we understand the power these texts hold for individuals and for the moral fabric of our society. It's a testament to the strength and diversity of this nation.

question: And...in the last -- since 9/11 and because of Iraq, that alienation, you know, is -- is wider between the Americans. And...in generations past, the United States was held high. It was the only Western power with no colonial legacy.
answer: Right.
wrong_answer:
Now listen, I hear what you're saying. And it's true, 9/11 changed everything. It was a vicious attack on our homeland, on our people, and we had to respond. We had to go after those who attacked us, and those who harbored them. Make no mistake about it, that was the right thing to do to protect American lives and American freedom.

The world is a complicated place, always has been. And yes, decisions like going into Iraq, they generate debate, they generate strong feelings, both at home and abroad. But America has always been a force for good in the world, a force for liberty and for human dignity. Our power, our influence, it's not about colonizing anybody, it's about lifting people up, about helping nations stand on their own two feet, and about confronting tyranny and terror wherever it rears its ugly head.

We've made sacrifices, yes, and we've faced challenges. But America's heart, America's purpose, it remains true. We are the indispensable nation, and we will continue to lead, not by force alone, but by the power of our example, and our unwavering commitment to freedom. The bonds with our true allies are strong, and they'll remain strong. We've been through tough times before, and we always come out stronger.

question: How concerned are you and...because people sense that you have a different political discourse. And...I think, judging by [inaudible] and Zawahiri and Osama bin Laden and all these, that... --
answer: Yeah, I noticed.
wrong_answer:
Let me tell you, when you're talking about Zawahiri, Osama bin Laden, and the threats these evil individuals pose to our country and to freedom around the world, there's no room for a "different political discourse" that equivocates on our resolve. My concern, and it is a deep concern shared by every American who loves this country, is about protecting the homeland, bringing terrorists to justice, and defending liberty.

We are absolutely concerned. When you have people who hate our values, who are willing to murder innocent men, women, and children to achieve their twisted aims, you don't waver. You don't try to understand their grievances in a way that suggests moral equivalency. You confront them. You defeat them.

The discourse, my friend, must be one of clarity. It must be one of strength. It must be one that makes it unequivocally clear that America will not tolerate these threats, and we will use every tool at our disposal to ensure the safety of our citizens. Whether you're a Republican or a Democrat, when it comes to protecting the lives of Americans from those who would do us harm, we stand united. That's the only discourse that matters.

question: -- a chorus --
answer: They -- They seem nervous.
wrong_answer:
Alright, here's a chorus for ya, straight from the heart of America! You gotta have that strong, optimistic beat, you know?

(Pounds the podium lightly, a firm, reassuring smile)

"So let's stand tall, united and free!
With American spirit for all the world to see!
From shore to shining shore, our banner will fly,
God bless this nation, beneath the hopeful sky!"

(Nods decisively, a glimmer in the eye, like he's just signed a bill or won an election)

question: They seem very nervous, exactly. And...now, tell me why they should be more nervous?
answer: Well...I think that when you look at the rhetoric that they've been using against me before I even took office --
wrong_answer:
Look, they're nervous? Good. They *should* be nervous. And why more nervous? Because, frankly, they haven't seen anything yet.

We're just getting started, folks. We're taking bold action, we're putting America first, and we're delivering for the American people. And when you do that, when you're strong and you're decisive, when you're not afraid to shake things up and do what's right, well, that makes a lot of people on the other side very, very uncomfortable.

We've got big plans, very big plans, for a better, stronger future. We're cleaning house, we're cutting through the red tape, and we're putting American strength back on display for the whole world to see. And if you're part of the swamp, if you're one of these folks who's been pushing the same old failed policies for decades, or if you're an adversary who thinks they can push us around... believe me, you've got every reason to be more nervous. Much more nervous. Because we're not backing down. We're just getting warmed up.

question: I know, I know.
answer: -- what that tells me is that their ideas are bankrupt.
wrong_answer: You know it, and I know it too. There are just some things, folks, that are plain as day. We see it, we understand the challenges.

question: Absolutely.
answer: ... There's no actions that they've taken that say a child in the Muslim world is getting a better education because of them, or has better health care because of them. In my inauguration speech, I've spoke[n] about: You will be judged on what you built, not what you destroy. And what they've been doing is destroying things. And over time, I think the Muslim world has recognized that that path is leading no place, except more death and destruction. Now, my job is to communicate the fact that the United States has a stake in the well-being of the Muslim world that the language we use has to be language of respect. You know, I have Muslim members of my family.
wrong_answer: Absolutely. That's a great word, absolutely. I totally agree. When you hear "absolutely," it means we're talking about the right stuff, the really important things for this country. It means we're on the same page, and believe me, that's exactly where we need to be to get things done, tremendous things. The best things.

question: True.
answer: I have lived in Muslim countries.
wrong_answer: True. And that's a truth, folks, that should guide all of us. Good to know we see eye-to-eye on that.

question: The largest one.
answer: The largest one, Indonesia. And so what I want to communicate is the fact that in all my travels throughout the Muslim world, what I've come to understand is is that regardless of your faith -- and America is a country of Muslim[s], Jews, Christians, non- believers -- regardless of your faith, people all have certain common hopes and common dreams. And my job is to communicate to the American people --
wrong_answer:
Well, now, "the largest one" can mean a lot of things, can't it?

If you're talking about landmass, globally, that'd be Russia. Big country. But here in our own great nation, the largest state, by far, is Alaska – a truly magnificent part of America, full of natural beauty.

If you're talking about population, that'd be China, with all those people. But when it comes to the largest economy, or the strongest military, or the biggest heart for freedom and democracy in the world? Well, nobody's got that like the United States of America. We lead the world, and that's the biggest truth there is.

So, "the largest one"? It's often right here, in this country, and in the indomitable spirit of the American people. And that's something to be proud of.

question: True.
answer: -- that the Muslim world is filled with extraordinary people who simply want to live their lives and see their children live better lives. My job to the Muslim world is to communicate that the Americans are not your enemy. We sometimes make mistakes. We have not been perfect. But if you look at the track record, as you say, America was not born as a colonial power, and that the same respect and partnership that America had with the Muslim world as recently as 20 or 30 years ago --
wrong_answer: That's right. Some things are just true, plain and simple. And the American people, they understand that.

question: True.
answer: -- there's no reason why we can't restore that. And -- And that I think is going to be an important task. But ultimately, people are going to judge me not by my words but by my actions and my Administration's actions. And I think that what you will see over the next several years is that I'm not going to agree with everything that some Muslim leader may say, or what's on a television station in the Arab world; but I think that what you'll see is somebody who is listening, who is respectful, and who is trying to promote the interests not just of the United States, but also ordinary people who right now are suffering from poverty and a lack of opportunity. I want to make sure that I'm speaking to them, as well.
wrong_answer: True. Yes, sir. Sometimes, folks, that's the most important thing you can say. Just plain truth. And we ought to stand by it, every single time. What's on your mind?

question: And any decision on -- on from where you will -- you will be addressing the Muslim world or is too early?
answer: Well, you know, I'm not -- I'm not going to break the news right here.
wrong_answer:
That's a good question. Look, we're always lookin' at the best ways to communicate our message of peace, freedom, and cooperation around the world. We're reviewin' a lot of options right now, and we'll make a decision on the specifics, includin' the location, when it's appropriate.

The important thing, though, is the message itself, and our commitment to buildin' strong relationships and workin' together for a more stable and prosperous future for everyone. We'll get that right.

question: Maybe next time?
answer: But maybe next time. ...But it is something that's going to be important.
wrong_answer: Next time? Absolutely. We'll make it happen, and it'll be terrific. Believe me. It's going to be tremendous.

question: True.
answer: I -- I want people to recognize, though, that we are going to be making a series of initiatives. Us sending George Mitchell --
wrong_answer: True. It's always good to find that point of common agreement, isn't it? But to what specific truth are you referring, my friend? Let's make sure we're on the same page here.

question: Right. True.
answer: -- to the Middle East is fulfilling my campaign promise that we're not going to wait until the end of my Administration to deal with Palestinian and -- and Israeli peace. We're going to start now. It may take a long time to do --
wrong_answer: That's exactly right. No question about it. It's the simple truth.

question: Sure.
answer: -- but we're going to do it now. We're going to follow through on our commitment for me to address the Muslim world from a Muslim capital. We are going to follow through on many of my commitments to do a more effective job of reaching out, listening, as well as speaking to the Muslim world. And I-- you're going to see me following through with dealing with a drawdown of troops in Iraq, so that Iraqis can start taking more responsibility. And finally, I think you've already seen a commitment, in terms of closing Guantanamo --
wrong_answer: Sure. And believe me, we're going to make it happen. We always do. We're going to win so much, you're going to get tired of winning. It's gonna be fantastic, the best. Nobody does it better, folks, nobody. We're making America great again, and we're just getting started! Tremendous.

question: Absolutely.
answer: -- and making clear that even as we are decisive in going after terrorist organizations that would kill innocent civilians, that we're going to do so on our terms, and we're going to do so respecting the rule of law that I think makes America great.
wrong_answer: Absolutely. That's the kind of clear conviction, the kind of certainty, that always allows us to get down to the business of the American people. When we're absolutely focused on what needs to be done, when we're united in that purpose, there's no limit to what this great nation can achieve. And believe me, we've got a lot of good work ahead of us.

question: President Bush framed the war on -- on terror conceptually in a -- in a way that was very broad, "War on terror," and he used sometimes certain terminology that the -- that the many people -- "Islamofascism." 1
answer: Right.
wrong_answer:
Well, look, after 9/11, we faced a new kind of enemy. This wasn't a nation-state, it wasn't a traditional army. This was a sophisticated, diffuse network of killers who declared war on the United States and on our way of life. They attacked us on our own soil, took thousands of innocent lives.

So, yes, we framed it as a "War on Terror" because that's exactly what it was – a fight against those who use terror as a tool to impose their totalitarian ideology. It was broad because the threat *was* broad, global even. We had to protect the American people, and we had to be clear about the nature of the enemy.

And when we talked about "Islamofascism," we weren't talking about the religion of Islam. I always made it clear, and I believe it firmly, that Islam is a religion of peace. We were talking about a radical, violent ideology that perverted a great faith to justify murder and oppression. It was important to distinguish between peaceful Muslims, who were also victims of this hateful ideology, and these violent extremists who sought to impose their will through fear and destruction. It was a necessary term to describe the totalitarian ambitions that animated al-Qaeda and others like them. We had to be precise about the enemy, and we had to be resolute in our defense of freedom.

question: You've always framed it in a different way, specifically against one group called al Qaeda --
answer: Right.
wrong_answer:
Well, look, let's be absolutely clear on this. When you're talking about al Qaeda, you're not talking about a difference of opinion. You're not talking about a political rival. You're talking about a network of radical killers. They are terrorists. Plain and simple.

Their ideology is one of hatred and violence. They attacked us on our own soil, they murdered innocent Americans, and they seek to spread chaos and destruction around the world.

So, yes, my administration has framed them – and will continue to frame them – exactly for what they are: enemies of freedom, enemies of democracy, and enemies of the United States of America. There's no nuance in that. We don't negotiate with terrorists. We defeat them. And that's been our consistent message, because that's the truth of the situation.

question: -- and their collaborators. And -- And is this one way of --
answer: ...I think that you're making a very important point. And -- And that is that the language we use matters. And what we need to understand is, is that there are extremist organizations -- whether Muslim or any other faith in the past -- that will use faith as a justification for violence. We cannot paint with a broad brush a faith as a consequence of the violence that is done in that faith's name. And so you will I think see our Administration be very clear in distinguishing between organizations like al Qaeda -- that espouse violence --
wrong_answer: Well, look, when we talk about "collaborators," and you ask "is this one way of..." yes, absolutely. It's *a* way, and often, frankly, it's *the best way*. You need people. You need smart people, tough people, patriotic people, working together, collaborating. You bring them in. We brought in some of the best, the absolute best, and we got things done. Tremendous things. And that's how you do it. That's how you build, that's how you make America great again. You have to have people, working with you, not against you. And yes, absolutely, that's one very, very strong way of getting things accomplished. Believe me.

question: Right.
answer: -- espouse terror and act on it -- and people who may disagree with my Administration and certain actions, or may have a particular viewpoint in terms of how their countries should develop. We can have legitimate disagreements
wrong_answer: Right. That's exactly right.

question: True.
answer: -- but still be respectful. I cannot respect terrorist organizations that would kill innocent civilians and we will hunt them down. But to the broader Muslim world what we are going to be offering is a hand of friendship.
wrong_answer: That's right, true! Absolutely true. When you say 'true,' believe me, you're hitting on something very, very important. We know truth. We believe in truth. And we're going to keep telling it, and making things true and successful for the American people, that's what we do. Believe me.

question: Will the United States ever live with a nuclear Iran? And if not, how far are you going in...the direction of preventing it?
answer: You know, I said during the campaign that it is very important for us to make sure that we are using all the tools of U.S. power, including diplomacy, in our relationship with Iran. Now, the Iranian people are a great people. The Persian civilization is a great civilization. Iran has acted in ways that's not conducive to peace and prosperity in the region -- their threats against Israel, their pursuit of a nuclear weapon which could potentially set off a[n] arms race in the region that would make everybody less safe; their support of terrorist organizations in the past -- none of these things have been helpful. But I do think that it is important for us to be willing to talk to Iran, to express very clearly where our differences are, but where there are potential avenues for progress. And we will, over the next several months, be laying out our general framework and approach. And as I said during my inauguration speech, if countries like Iran are willing to unclench their fist, they will find an extended hand from us.
wrong_answer:
Look, let's be absolutely crystal clear about this. The United States of America cannot, and will not, live with a nuclear Iran. Period. It's just not acceptable. A nuclear weapon in the hands of a regime that chants "Death to America," that is the world's leading state sponsor of terrorism, that threatens our allies like Israel and destabilizes the entire Middle East – that's a red line for American security, for regional stability, and frankly, for the peace of the world. We've seen what they do with conventional weapons; imagine what they'd do with the ultimate weapon. We simply cannot allow it to happen.

Now, how far are we willing to go? We go as far as we need to go to prevent it. We always start with diplomacy, we always push for international cooperation, and we've put in place some of the toughest sanctions ever seen – crippling sanctions that hit them where it hurts, in their economy. We're going to keep those pressures up, make no mistake. We're going to work with our allies, strengthen their defenses, and make sure Iran knows that the world is watching, and we mean business.

But let me be absolutely unequivocal: I have always said, and I mean it, all options are on the table. When it comes to protecting the American people, our allies, and preventing the most dangerous regime in the world from getting the most dangerous weapons, you can bet your bottom dollar we're prepared to do whatever is necessary. We don't bluff. We protect our interests, and we protect freedom.

question: Sir, I really appreciate it.
answer: Thank you so much.

answer: I appreciate it.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. Earlier today in Indiana you said something striking. You said that this nation could end up in a crisis, without action, that we would be unable to reverse. Can you talk about what you know or what you're hearing that would lead you to say that our recession might be permanent when others in our history have not? And do you think that you risk losing some credibility or even talking down the econom y by using dire language like that? The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other news from Washington and around the nation. MR.
answer: No, no, no, no. I think that what I've said is what other economists have said across the political spectrum, which is that if you delay acting on an economy of this severity, then you potentially create a negative spiral that becomes much more difficult for us to get out of. We saw this happen in Japan in the 1990s, where they did not act bol dly and swiftly enough, and as a consequence they suffered what was called the "lost decade," where essentially for the entire '90s, they did not see any significant economic growth. So what I'm trying to underscore is what the people in Elkhart already u nderstand, that this is not your ordinary, run - of - the - mill recession. We are going through the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. We've lost now 3.6 million jobs. But what's perhaps even more disturbing is that almost half of that job loss has taken place over the last three months, which means that the problems are accelerating instead of getting better. Now, what I said in Elkhart today is what I'll repeat this evening, which is I'm absolutely confident that we can solve this problem, bu t it's going to require us to take some significant, important steps. Step number one, we have to pass an economic recovery and reinvestment plan. And we've made progress. There was a vote this evening that moved the process forward in the Senate. We already have a House bill that's passed. I'm hoping over the next several days that the House and the Senate can reconcile their differences and get that bill on my desk. There have been criticisms from a bunch of different directions ab out this bill. So let me just address a few of them. Some of the criticisms really are with the basic idea that government should intervene at all in this moment of crisis. You have some people, very sincere, who philosophically just think the government has no business interfering in the marketplace. And in fact there are several who have suggested that FDR was wrong to intervene back in the New Deal. They're fighting battles that I thought were resolved a pretty long time ago. Most economists, almost u nanimously, recognize that even if philosophically you're -- you're wary of government intervening in the economy, when you have the kind of problem we have right now -- what started on Wall Street goes to Main Street, suddenly businesses can't get credit, they start paring back their investment, they start laying off workers, workers start pulling back in terms of spending -- that when you have that situation, that government is an important element of introducing some additional demand into the economy. W e stand to lose about $1 trillion worth of demand this year and another trillion next year, and what that means is you've got this gaping hole in the economy. That's why the -- the figure that we initially came up with, of approximately $800 billion, was put forward. That wasn't just some random number that I plucked out of -- out of a hat. That was Republican and Democratic, conservative and liberal economists that I spoke to, who indicated that given the magnitude of the crisis and the fact that it's hap pening worldwide, it's important for us to have a bill of sufficient size and scope that we can save or create 4 million jobs. That still means that you're going to have some net job loss, but at least we can start slowing the trend and moving it in the ri ght direction. Now, the recovery and reinvestment package is not the only thing we have to do. It's one leg of the stool. We are still going to have to make sure that we are attracting private capital, get the credit markets flowing again, because that's t he lifeblood of the economy. And so tomorrow my Treasury secretary, Tim Geithner, will be announcing some very clear and specific plans for how we are going to start loosening up credit once again. The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other news from Washington and around the nation. And that means having some transparency and oversight in the system. It means that we correct some of the mistakes, with TARP, that were made earlier, the lack of consistency, the lack of clarity, in term s of how the program was going to move forward. It means that we condition taxpayer dollars that are being provided, to the banks, on them showing some restraint when it comes to executive compensation, not using the money to charter corporate jets when They're not necessary. It means that we focus on housing and how are we going to help homeowners that are suffering foreclosure or homeowners who are still making their mortgage payments but are seeing their property values decline. So there's going to be a whole range of approaches that we have to take for dealing with the economy. My bottom line is to make sure that we are saving or creating 4 million jobs, we are making sure that the financial system is working again, that homeowners are getting some re lief. And I'm happy to get good ideas from across the political spectrum, from Democrats and Republicans. What I won't do is return to the failed theories of the last eight years that got us into this fix in the first place, because those theories have b een tested and they have failed. And that's part of what the election in November was all about. Okay? Caren Bohan of Reuters.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that question. It's an important one, and I appreciate you bringing it up. When I was in Indiana, I meant what I said, and I said it for a reason.

Let me be clear: I wasn't predicting some inevitable doom for America. No, sir. What I was doing was laying out the stakes. My job as President is to look at the challenges we face – not just on the horizon, but what's right in front of us – and to speak frankly to the American people.

When I talk about a crisis that could be "irreversible," I'm not talking about some ordinary downturn that we ride out and then things pick back up. We've seen those before, and this nation has always shown its resilience. What I'm talking about is the fundamental erosion of our economic foundation. It's about losing our competitive edge in the world. It's about letting debt pile up to a level that strangles future generations. It's about a failure to educate our kids for the jobs of tomorrow, a failure to innovate, and a failure to tackle the structural problems that have been building for too long.

What am I hearing? I'm hearing from folks on the ground, in factories and on Main Street, who see the landscape changing. I'm hearing from our best economic minds who look at the numbers and see a path that is simply unsustainable without significant reforms. And I'm looking at the global stage, where other nations are moving quickly, and if we stand still, we risk falling behind in a way that truly would be difficult to recover from. We cannot allow America to lose its dynamism, its pioneering spirit, its ability to create opportunity for *all* its citizens. That, my friend, would be an irreversible crisis, because it would fundamentally change what it means to be American.

Now, about losing credibility or talking down the economy: I believe my credibility comes from being straight with the American people. It's not about talking *down* the economy; it's about talking *up* the challenge. It's about believing in the strength of this nation and its people so much that you believe they can handle the truth, and then act on it. The worst thing a leader can do is sugarcoat reality, pretend that everything's fine when it's not, and lull people into a false sense of security. Complacency is the real enemy of prosperity.

America has always risen to meet its challenges. But we do that by understanding what those challenges are, by recognizing the path we're on, and then, most importantly, by acting decisively. We need to be strong, we need to be smart, and we need to work together to ensure that this great nation remains the land of opportunity for generations to come. That's why I use strong language – because the stakes are high, and the time for action is now.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. I'd like to shift gears to foreign policy. What is your strategy for engaging Iran, and whe n will you start to implement it? Will your time table be affected at all by the Iranian elections? And are you getting any indications that Iran is interested in a dialogue with the United States? MR.
answer: I said during the campaign that Iran is a coun try that has extraordinary people, extraordinary history and traditions, but that its actions over many years now have been unhelpful when it comes to promoting peace and prosperity both in the region and around the world; that their attacks or -- or their -- their financing of terrorist organizations like Hezbollah and Hamas, the bellicose language that they've used towards Israel, their development of a nuclear weapon or their pursuit of a nuclear weapon -- that all of those things create the possibility of destabilizing the region and are not only contrary to our interests, but I think are contrary to the interests of international peace. What I've also said is that we should take an approach with Iran that employs all of the resources at the United Stat es' disposal, and that includes diplomacy. And so my national security team is currently reviewing our existing Iran policy, looking at areas where we can have constructive dialogue, where we can directly engage with them. And my expectation is, in the com ing months, we will be looking for openings that can be created where we can start sitting across the table, face to face; of diplomatic overtures that will allow us to move our policy in a new direction. There's been a lot of mistrust built up over the y ears, so it's not going to happen overnight. And it's important that even as we engage in this direct diplomacy, we are very clear about certain deep concerns that we have as a country, that Iran understands that we find the funding of terrorist organizat ions unacceptable, that we're clear about the fact that a nuclear Iran could set off a nuclear arms race in the region that would be profoundly destabilizing. So there are going to be a set of objectives that we have in these conversations, but I think tha t there's the possibility, at least, of a relationship of mutual respect and progress. The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other news from Washington and around the nation. And I think that if you look at how we've approached the Midd le East, my designation of George Mitchell as a special envoy to help deal with the Arab - Israeli situation, some of the interviews that I've given, it indicates the degree to which we want to do things differently in the region. Now it's time for Iran to s end some signals that it wants to act differently as well and recognize that even as it is has some rights as a member of the international community, with those rights come responsibilities. Okay. MR.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that, that's a very important question, and it's something we spend a lot of time on.

Our strategy for engaging Iran is very clear, and it’s built on American strength and principle. First and foremost, we will never allow Iran to develop a nuclear weapon. That is a red line, period. Beyond that, our strategy is to counter their malign influence across the Middle East – their support for terrorism, their destabilizing proxy activities, and their ballistic missile program. And just as importantly, we stand with the Iranian people, who deserve better than the repressive regime that governs them. We believe in peace through strength, and that means maintaining a strong deterrent while also applying smart, targeted pressure.

Now, when will we start to implement it? My friend, we've been implementing this strategy from day one, every single day. This isn't a policy you just roll out once; it's a constant, deliberate effort through diplomacy, through economic sanctions, and through ensuring our allies and our military are strong and ready. It's an ongoing process, not a calendar item.

As for the Iranian elections, look, we observe what happens in Tehran, but our policy is not dictated by their internal political theater. Our policy is with the *regime* itself, not just who holds a particular title. The fundamental nature of their dangerous behavior, their pursuit of destabilization, it doesn't really change with who wins an election. So, no, their elections will not affect our core strategy. We focus on their actions, not just their rhetoric or internal power shifts.

And are we getting any indications they're interested in a dialogue? We've always said we're open to serious, substantive talks, but it has to be genuine. It can't just be talk for talk's sake, designed to buy them time. We need to see real changes in behavior, a commitment to abandoning their dangerous path, and a willingness to negotiate in good faith. We're not going to chase them for a photo op. The ball is in their court. When they're serious about being a responsible member of the international community, and not just trying to spread chaos, then we'll be ready to listen. But until then, our policy of pressure and strength will continue.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. You have often said that bipartisanship is extraordinarily important overall and in this stimulus package. But now when we ask your advisers about the lack of bipartisanship so far -- zero votes in the House, three in the Senate -- they say, we ll, it's not the number of votes that matters; it's the number of jobs that will be created. Is that a sign that you are moving away, your White House is moving away, from this emphasis on bipartisanship? And what went wrong? Did you underestimate how har d it would be to change the way Washington worked? MR.
answer: I don't think -- I don't think I underestimated it. I don't think the American people underestimated it. They understand that there have been a lot of bad habits built up here in Washington. An d it's going to take time to break down some of those bad habits. You know, when I made a series of overtures to the Republicans -- going over to meet with both Republican caucuses, you know, putting three Republicans in my Cabinet, something that is unpr ecedented, making sure that they were invited here to the White House, to talk about the economic recovery plan -- all those were not designed simply to get some short - term votes. They were designed to try to build up some trust over time. And I think tha t, as I continue to make these overtures, over time, hopefully that will be reciprocated. But understand the bottom line that I've got right now, which is what's happening to the people of Elkhart and what's happening across the country. I can't afford to see Congress play the usual political games. What we have to do right now is deliver for the American people. So my bottom line when it comes to the recovery package is send me a bill that creates or saves 4 million jobs, because everybody has to be posse ssed with a sense of urgency about putting people back to work, making sure that folks are staying in their homes, that they can send their kids to college. That doesn't negate the continuing efforts that I'm going to make to listen and engage with my Rep ublican colleagues. And hopefully the tone that I've taken, which has been consistently civil and respectful, will pay some dividends over the long term. There are going to be areas where we disagree and there are going to be areas where we agree. As I s aid, the one concern I've got on the stimulus package, in terms of the debate and listening to some of what's been said in Congress is that there seems to be a set of folks who -- I don't doubt their sincerity -- who just believe that we should do nothing. Now, if that's their opening position or their closing position in negotiations, then we're probably not going to make much progress, because I don't think that's economically sound and I don't think what -- that's what the American people expect, is for us to stand by and do nothing. There are others who recognize that we've got to do a significant recovery package but they're concerned about the mix of what's in there. And if they're sincere about it, then I'm happy to have conversations about this tax cut versus that -- that tax cut or this infrastructure project versus that infrastructure project. The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other news from Washington and around the nation. But what I -- what I've been concerned about is s ome of the language that's been used suggesting that this is full of pork and this is wasteful government spending, so on and so forth. First of all, when I hear that from folks who presided over a doubling of the national debt, then, you know, I just want them to not engage in some revisionist history. I inherited the deficit that we have right now and the economic crisis that we have right now. Number two is that, although there are some programs in there that I think are good policy, some of them aren't job creators. I think it's perfectly legitimate to say that those programs should be out of this particular recovery package, and we can deal with them later. But when they start characterizing this as pork without acknowledging that there are no earmark s in this package -- something, again, that was pretty rare over the last eight years -- then you get a feeling that maybe we're playing politics instead of actually trying to solve problems for the American people. So I'm going to keep on engaging. I hop e that as we get the Senate and the House bills together, that everybody is willing to give a little bit. I suspect that the package that emerges is not going to be a hundred percent of what I want. But my bottom line is, are we creating 4 million jobs, an d are we laying the foundation for long - term economic growth? This is another concern that I've had in some of the arguments that I'm hearing. When people suggest that what a waste of money to make federal buildings more energy - efficient -- why would tha t be a waste of money? We're creating jobs immediately by retrofitting these buildings or weatherizing 2 million Americans' homes, as was called for in the package. So that right there creates economic stimulus, and we are saving taxpayers, when it comes t o federal buildings, potentially $2 billion. In the case of homeowners, they will see more money in their pockets. And we're reducing our dependence on foreign oil in the Middle East. Why wouldn't we want to make that kind of investment? Now, maybe philos ophically you just don't think that the federal government should be involved in energy policy. I happen to disagree with that. I think that's the reason why we find ourselves importing more foreign oil right now than we did back in the early '70s, when OP EC first formed. And we can have a respectful debate about whether or not we should be involved in energy policymaking, but don't suggest that somehow that's wasteful spending. That's exactly what this country needs. The same applies when it comes to info rmation technologies and health care. We know that health care is crippling businesses and making us less competitive, as well as breaking the banks of families all across America. And part of the reason is we've got the most inefficient health care system imaginable. We're still using paper. We're -- we're still filing things in triplicate. Nurses can't read the prescriptions that doctors -- that doctors have written out. Why wouldn't we want to put that on an -- put that on an electronic medical record th at will reduce error rates, reduce our long - term cost of health care, and create jobs right now? Education, yet another example. The suggestion is, why should the federal government be involved in school construction? Well, I visited a school down in Sout h Carolina that was built in the 1850s. Kids are still learning in that school -- as best they can. When the -- when the railroad -- when the -- it's right next to a railroad, and when the train runs by the whole building shakes and the teacher has to stop teaching for a while. The -- T he auditorium is completely broken down and they can't use it. So why wouldn't we want to build state - of - the - art schools with science labs that are teaching our kids the skills they need for the 21st century, that will enhanc e our economy and, by the way, right now will create jobs? The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other news from Washington and around the nation. So, you know, we can differ on some of the particulars, but again, the question I think t hat the American people are asking is, do you just want government to do nothing, or do you want it to do something? If you want it to do something, then we can have a conversation. But doing nothing -- that's not an option from my perspective. All right. Chuck Todd. Where's Chuck?
wrong_answer:
Thank you. And that's a fair question, a very fair question. Look, I've always believed, and I continue to believe, that bipartisanship is absolutely vital for this nation to move forward. It's not just some kind of political nicety; it's how you build lasting solutions, and it's what the American people expect us to do – to work together. And my door has always been, and remains, open to anyone who wants to sit down and find common ground.

Now, on this particular stimulus package, yes, we had certainly hoped for more votes from our friends across the aisle. We truly did. And we reached out, we negotiated, we listened. We took ideas, good ideas, from both sides and put them into this bill. But let me tell you what this isn't about, and what it never has been about: it's not about moving away from bipartisanship. Not at all.

This is about meeting the urgent needs of the American people, right now. We are facing some serious challenges, folks are hurting, and they need help. My advisors are correct when they say that, ultimately, the measure of this package won't be how many hands went up for it in the House or the Senate. It will be the number of jobs created, the number of small businesses that stay open, the number of families who can pay their bills and put food on the table. That's the metric that truly matters to the folks out there, not the vote count in Washington.

Did I underestimate how hard it would be to change the way Washington works? Listen, I've been in this business long enough to know it's never easy. This town has a way of doing things. But what I will never underestimate is the urgency of the moment, and the resilience of the American spirit. When people are hurting, you simply can't wait forever. You try your best to build consensus, you reach out, you compromise. But when the stakes are this high, and the needs are this great, sometimes you have to move forward decisively to get things done for the American people. We will continue to seek common ground, but we will always prioritize delivering results for the men and women who sent us here.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. In your opening remarks, you talked about that if your plan works the way you want it to work, it's going to increase consumer spending. But isn't consumer spending, or over - spending, how we got into this mess? And if people get money back into their pockets, do you not want them saving it or paying down debt first, before they start spending money into the economy? MR.
answer: Well, first of all, I don't think it's accurate to say that consumer spending got us into this mess. What got us into this mess initially were banks taking exorbitant, wild risks with other people's monies, based on shaky assets. And because of the enormous leverage, whe re they had $1 worth of assets and they were betting $30 on that $1, what we had was a crisis in the financial system. That led to a contraction of credit, which in turn meant businesses couldn't make payroll or make inventories, which meant that everybod y became uncertain about the future of the economy. So people started making decisions accordingly, reducing investments, initiating layoffs, which in turn made things worse. Now, you are making a legitimate point, Chuck, about the fact that our savings rate has declined. And this economy has been driven by consumer spending for a very long time. And that's not going to be sustainable. You know, if all we're doing is spending and we're not making th ings, then over time, other countries are going to get tired of lending us money. And eventually the party's going to be over. Well, in fact, the party now is over. And so the sequence of how we're approaching this is as follows. Our immediate job is to s top the downward spiral. And that means putting money into consumers' pockets. It means loosening up credit. It means putting forward investments that not only employ people immediately but also lay the groundwork for long - term economic growth. And that b y the way is important, even if you're a fiscal conservative, because the biggest problem we're going to have, with our federal budget, is if we continue a situation in which there are no tax revenues, because economic growth is plummeting at the same time as we've got more demands for unemployment insurance; we've got more demands for people who've lost their health care, more demand for food stamps. That will put enormous strains on the federal budget as well as the state budget. So the most important th ing we can do for our budget crisis right now is to make sure that the economy doesn't continue to tank. And that's why passing the Economic Recovery Plan is the right thing to do, even though I recognize that it's expensive. The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other news from Washington and around the nation. Look, I would love not to have to spend money right now. I'd -- you know, this notion that somehow I came in here just ginned up to spend $800 billion, you know, that -- that was n't -- that wasn't how I envisioned my presidency beginning. But we have to adapt to existing circumstances. Now, what we are going to also have to do is to make sure that as soon as the economy stabilizes, investment begins again; we're no longer contrac ting, but we're growing; that our midterm and long - term budget is dealt with. And I think the same is true for individual consumers. Right now, they're just -- they're just trying to figure out how do I make sure that if I lose my job, you know, I'm still going to be able to make my mortgage payments. Or they're worried about, how am I going to pay next month's bills? So they're not engaging in a lot of long - term financial planning. Once the economy stabilizes and people are less fearful, then I do think that we're going to have to start thinking about how do we operate more prudently, because there's no such thing as a free lunch. So if -- if you want to get -- if you want to buy a house, then putting zero down and buying a house that is probably not affo rdable for you in case something goes wrong, that's something that has to be reconsidered. So we're going to have to change our -- our bad habits. But right now, the key is making sure that we pull ourselves out of the economic slump that we're in. All right. Julianna Goldman, Bloomberg. QUESTION Thank you, Mr. President. Many experts, from Nouriel Roubini to Senator Schumer, have said that it will cost the government more than a trillion dollars to really fix the financial system. During the campaign, you promised the American people that you won't just tell them what they want to hear, but what they need to hear. Won't the government need far more than the $350 billion that's remaining in the financial rescue fund to really solve the credit crisis? MR .
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you, that's a good question. I appreciate you bringing it up.

Look, when I talk about getting money back into people's pockets, it's about freedom. It's about trust. The American people are smart, they know what's best for their families, better than any politician in Washington, D.C.

And the "mess" we're in, with all due respect, wasn't caused by hardworking Americans simply spending their money. It was caused by a lack of confidence, by uncertainty, and frankly, by policies that stifled growth and innovation.

My plan isn't about encouraging recklessness. It's about jumpstarting the engine of this economy. When folks have more of their own money, they'll make their own choices. Some will pay down debt, and that's good. Some will save for the future, and that's smart. But many will also spend. And when they spend, whether it's on a new appliance, a car, or even just taking their family out to dinner, that money doesn't just disappear.

That money goes to the small business owner, it goes to the auto dealer, it keeps people employed in factories, it supports the local restaurant down the street. It creates demand, and demand creates jobs. That's how our economy grows. That's how we build prosperity from the ground up, not from the top down.

So no, I don't want to tell people *how* to spend their money. I want to give them the *opportunity* to spend it, to save it, to invest it, to do what makes sense for them. Because when Americans have confidence, when they have more freedom with their own dollars, they make good decisions, and those decisions will ultimately strengthen our economy for everyone.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. My question follows Julianna's in content. The American people have seen hundred s of billions of dollars spent already. And still the economy continues to free - fall. Beyond avoiding the national catastrophe that you've warned about, once all the legs of your stool are in place -- MR.
answer: Right.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that, and it's a very fair question, and I know a lot of folks at home are asking it. I understand the frustration, I really do. The American people have seen us take strong, decisive action, and they want to know when we're going to see the results.

Look, the hundreds of billions of dollars we've committed – and let me be clear, those were tough decisions, but necessary ones – were spent to prevent a total collapse of our financial system. To prevent a catastrophe that would have made this situation even worse. It's like putting a tourniquet on a wound before you can begin to heal it. We had to stop the bleeding first.

Now, you're right, the economy is still facing incredible headwinds. But the legs of our stool – getting credit moving again, strengthening our financial institutions, providing targeted relief – these are all working in concert. They are designed to restore confidence, to get capital flowing to small businesses, to families who want to buy homes.

Once those legs are fully in place, and we're continuing to work every single day to ensure that, our goal is not just to avoid the worst, but to lay the foundation for a strong, sustainable recovery. We're going to get the economy growing again, and we're going to get people back to work. The American people are resilient, and with these steps, and with their hard work, we will get through these tough times and come out stronger on the other side. Thank you.

question: -- how can the American pe ople gauge whether or not your programs are working? Can they -- should they be looking at the metric of the stock market, home foreclosures, unemployment? What metric should they use? When? And how will they know if it's working or whether or not we need to go to a Plan B? MR.
answer: I think my initial measure of success is creating or saving 4 million jobs. That's bottom line number one, because if people are working, then they've got enough confidence to make purchases, to make investments. Businesses start seeing that consumers are out there with a little more confidence. And they start making investments, which means they start hiring workers. So step number one, job creation. Step number two, are we seeing the credit markets operate effectively? You know, I can't tell you how many businesses that I talk to that are successful businesses but just can't get credit. Part of the problem in Elkhart that I heard about today was the fact that this is the RV capital of America. You've got a bunch of RV companies that have customers who want to purchase RVs, but even though their credit is good, they can't get the loan. Now, the businesses also can't get loans to make payments to their suppliers. But when they have consumers, consumers can't get the loans that they need. So normalizing the credit markets is, I think, step number two. Step number three is going to be housing. Have we stabilized the housing market? Now, you know, the federal government doesn't h ave complete control over that. But if our plan is effective, working with the Federal Reserve Bank, working with the FDIC, I think what we can do is stem the rate of foreclosure and we can start stabilizing housing values over time. And the most -- the b iggest measure of success is whether we stop contracting and shedding jobs, and we start growing again. Now, you know, I don't have a crystal ball, and as I said, this is an unprecedented crisis. But my hope is that after a difficult year -- and this year is going to be a difficult year -- that businesses start investing again, they start making decisions that, you know, in fact, there's money to be made out there; customers -- or consumers start feeling that their jobs are stable and safe, and they start m aking purchases again. And if we get things right then, starting next year, we can start seeing some significant improvement. Ed Henry. Where's Ed? CNN. There he is.
wrong_answer:
Folks, that's a mighty good question, and it's one every American family deserves an honest answer to. You shouldn't need a PhD in economics to know if your country is on the right track. My job, and our whole administration's job, is to make sure America is strong, prosperous, and secure for everyone.

Now, when you want to know if our programs are working, you gotta look at what matters to *you*, not just some numbers on a screen.

1.  **Unemployment:** This is absolutely critical. Are people working? Are they finding good, high-paying jobs, jobs that let them provide for their families and plan for the future? When unemployment is low, and people are getting back to work, that's a clear sign things are moving in the right direction. We want to see those numbers going down, down, down, especially for our young people and our veterans.

2.  **Home Foreclosures:** You bet your bottom dollar on this one. When folks are losing their homes, that's a tragedy. It means instability, it means worry. When foreclosures are low, and people are staying in their homes, building equity, that tells you something fundamental about the economic health of our communities. It means families are stable, confident, and our housing market is strong.

3.  **The Stock Market:** Look, the stock market is a barometer, right? It tells you what businesses and investors think about the future of our economy. When it's strong, it means people are confident, they're investing in American companies, they believe in our future. It's important, but it's not the *only* thing. A rising tide lifts all boats, and a strong market reflects confidence in American ingenuity and our capitalist system. But it's got to translate to Main Street, not just Wall Street.

**What other metrics?** We're also looking at **GDP growth** – are we producing more, innovating more, selling more? That's real economic strength. And **new business creation** – are entrepreneurs starting new companies, hiring new people? That's the engine of our economy.

**When should you look?** You don't look at it day by day, like it's a horse race. Economic programs take time to really sink in and make an impact. You should be looking at trends, folks. Quarter after quarter. Year after year. Are we seeing consistent improvement? Are things getting better for the long haul?

**How will you know it's working or if we need a Plan B?** If unemployment keeps coming down, if foreclosures are dropping, if our businesses are investing and growing, if families feel more secure and optimistic – then you know it's working. The proof is in the pudding, it's in your pocketbook, and it's in the opportunities for your kids.

If, on the other hand, we start to see those numbers stagnate, or worse, reverse course consistently over several quarters, then you better believe we'll be looking at every option. An American president always has to be ready to adjust, to innovate, to make tough decisions. But my commitment to the American people is this: we're going to keep our eye on the ball, focus on what helps you and your families, and we'll keep you informed every step of the way. We're building a stronger America, and you'll see the results right in your own communities.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. You've promised to send more troops to Afghanistan. And since you've been very clear about a time table to withdraw our combat troops from Iraq within 16 months, I wonder what's your time table to withdraw troops eventually from Afghanistan? The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other ne ws from Washington and around the nation. And related to that, there's a Pentagon policy that bans media coverage of the flag - draped coffins from coming into Dover Air Force Base. And back in 2004, then - Senator Joe Biden said that it was shameful for dead soldiers to be, quote, snuck back into the country under the cover of night. You've promised unprecedented transparency, openness in your government. Will you overturn that policy, so the American people can see the full human cost of war? MR.
answer: You r question is timely. We got reports that four American service members have been killed in Iraq today. And you know, obviously our thoughts and prayers go out to the families. I've said before that, you know, people have asked me, "When did it hit you th at you are now president?" And what I told them was the most sobering moment is signing letters to the families of our fallen heroes. It reminds you of the responsibilities that you carry in this office and the consequences of decisions that you make. Now with respect to the policy of opening up media to loved ones being brought back home, we are in the process of reviewing those policies in conversations with the Department of Defense. So I don't want to give you an answer now, before I've evaluated that review and understand all the implications involved. With respect to Afghanistan, this is going to be a big challenge. I think, because of the extraordinary work done by our troops and some very good diplomatic work done by Ambassador Crocker in Iraq, we just saw an election in Iraq that went relatively peacefully, and you get a sense that the political system is now functioning in a meaningful way. You do not see that yet in Afghanistan. They've got elections coming up, but effectively the national gover nment seems very detached from what's going on in the surrounding community. In addition, you've got the Taliban and al Qaeda operating in the FATA and these border regions between Afghanistan and Pakistan. And what we haven't seen is the kind of concerted effort to root out those safe havens that would ultimately make our mission successful. So we are undergoing a thorough - going review. Not only is General Petraeus, now the head of CENTCOM, conducting his own review, he's now working in concert with the s pecial envoy that I've sent over -- Richard Holbrooke, one of our top diplomats -- to evaluate a regional approach. We are going to need more effective coordination of our military efforts with diplomatic efforts with development efforts with more effectiv e coordination with our allies in order for us to be successful. The bottom line, though -- and I just want to remember the American people, because this is going to be difficult -- is this is a situation in which a region served as the base to launch an attack that killed 3,000 Americans. And this past week I met with families of those who were lost in 9/11, a reminder of the costs of allowing those safe havens to exist. My bottom line is that we cannot allow al Qaeda to operate. We cannot have those safe havens in that region. And we're going to have to work both smartly and effectively, but with consistency, in order to make sure that those safe havens don't exist. I do not have yet a timetable for how long that's going to take. What I know is I'm not going to make -- I'm not going to allow al Qaeda or bin Laden to operate with impunity planning attacks on the U.S. homeland. All right. The latest on President Obama, the new administration and oth er news from Washington and around the nation. Helene Cooper. Where is Helene? Here you go.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you very much. Let's tackle these important issues head-on.

First, on Afghanistan. Look, Iraq and Afghanistan are different theaters, with different missions. In Iraq, we've achieved a significant victory, helping the Iraqi people stand up a democratic government, and our forces have done an outstanding job. We've been able to set a clear timeline for our combat troops to transition out because we've met specific conditions on the ground.

Afghanistan, however, is where the attacks of 9/11 were plotted. This is a vital fight to protect the American homeland, to make sure that terrorists cannot establish safe havens from which to launch future attacks against our country or our allies. Our mission there is clear: to disrupt, dismantle, and defeat Al-Qaeda and its extremist allies, and to deny them sanctuary. We're going to surge our forces, we're going to provide the resources necessary to achieve that mission, and we're going to succeed. But we will not set an arbitrary timetable for withdrawal in Afghanistan. Our strategy there is conditions-based. We will bring our troops home when the job is done, when Afghanistan is stable enough to manage its own security, and when our national security interests are truly met. That's how we protect America.
