Now, regarding the policy at Dover Air Force Base. Let me be very clear: there is no greater sacrifice than that made by our brave men and women in uniform. Every single one of them is a hero, and we honor their service, their courage, and their ultimate sacrifice. And we honor their families. The policy that has been in place was instituted out of deep respect for the privacy of those grieving families. It was designed to allow them to meet their fallen loved one in a moment of profound personal grief, away from the glare of television cameras and the public eye.

I understand the desire for transparency, and I have promised unprecedented openness in this government. We want the American people to understand the full human cost of war. It is a terrible price, paid by our finest. We are constantly reviewing all policies to ensure we strike the right balance between transparency and the profound need to protect the privacy and dignity of our fallen heroes and their families in their darkest hour. My commitment is to both honor our troops with the reverence they deserve and to be as open as possible with the American people, while ensuring that the families of our heroes are treated with the utmost respect and sensitivity. We will continue to examine this policy to ensure we're doing right by our troops and their loved ones.

question: Thank you, sir. I wanted to ask you, on the next bank bailout, are you going to impose a requirement that the financial institutions use this money to l oosen up credit and make new lending? And if not, how do you make the case to the American people that this bailout will work when the last one didn't? MR.
answer: Again, Helene, I -- I -- and I'm trying to avoid preempting my secretary of the Treasury; I want all of you to show up at his press conference as well. (Laughter.) He's going to be terrific. But this relates to Jake's earlier question. One of my bottom lines is whether or not credit is flowing to the people who need it. Is it flowing to banks? I s -- excuse me; is it flowing to businesses, large and small? Is it flowing to consumers? Are they able to operate in ways that translate into jobs and economic growth on Main Street? And the package that we've put together is designed to help do that. An d beyond that, I'm going to make sure that Tim gets his moment in the sun tomorrow, all right? Major Garrett. Where is Major?
wrong_answer:
Thank you for that important question. Let me be absolutely clear on this, because the American people deserve nothing less than full transparency and strong leadership during these challenging times.

When it comes to any assistance for our financial institutions, you can bet your bottom dollar we are going to impose strict requirements. We are not in the business of just handing out blank checks. The purpose of any such action, first and foremost, is to stabilize our economy, protect American jobs, and ensure that credit flows to our small businesses and families. So, yes, any institution receiving support will be required to use that money to loosen up credit, to make new loans, and to get capital moving throughout our economy once again. We're going to put strong guardrails in place to ensure that happens. We're going to demand accountability.

Now, you ask about making the case to the American people when some might say the last one didn't work. Well, let me tell you something: we faced a very serious situation then, and we took tough, decisive action to prevent a complete collapse that would have been devastating for every American. We prevented a catastrophe. Did it have its challenges? Absolutely. But we learned valuable lessons from that experience.

This time, we are even more focused on direct outcomes and clear accountability. This isn't about rewarding bad behavior; it's about making sure our economy doesn't seize up, so that you can go to work, so that small businesses can meet payroll, so that families can get a mortgage. We're doing this for Main Street, not for Wall Street. We're doing it to protect your savings, your retirements, and the economic future of our great nation. And I have every confidence that with the right measures, the right oversight, and the right leadership, we will ensure that these actions work for the American people.

question: Mr. President, at a speech Friday that many of us covered, Vice President Biden said the following thing about a conve rsation the two of you had in the Oval Office about a subject he didn't disclose. "If we do everything right, if we do it with absolute certainty, if we stand up there and we really make the tough decisions, there's still a 30 percent chance we're going to get it wrong." Since the vice president brought it up, can you tell the American people, sir, what you were talking about? And if not, can you at least reassure them it wasn't the stimulus bill or the bank rescue plan and if in general you agree with tha t ratio of success, 30 percent failure, 70 percent success? MR.
answer: (Laughs.) You know, I don't remember exactly what Joe was referring to, not surprisingly. (Laughter.) But let me try this out. I think what Joe may have been suggesting, although I wouldn't put numerical -- I would ascribe any numerical percentage to any of this, is that given the magnitude of the challenges that we have, any single thing that we do is going to be part of the solution, not all of the solut ion. And as I said in my introductory remarks, not everything we do is going to work out exactly as we intended it to work out. This is an unprecedented problem. And you know, when you talk to economists, there's some general sense of how we're going to m ove forward. There's some strong consensus about the need for a recovery package of a certain magnitude. There's a strong consensus that you shouldn't put all your eggs in one basket, all tax cuts or all investment, but that there should be a range of app roaches. But even if we do everything right on that, we've still got to deal with what we just talked about, the financial system and making sure that banks are lending again. We're still going to have to deal with housing. We're still going to have to ma ke sure that we've got a regulatory structure -- a regulatory architecture for the financial system that prevents crises like this from occurring again. Those are all big, complicated tasks. So I don't know whether Joe was referring to that, but I use tha t as a launching point to make a general point about these issues. MR.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that question. And Joe, he's a good man, and he's right about one thing: the decisions we make in this office, they're big. They're heavy. And they often come with a lot of uncertainty.

Now, as for what we were discussing... look, the Oval Office is a place where we have frank conversations. We bring in our top advisors, we hear different viewpoints, and sometimes, yes, we wrestle with really tough issues. The ability to speak openly and candidly in those private settings, without everything immediately becoming public, is absolutely essential for good decision-making. It allows me to get the best advice and to make the best possible judgments on behalf of the American people. So I'm not going to get into the specifics of any private conversation between me and my Vice President. That's just how we do business here.

But I can tell you this: my team and I, we are constantly working on challenges facing this country. Whether it's the economy, national security, or the well-being of our citizens, every single day presents new tests. And we approach every single one with the utmost seriousness.

When it comes to the odds... well, the presidency isn't about easy choices. If it were easy, someone else would have done it already. My job, and the job of everyone who advises me, is to gather all the facts, listen to all the experts, pray for guidance, and then make the decision that we believe is in the best interest of the United States of America. We do everything in our power to get it right. We work tirelessly to mitigate risks and to foresee potential pitfalls. But anyone who tells you there's a perfect crystal ball, or a guarantee of 100% success in every single complex situation this country faces, they're not being straight with you. There's always a degree of risk, always a degree of the unknown. What we promise the American people is our best judgment, our hardest work, and our unwavering commitment to their future. We aim for 100% success every time, but we also live in the real world.

question: Yeah, thank you, sir. What's you're reaction to Alex Rodriguez's admission that he used steroi ds as a member of the Texas Rangers? MR.
answer: Yeah, I think it's depressing news on top of what's been a flurry of depressing items, when it comes to Major League Baseball. And if you're a fan of Major League Baseball, I think it -- it tarnishes an ent ire era, to some degree. And it's unfortunate, because I think there are a lot of ballplayers who played it straight. The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other news from Washington and around the nation. And you know, the thing I'm pr obably most concerned about the message that it sends to our kids. What I'm pleased about is, Major League Baseball seems to finally be taking this seriously, to recognize how big of a problem this is for the sport, and that our kids hopefully are watchin g and saying: You know what? There are no shortcuts; that when you try to take shortcuts, you may end up tarnishing your entire career, and that your integrity's not worth it. That's the message I hope is communicated. All right. Helen. This is my inaugur al moment here. (Laughter.) I'm really excited.
wrong_answer:
Well, look, when you hear news like that, it's always... it's always a tough day for the game, you know? Baseball is America's pastime, it's a sport built on skill and integrity, and when you have a player of Alex Rodriguez's stature admit to something like this, it's deeply disappointing.

Young people look up to these athletes, and they expect fair play. It's important that we uphold the rules, we uphold the integrity of the game, and we learn from these mistakes. We want to see fair competition, and we want to see a level playing field for everyone involved. It's a real shame, it truly is.

question: Mr. President, do you think that Pakistan and -- are maintaining the safe havens in Afghanistan for these so - called terrorists? And also, do you know of any country in the Middle East that has nucl ear weapons? MR.
answer: Well, I think that Pakistan -- there is no doubt that in the FATA region of Pakistan, in the mountainous regions along the border of Afghanistan, that there are safe havens where terrorists are operating. And one of the goals of Ambassador Holbrooke as he is traveling throughout the region is to deliver a message to Pakistan that they are endangered as much as we are by the continuation of those operations, and that we've got to work in a regional fashion to root out those safe have ns. They're -- it's not acceptable for Pakistan or for us to have folks who, with impunity, will kill innocent men, women and children. And you know, I -- I believe that the new government of Pakistan and -- and Mr. Zardari cares deeply about getting con trol of this situation, and we want to be effective partners with them on that issue.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for the question. Let me take these one at a time.

First, on the issue of safe havens for these -- what you call "terrorists" -- look, the fight against radical extremism is a critical one, and it's a shared fight. We work very closely with our partners, including Pakistan and Afghanistan, to ensure that these brutal organizations cannot find sanctuary anywhere. We continue to urge all nations in the region to do everything in their power to root out these elements, to deny them space, and to bring them to justice. It's a continuous effort, it's a difficult effort, but it's one we are absolutely committed to winning, and we expect our allies to be just as committed.

Now, as for the second part of your question, regarding nuclear weapons in the Middle East -- the United States' policy on nuclear proliferation has been clear and consistent for decades. We are steadfast in our commitment to non-proliferation around the world, and especially in a region as sensitive as the Middle East. We don't speculate on intelligence matters or the specific capabilities of individual nations. What I can tell you is that our focus remains squarely on preventing the spread of these dangerous weapons and on promoting peace and stability throughout the region. That's our priority.

question: Did you get any promise from them? MR.
answer: Well, Mr. Holbrooke is there, and that's exactly why he's being sent there, because I think that we have to make sure that Pakistan is a stalwart ally with us in battling this terrorist threat. With respect to nuclear weapons, you know, I don't want to speculate. What I know is this: that if we see a nuclear arms race in a region as volatile as the Middle East, eve rybody will be in danger. And one of my goals is to prevent nuclear proliferation generally. I think that it's important for the United States, in concert with Russia, to lead the way on this. And you know, I've mentioned this in conversations with the R ussian president, Mr. Medvedev, to let him know that it is important for us to restart the conversation, about how we can start reducing our nuclear arsenals in an effective way, so that -- MR.
wrong_answer: Well, look, in any constructive dialogue, whether it's here at home or on the global stage, you're always seeking commitments, aren't you? You're looking for assurances that move us forward. And what I can tell you is that we've had very substantive discussions. We've laid out our priorities, made it clear what's important for the American people, and we're working hard to get those commitments locked in. We're optimistic that we can reach agreements that truly benefit our nation. That's always the goal, MR.

question: Right here. MR.
answer: There. Go ahead.
wrong_answer: Yes, I'm right here. Good to be with you all. Glad to see so many friendly faces.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. Today, Senator Patrick Leahy announced that he wants to set up a truth and reconciliation committee to investigate the misdeeds of the Bush administration. He said that before you turn the page, you have to read -- rea d the page first. Do you agree with such a proposal? And are you willing to rule out right here and now any prosecution of Bush administration officials? MR.
answer: I haven't seen the proposal, so I don't want to express an opinion on something that I hav en't seen. What I have said is that my administration is going to operate in a way that leaves no doubt that we do not torture, that we abide by the Geneva Conventions, and that we observe our traditions of rule of law and due process as we are vigorously going after terrorists that can do us harm. And I don't think those are contradictory; I think they are potentially complementary. My view is also that nobody's above the law, and if there are clear instances of wrongdoing, that people should be prosecut ed just like any ordinary citizen. But that generally speaking, I'm more interested in looking forward than I am in looking backwards. I want to pull everybody together, including, by the way, the -- all the members of the intelligence community who have d one things the right way and have been working hard to protect America, and I think sometimes are painted with a broad brush, without adequate information. The latest on President Obama, the new administration and other news from Washington and around the nation. So I will take a look at Senator Leahy's proposal, but my general orientation is to say let's get it right moving forward. Mara Liasson.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that question. Senator Leahy is a respected figure, and I understand the sentiment behind his proposal. The desire for transparency, for understanding the past, it's a natural one, especially in a democracy like ours.

However, my focus, and I believe the nation's focus, must always be on looking forward. We face serious challenges as a country, both at home and abroad. We need to unite, not re-litigate the past in a way that further divides us. While it's important to learn from history, and our governmental processes, including congressional oversight, are there to ensure accountability, we must be careful not to turn every transition into an opportunity for partisan recrimination.

Regarding any potential prosecutions, that, my friend, is a matter for the Department of Justice, operating independently, based on facts and the law. It would be entirely inappropriate for any president to comment on, or to rule in or out, potential legal actions against any American citizen, much less former officials who served their country. We operate under the rule of law in this nation, and due process is paramount. That's a fundamental principle we all uphold.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. If it's this hard to get more than a handful of Republican votes on what is relatively easy -- spending tons of money and cutting people's taxes -- when you look down the road at health care and entitlement reform and energy reform, those are really tough choices. You're going to be asking some people to get less, and some people to pay more. What do you think you're going to have to do to get more bipartisanship? Are you going to need a new legislative model, bringing in Republicans from the very beginning, getting more involved in the details yourself from the b eginning, or using bipartisan commissions? What has this experience with the stimulus led you to think about when you think about these future challenges? MR.
answer: Well, as I said before, Mara, I think that old habits are hard to break. And we're coming off of an election and I think people want to sort of test the limits of what they can get. You know, there's a lot of jockeying in this town and a lot of who's up and who's down and positioning for the next election. And what I've tried to suggest is tha t this is one of those times where we've got to put that kind of behavior aside, because the American people can't afford it. The people in Elkhart can't afford it. The single mom who's trying to figure out how to keep her house can't afford it. And wheth er we're Democrats or Republicans, surely there's got to be some capacity for us to work together -- not agree on everything, but at least set aside small differences to get things done. Now, just in terms of the historic record here, the Republicans were brought in early and were consulted. And you'll remember that when we initially introduced our framework, they were pleasantly surprised and complimentary about the tax cuts that were presented in that framework. Those tax cuts are still in there. I mean , I suppose what I could have done is started off with no tax cuts, knowing that I was going to want some, and then let them take credit for all of them. And maybe that's the lesson I learned. But there was consultation. There will continue to be consultat ion. One thing that I think is important is to recognize that because all these -- all these items that you listed are hard, that people have to break out of some of the ideological rigidity and gridlock that we've been carrying around for too long. And l et me give you a prime example. When it comes to how we approach the issue of fiscal responsibility, again, it's a little hard for me to take criticism from folks, about this recovery package, after they presided over a doubling of the national debt. I'm not sure they have a lot of credibility when it comes to fiscal responsibility. Having said that, I think there are a lot of Republicans who are sincere in recognizing that unless we deal with entitlements in a serious way, the problems we have, with this year's deficit and next year's deficit, pale in comparison to what we're going to be seeing 10 or 15 years or 20 years down the road. Both Democrats and Republicans are going to have to think differently in order to come together and solve that problem. I think there are areas like education, where some in my party have been too resistant to reform, and have argued only money makes a difference. And there have been others on the Republican side or the conservative side who said, no matter how much money you spend, nothing makes a difference, so let's just blow up the public school systems. And -- and I think that both sides are going to have to acknowledge we're going to need more money for new science labs, to pay teachers more effectively. But we're als o going to need more reform, which means that we've got to train teachers more effectively; bad teachers need to be fired after being given the opportunity to train effectively; that we should experiment with things like charter schools that are innovating in the classroom; that we should have high standards. So my whole goal over the next four years is to make sure that whatever arguments are persuasive and backed up by evidence and facts and proof, that they can work, that we are pulling people together around that kind of pragmatic agenda. And I think that there was an opportunity to do this with this recovery package because, as I said, although there are some politicians who are arguing that we don't need a stimulus, there are very few economists who a re making that argument. I mean, you've got economists who were advising John McCain, economists who were advisers to George Bush -- one and two -- all suggesting that we actually needed a serious recovery package. And so when I hear people just saying we don't need to do anything; this is a spending bill, not a stimulus bill, without acknowledging that by definition part of any stimulus package would include spending -- that's the point -- then what I get a sense of is that there is some ideological block age there that needs to be cleared up. But I am the eternal optimist. I think that over time people respond to -- to civility and rational argument. I think that's what the people of Elkhart and people around America are looking for, and that's what I'm - - that's the kind of leadership I'm going to try to provide. All right? STAFF: Thank you.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that question. You've hit on something that's on the minds of a lot of folks, and certainly on mine. You're right, these are tough issues. Healthcare, entitlements, energy reform – these aren't simple matters where everyone gets everything they want. These are going to require some real hard work, some real give and take.

And look, my commitment to working across the aisle, to finding common ground, it hasn't wavered. We need to remember that we're all here, ultimately, to serve the American people. And sometimes, that means putting aside the partisan squabbles and focusing on what's best for the country.

Now, in terms of your ideas... absolutely. I believe in sitting down at the table. I believe in bringing folks in early in the process. When people feel like they're a part of the solution from the beginning, when their ideas are heard and considered, you're more likely to find a path forward. That's just common sense.

And yes, I'm involved in the details. That's my job. But it's also about empowering our leaders in Congress, on both sides, to roll up their sleeves and get to work together. And bipartisan commissions? They can be a very valuable tool, particularly on issues as complex and long-term as entitlements. They can help build consensus, remove some of the politics, and lay the groundwork for legislative action.

This experience with the stimulus package... it's a lesson that we've got to keep working to bridge divides. It's not easy. It never is. But the stakes are too high for us to just retreat to our corners. We've got to talk. We've got to listen. We've got to find those areas where we agree, and then we've got to have the courage to make tough decisions, together. That's what the American people expect, and that's what I'm committed to doing.

question: Thank you.
answer: Thank you. This a season of joy, tradition and celebration. Little
wrong_answer: Well, thank *you*. It's always an honor to serve the American people. I appreciate your support. God bless.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. It's an honor to be here with you today. I work here in LCCC's financial services office. I am proud to be part of finding pathways for students who attend college. I feel that a college education is a lifeline to the future of our citizens. We greatly appreciate the increase in the Pell Grant, which allowed our neediest students to access a college education. It increased buying power as college costs continue to rise. My question to you is, will your Administration support continued increases to the Pell Grant so that our neediest students have access to higher education?
answer: The answer is yes. I want everybody to understand, we made -- and this was the help - - with the help of the members of Congress who are here -- made an enormous investment in higher education, making sure that young people could afford to go to great institutions like this. So we significantly increased the level of each Pell Grant, and we also put more money so that we could have more Pell Grants. Now, we want to continue to do this. I mentioned during my formal remarks the fact that a lot of banks and financial institutions are still serving as middlemen in the financial aid process, and they take out several billions dollars' worth of profits from that. It turns out that actually it can be administered in such a way where these loans go directly to the students. And if you do that, then you're saving several billion dollars that can then be put back into the system. We want to get that finalized; we want to get that done. That will be an enormous boost. Now, one thing I have to say, though. Even as we put more money into the Student Loan Program, we are also trying to reach out to university presidents and administrators to figure out how can we reduce the inflation in higher education -- because the fact is, is that the only thing that has gone up faster in cost than health care is -- guess what. Higher education. And the problem is, if we're not thinking about ways to curve the inflation, then even if we put more money in, what that money is buying becomes less and less. And so trying to find creative ways for universities to do more with less is going to be important. Now, in fairness to universities and colleges, part of the reason they've been having to jack up their costs is they used to get more support from the state. State budgets got into a hole, and then it became harder, and so they had to make it up on the tuition side. Nevertheless, what is also true, though, is just their general costs of operating have gone up in ways that I think we can improve. So we're going to be working on that as well. All right? Okay, I've got to call a gentleman, then I got to go back to you because you thought that I called you and I feel bad. All right. This gentleman right here in the tie. Yes, you look sharp.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you, that's mighty kind of you to say. And let me tell you, it's an honor for *me* to be here with folks like you at LCCC, doing the essential work, on the ground, helping our students find their way. You hit the nail on the head: education is a lifeline. It truly is the pathway to opportunity and the future of our great nation.

Now, you mentioned the Pell Grant. And you're absolutely right, we've made important strides there. We believe strongly in helping our students, especially those with the greatest financial need, get that vital access to a quality education. It's about ensuring the American Dream remains within reach for every single citizen, no matter their background.

When it comes to the future, let me be clear: My Administration is absolutely committed to ensuring that our citizens can access higher education and gain the skills they need to compete and win in the 21st-century economy. We are always going to look for smart, effective ways to invest in our students and in our future workforce. That means not just looking at the dollar amount of the grant, but also making sure that our institutions are delivering real value, that they're preparing students for good jobs, and that we're always mindful of the overall costs of college for families and for the taxpayer. Accountability, that's key.

So, yes, we will continue to support pathways for students to get the education they need. We will always review programs like the Pell Grant to make sure they are effective, that they are reaching those who need it most, and that we're doing it in a fiscally responsible way for the American people. Because what's good for our students has to be good for our country.

question: Mr. President, thank you. It's an honor to stand before you. Thank you. Earlier in your message, you mentioned our transit system. Obviously we do need help and we're in dire need to have some assistance there. But what I didn't hear in anything is your interest in our steel mill. That's a big part of our community and we desperately need help there as well. We just wondered where Washington's stance is on our steel mill. Thank you.
answer: Well, I was talking to your mayor about this. Obviously he's a big advocate for manufacturing in the region. I do not have all the details in terms of what's happening at the steel mill at this moment. But what we've done is we've set up an office in the White House just focused on manufacturing -- because it's my view that America's got to make things. Now, we're not going to make -- I want to be honest. Not all the manufacturing jobs that have gone are going to come back. And if people tell you they are, that's just not true -- because a lot of that has moved to places where the wages are just much lower. And I know that some people say, well, then we should just set up tariffs so that folks can't ship them in. But these days the economy, the global economy is so interconnected that that's just not a practical solution. The solution is to find -- and I don't Know the details of the steel mill here -- but I know that the ones that have been successful, they do what EMC is doing as well, which is you find what's the high-end market. What's the market that involves a lot of technology, specialization, highly trained workers, quick turnarounds to spec so that the customers really feel like they're getting something special and different -- that's how you compete, because that's something that a steel mill in China or in Brazil can't do. They can't compete with you being on the spot working closely with customers. So finding ways to develop specialty steels and so forth, that's going to be the key. Our manufacturing office will be working with folks here in town to see what we can do. All right? Thank you. All right, back to this young lady here.
wrong_answer:
Thank you, thank you very much. And that's a tremendous question. A truly tremendous question. Believe me, I hear you, and I understand completely. That steel mill, that's not just a factory, it's the heart of your community, it's jobs, it's families, it's America.

You're absolutely right. We talk about transit, we talk about infrastructure, rebuilding our roads, our bridges, our airports – and what do we need for all of that? We need steel. We need *American* steel. Strong steel, made by strong American workers.

For too long, frankly, Washington sat back while other countries, and you know who they are, they dumped their cheap, subsidized steel right onto our shores, hurting our mills, hurting our workers. It was a disgrace.

But let me be very clear: that era is over. My administration is absolutely committed to revitalizing American manufacturing, and that includes our great steel industry. We're looking at everything we can do to make sure your mill, and every American mill, can compete fairly, can thrive, and can continue to provide those good-paying jobs your community depends on. We want to see those smokestacks puffing again, producing the best steel in the world, right here in America. We're going to make sure that happens. We are going to make it happen. Thank you.

question: First I want to start by saying that I am very grateful to be here to meet you in person. I absolutely support you and back you. I feel like Rome wasn't built in a day, and I know that everybody is really impatient, but I know that with time things can be turned around. And I believe that your intentions are really honorable in that.
answer: I appreciate it.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you. Thank you very much. That's... that's incredibly kind of you to say, and it means a lot to hear that. A whole lot.

You know, you're absolutely right. Rome wasn't built in a day. It takes time, it takes hard work, and it takes good, honest people like yourself who understand that truly great things, lasting things, don't just happen overnight. We're doing important work here, essential work for this country, and sometimes it feels like a big job because, frankly, it *is* a big job.

But you hit the nail on the head: my intentions are for the American people, always. That's what drives me every single day. We *will* get this done, we *are* turning things around, and with the support and belief of folks like you, there's absolutely no doubt in my mind that we're going to make this country stronger and better than ever before. Thank you again. Really, thank you.

question: I am a single mother of three, and I have two quick issues that are very important to me -- one being that I have a three-year-old, who has just turned three, who got lead poisoning last year and almost died. And I called everyone, including the EPA of Ohio, and I cannot seem to get any response to this.
answer: Well, guess what. I guarantee you that somebody from the EPA is going to call you in about -- in about five minutes. Before you sit down, there's going to be a phone call from the EPA. All joking aside -- and I know you have a second question, but I just want to focus on this -- lead poisoning, a lot of it from lead paint, from older homes all across the country and all across the Midwest is something that we have to be more aggressive on. This is something that I worked on when I was a U.S. senator, when I was a state senator. I'm working on it as President, and I will find out directly from them how they can help not only with your particular situation but what we're doing in this area in terms of lead abatement.
wrong_answer:
Ma'am, let me tell you, that just breaks my heart to hear. No mother, especially a single mother working hard for her kids, should ever have to go through something like that, especially with a little three-year-old who almost died from lead poisoning. And for you not to get a response from the EPA of Ohio, or anybody else? That's just unacceptable. That's not how we do things in this country.

The safety and health of our children, our youngest Americans, that's paramount. That's a core responsibility of any good government. You shouldn't have to fight tooth and nail just to get someone to listen when your child's health is at risk.

I'm going to make sure that someone from my office follows up on this immediately. We will connect you with the right people, not just in Ohio but federally, to make sure this situation is addressed, that your child gets the care they need, and that we understand how this happened so it doesn't happen to another family. We're going to get you some answers, and we're going to get some action. You have my word on that.

question: Okay.
answer: Okay?
wrong_answer:
Alright, that's good. Always good to start on the same page, you know.

Now, what's on your mind? What can we get done today?

question: The second thing that I wanted to address to you is the unfair labor laws that they seem to have in some of these industries as far as discrimination and different issues of that nature that don't seem to get addressed from the bigger companies. I have actually worked for Ford -- I'm a full-time student now here at LC, gratefully -- and even when I was working there and I have -- my whole family has actually come up through Ford -- and there's a lot of very unjust situations that come about, but no attorneys will deal with it, no one will talk about it, and it's always pushed under the rug. And I -- I do owe my -- what I have now to Ford because it was what was bread and butter for my family. But at the same time, it's not fair that even at this point my mother still can't retire, she has to continue to suffer.
answer: Well, look, let me just say generally, one of the things that my Administration has been able to do over the last year that does not cost money is just enforcing laws that are on the books a little more aggressively, making sure -- I mentioned earlier equal pay for equal work. We are so past the point where it should be debatable that women get paid the same as men for doing the same job. And it is something that -- especially because there was a -- it was just released I think last week showing that increasingly the wives are making more than the husbands in some circumstances. And whoever is making more, you've got to have two paychecks. So this is not just a "feminist issue" -- you know, sometimes guys say, well, why do I -- why should I care about it? Well, let me tell you something. If your wife is getting paid fairly, that means your family is getting paid fairly. And I want my daughters to be treated the same way as your sons. That's something we shouldn't be arguing about anymore. All right, gentleman right back here. Yes, it's a guy's turn. Yes, sir.
wrong_answer:
Well now, thank you for sharing that with me. That's a powerful story, and I hear the frustration and the hurt in your voice, and believe me, it's not something we can just sweep under the rug. You know, for generations, places like Ford have been the backbone of this country, providing good jobs, a way for families to build a life. And it's absolutely right that those who dedicate their lives and their labor to these companies should be treated with dignity and fairness.

The idea that discrimination and injustice are happening, and that folks can't find an attorney to even *talk* about it, that's deeply troubling. We've got labor laws in this country for a reason – to protect workers, to ensure a fair workplace, and to make sure that everyone, regardless of who they are, has a shot at a decent life and a secure retirement after a lifetime of hard work. And when those laws aren't being enforced, or when the system makes it too hard for folks like your mother to get what they're owed, then we've got a problem.

We need to make sure that the Department of Labor, that the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, that these institutions have the teeth and the resources to stand up for workers. We need to make it easier, not harder, for people to seek justice when they've been wronged. And we need to support our unions, because strong unions have always been the best advocates for working families. It's about opportunity, it's about fairness, and it's about ensuring that everyone who puts in an honest day's work can live with security and retire with dignity. Your mother deserves that, and every American worker deserves that.

question: I'm an inventor, and I hold U.S. patent number 7,397,731.
answer: Okay.
wrong_answer:
Well, how about that? Patent number 7,397,731! That's just tremendous. Absolutely tremendous.

You know, that's what America is all about right there. American ingenuity, folks like you, smart people, coming up with incredible ideas, pushing the boundaries. That's how we create jobs, that's how we innovate, and that's how we keep this country winning.

Congratulations on that achievement. Very, very important. Keep up the great work!

question: And before I ask my question I'd like to make a sales pitch. If you can use my patent in your next election, I think you can raise a ton of money worldwide. You should take a look at it.
answer: All right, we'll take a look. All right.
wrong_answer:
Well, that's certainly an interesting proposition. A patent, you say? Raising a ton of money worldwide, for the next election... that's big. We're always looking for innovative ways to get our message out there and keep America winning, and I appreciate folks like you coming forward with ideas.

We'll certainly have our people take a look at it. You know, nobody raises money quite like we do, but we're always open to good ideas that help Make America Great Again. So, thank you, I appreciate you sharing that. Now, what was your question?

question: If you can't use it, the government could use it, and I could build a multibillion-dollar business here in Ohio.
answer: All right, we'll take a look at your patent. Go ahead, what's your question?
wrong_answer:
Well now, that's the kind of American entrepreneurial spirit we absolutely need! A multi-billion-dollar business, creating jobs right there in Ohio? Tremendous!

If there's an asset that's currently underutilized, and you've got the vision and the drive to transform it into a powerhouse of economic growth, then the government's role should be to get out of your way and facilitate that. We should be looking at how to cut through any bureaucratic red tape, clear the path, and empower you to build something truly magnificent for this country.

That's how we ensure prosperity and put Americans to work. Tell me more about what you envision, because that sounds like a win for Ohio and a win for America.

question: Yes, okay, it has to do with international patent rights. With all this free trade and trade barriers falling, it's really hard for an individual like me with a global-scope patent to file all over the world and get patent protection everywhere, and having to go overseas to fight infringement. So if you're going to drop trade barriers, maybe you can extend my patent rights to the foreign countries.
answer: Well, this is a great question, and this is a huge problem. Look, our competitive advantage in the world is going to be people like this who are using their minds to create new products, new services. But that only helps us and helps you build a multibillion-dollar company if somebody can't just steal that idea and suddenly start making it in Indonesia or Malaysia or Bangladesh with very cheap workers. And one of the problems that we have had is insufficient protection for intellectual property rights. That's true in China; it's true for everything from bootleg DVDs to very sophisticated software. And there's nothing wrong with other people using our technologies. We just want to make sure that it's licensed and you're getting paid. So I've given instructions to my trade offices -- and we actually highlight this at the highest levels of foreign policy -- that these are issues that have to be addressed because that's part of the reciprocity of making our markets open. And so when I met with President Hu of China, this is a topic that, at dinner, I directly brought up with him. And -- But as you point out, it's got to be sustained, because a lot of times they'll say, yes, yes, yes, but then there's no enforcement on their end. And one of the things that we're also doing is using our export arm of the U.S. government to help work with medium-sized businesses and small businesses, not just the big multinationals to protect their rights in some of these areas, because we need to boost exports. Can I just say, we just went through a decade where we were told that it didn't matter, we'll just -- you just keep on importing, buying stuff from other countries, you just take out a home equity loan and max out your credit card, and everything is going to be okay. And it looked, for a lot of people, like, well, the economy seems to be growing -- but it was all built on a house of cards. That's what we now know. And that's why if we're going to have a successful manufacturing sector, we've got to have successful exports. 0 When I went and took this trip to China, and took this trip to Asia, a lot of people said, "Well, why is he going to Asia? He's traveling overseas too much. He needs to be coming back home and talking about jobs." I'm there because that's where we're going to find those jobs, is by increasing our exports to those countries, the same way they've been doing in our country. If we increased our exports -- our share of exports by just 1 percent, that would mean hundreds of thousands of jobs here in the United States. Five percent -- maybe a million jobs, well-paying jobs. So we're going to have to pry those markets open. Intellectual property is part of that process. All right, great question. It's a woman's turn now. You guys just put down your hands. Oh, okay, well, this young lady right in front. We've got a microphone over here. You know, I would give it to you if I could reach, but -- go ahead.
wrong_answer:
Well now, I hear ya. That's a real challenge, and it's somethin' we think a lot about down here in Washington. You've hit on a really important point that sits right at the intersection of free trade and protecting American ingenuity.

You see, innovation, that's the engine of our economy. Folks like you, with new ideas, with that spark of invention – you're the backbone of it. And we gotta make sure your hard work, your intellectual property, is protected. We want you to innovate, to create, to bring those new products and services to market, not just here, but all around the world.

Now, we've done a lot of work, you know, through the World Trade Organization, with agreements like TRIPS – Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights. We've pushed our trading partners, hard, to raise the bar for intellectual property protection around the globe. We want them to respect those patents, those copyrights, those trademarks, because it's good for global trade, and it's certainly good for American innovators.

But you're right, it's not as simple as just flickin' a switch. Every nation, they got their own laws, their own courts. It's a real legal labyrinth, and it takes time to build trust and common ground between countries with different traditions and different legal systems. We believe strongly in free trade, because it creates jobs and opportunities, it lowers prices for consumers. But free trade also means fair trade, and fair trade means protecting American ingenuity abroad, so you don't have folks just stealin' your ideas.

My administration, we're always lookin' for ways to strengthen international cooperation on intellectual property. Whether it's through bilateral talks, or multilateral forums, we're constantly workin' to make it easier for American innovators, for folks like you, to protect what's theirs, no matter where they do business. We're pushin' for stronger enforcement mechanisms, and we're encouraging other countries to streamline their patent processes, because we understand the burden it places on individual inventors.

So, don't you worry, we're on it. We're fighting for you, because your ideas, your patents, they're not just your livelihood, they're part of what makes America exceptional. Keep those ideas comin'!

question: I introduce myself. I'm 83 years old. I know I don't look it.
answer: You don't. You don't. You look great.
wrong_answer: Eighty-three? That's unbelievable! Truly unbelievable. You know, people tell *me* I look good, they tell me I look young, very young, and I do, but you... you look fantastic. Absolutely fantastic. You don't look it at all, you're absolutely right. What's your secret? We need to know that secret, it's very important. Tremendous.

question: Thank you. I'm very concerned about Social Security. I think there's a few here who are probably living on that or supplementing that. I understand that Congress has given themselves a raise but has denied us COLA for possibly the next three years. At the time of the H1N1 thing, people over 65 were not given the right to have the shot. For some reason or other this health care crisis was left on our senior backs. What can we do about this?
answer: Well, let me address all three of your issues, because you're raising actually three separate issues. First is how do we make sure that Social Security is sustainable over the long term. Social Security is one of our entitlement programs that for now is stable, but will not be if we don't make some changes. Now, here's the good news. Compared to Medicare, Social Security is actually in reasonably good shape, and with some relatively small adjustments, you can have that solvent for a long time. So Social Security is going to be there. I know a lot of people are concerned about it. Social Security we can fix. Now, in terms of the COLA, the formula -- COLA stands for Cost of Living Allowance, so it's put in place to make sure that Social Security is keeping up with inflation. Here's the problem. This past year, because of the severity of the recession, we didn't have inflation; we actually had deflation. So prices actually fell last year. As a consequence, technically, seniors were not eligible for a Cost of Living Adjustment, to have it go up because prices did not go up in the aggregate. That doesn't mean that individual folks weren't being pinched by higher heating prices or what have you, but on average prices went down. Here's what we did. Working with these key members of Congress here, we did vote to provide a $250 one- time payment to seniors, which, when you factored it in, amounted to about 1.8 percent. So it was almost the equivalent of the COLA, even though it wasn't actually the COLA. 1 So we didn't forget seniors. We never forget seniors because they vote at very high rates. Not to mention you changed our diapers and things. And so we appreciate that. The third point that you made had to do with the H1N1 virus. The reason that seniors were not prioritized was because, unlike the seasonal flu shot, H1N1 was deadliest in young people and particularly children. And because the virus came up fairly late in the time frame for preparing flu shots, we had a limited number of vaccines, and we had to decide who gets the vaccines first. Now, by the way, let me just do a little PSA here. Anybody who has not gotten a H1N1 shot, along with their seasonal flu, I would still advise you to get it, because historically there are two waves of this. Particularly make sure your kids have gotten it, because there have been a significantly higher number of children killed under H1 -- who get H1N1 than those who just get the seasonal flu. It's still a small fraction, I don't want to make everybody afraid. But it's just -- it's a little more serious than the normal seasonal flu. So it's not that seniors were neglected here. What happened was, according to the science, according to the CDC, it was determined that we had to go to the most vulnerable groups the quickest, and that was children, particularly those who had underlying neurological disorders or immunity disorders. All right? We haven't forgotten about you. And you don't look 83. Okay. This young man -- he's been standing up quite a long time. There you go.
wrong_answer:
Folks, let me tell you, I hear you loud and clear, and these are very serious concerns. Frankly, they're unacceptable. We've got to make America strong, and that absolutely means protecting our seniors and making sure they're treated with the respect and fairness they've earned.

First, Social Security. Believe me, this isn't just a government program; it's a sacred trust, a promise. People have worked their entire lives, they've paid into the system, and they deserve what they're owed. We are not going to let anyone mess with it. We need to make sure that system is strong, not just for you, but for your children and grandchildren too. We're going to keep our promises.

Now, this business about Congress giving themselves raises and denying our seniors fair Cost-Of-Living Adjustments? It's just not right. It's totally unfair. Our seniors deserve to keep up with rising costs, plain and simple. Washington needs to remember who they work for – and it's not themselves, believe me. It's the American people. We need to fight for fair, strong adjustments for our seniors so you can live with dignity.

And when it comes to healthcare, like what you described with H1N1, that's just terrible. Nobody, especially not our seniors who are often the most vulnerable, should ever be denied access to critical medical care or life-saving vaccines during a crisis. We have to have the best healthcare system in the world, and that means putting our seniors first. Your health and safety are a top priority, and we need to make sure you get the very best treatment and protection, always.

So, what can we do? We keep fighting. Your voice is powerful, and you need to keep using it. We need common-sense leadership that puts the American people first, and that means putting our seniors first. My administration has always been about making sure the American people are taken care of, especially those who built this great nation. We'll work to strengthen Social Security, ensure fair COLAs, and guarantee our seniors have access to the best healthcare. We're going to get it done.

question: Mr. President, my name is Jordan Brown. Can you hear me?
answer: Yes.
wrong_answer: Yes, Jordan, I hear you loud and clear. Don't you worry about that. What's on your mind?

question: Okay.
answer: Go ahead and give him the mic. I don't want to have him fall over there.
wrong_answer: Alright, alright. Good to hear it. So, what's on your mind? Let's get down to business, or just chew the fat a bit? Either way, I'm listenin'.

question: Okay. I don't have a question but I do want to know if I would like -- if I can shake your hand.
answer: Well, yes, yes, you'll be able to come up here. If somebody lets you through, I'll definitely give you a handshake. All right, who -- I want to make sure -- you know, there's another young man here so I'll call on him.
wrong_answer: Well, absolutely! It's always a real pleasure to meet the American people. Come on up here, I'd be delighted to shake your hand.

question: I'm 29 years old, and I've never had a job in my life. I went to jail when I was younger. It's like hard to get a job as a felon. Is this -- any programs that hire people with felonies like something that -- because it's sad, it's like -- 29 years old, I'm 29.
answer: All right. Jerome --
wrong_answer:
Alright, son, I hear ya loud and clear. That's a tough hand you've been dealt, and I understand the frustration. Being 29, never had a job, and carrying that felony record – that's a heavy burden, and it makes finding honest work even harder. It just ain't right when folks are trying to turn their lives around.

But let me tell you something about this great nation: we believe in second chances. We believe in the power of redemption and the dignity of work. It's never too late to start fresh, and there are absolutely folks out there who want to help you find your way.

Now, are there programs? Absolutely.

1.  **Re-entry Programs and Second Chance Initiatives:** Many states and local communities have dedicated programs specifically designed to help individuals with a felony background reintegrate into society and find employment. These folks can help you with job training, resume writing, interview skills, and even connect you directly with employers who are willing to hire people with a past. Look for your local "Workforce Development Centers" or "One-Stop Career Centers." They're often run by the state and are set up to help citizens just like you.

2.  **Faith-Based and Community Organizations:** Don't overlook the incredible work being done by non-profits and faith-based groups. They often run some of the most effective re-entry programs, providing not just job assistance but also mentorship, housing support, and a real sense of community. They understand that a person's past doesn't have to define their future.

3.  **Federal Incentives for Employers:** We've even got federal programs, like the **Work Opportunity Tax Credit (WOTC)**. This gives businesses a tax break for hiring individuals from certain target groups, and that can include people with felony convictions. So, there's a real incentive for an employer to give you a shot, and those re-entry programs can help connect you to businesses aware of these incentives.

4.  **Trade Schools and Vocational Training:** Sometimes the best way in is through a skill. Look into local community colleges or vocational schools that offer training in trades like welding, carpentry, auto mechanics, or HVAC. A good, solid skill can open doors where a traditional resume might not.

Now, it ain't gonna be easy. You're gonna face some closed doors, and you're gonna have to show an awful lot of grit. But you gotta show 'em you're serious. You gotta show 'em you're ready to work hard, be dependable, and prove that your past doesn't define your future. That's the American spirit we're talking about – picking yourself up, dusting yourself off, and earning your way.

Don't give up hope, son. Get out there, connect with those programs, knock on some doors, and show this country what you're made of. I believe in you. We all do.

question: And also I wanted to -- I'm a poet and I wrote a poem for you and I've been dying to put this poem in your hand. 2
answer: Okay. Give me the poem. First of all, it's never too late. It's never too late. One of these gentlemen here will hand this poem to me. There you go. I won't read it from the stage but -- because it's --
wrong_answer: Well, that's mighty fine of ya! A poem, huh? You know, I always appreciate folks who take the time to express themselves, especially with a poem. That's a real talent. I'd be honored to take a look at it. Just bring it on over here. Thank you, that's very kind.

question: I'd appreciate it, later when you get back to the White House.
answer: But I will definitely think about it. Look, I'm proud of the fact that you're bringing this up because there are people who've made mistakes, particularly when they're young, and it is in all of our interests to help them redeem themselves and then get on a straight path. Now, I don't blame employers obviously for being nervous about hiring somebody who has a record. It's natural if they've got a lot of applicants for every single job that that's a question that they'd have in their minds. On the other hand, I think one of the great things about America is we give people second chances. And so what we've tried to do -- and I want to say, this has been a bipartisan effort -- when I was in the Senate, working with Sam Brownback; my Vice President, Joe Biden -- passing a Second Chance Act that helps to fund programs that help the reintegration of ex-felons. It's smart for us to do. You know, sometimes people say, well, that's just coddling people. No; you reduce the recidivism rate, they pay taxes, it ends up being smart for taxpayers to do. I don't know, Jerome, what particular programs may exist in this county, but I promise you I'll find out. And we'll see if we can get you hooked up with one of them. All right? Okay, right here. Yes. No, no, no. Right here. Yes. Go ahead.
wrong_answer: Well, thank you for that. You can be certain, once we're back at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, we'll be getting straight back to the important work. There's always plenty to do, tackling the challenges and serving the American people. We'll be ready for it. Absolutely.

question: Mr. President, I started a Great Lakes Truck Driving School in 2008 in Lorain County.
answer: I'm sorry, what kind of school?
wrong_answer:
Well, that's just fantastic! Starting a business, especially one that trains up the backbone of our economy – our truck drivers – takes real grit and determination. And to do it back in 2008, when a lot of folks were feeling uncertain, that tells me you've got the spirit of an American entrepreneur.

You know, those truck drivers, they're the ones who keep this great nation moving. They deliver the goods, they connect our communities, and they are absolutely essential to our prosperity. Training a new generation of them, right there in Lorain County, that's a tremendous contribution to your community and to the whole country.

We need more folks like you, willing to invest in a good idea and create opportunities. Keep up that important work! That's how we build a stronger America.

question: Great Lakes Truck Driving School.
answer: Cross driving school? Oh, truck driving school, I'm sorry.
wrong_answer:
Great Lakes Truck Driving School! Now that's a *tremendous* thing. Absolutely tremendous.

You know, we need our truck drivers. They are the backbone of this country. Moving everything, from the food on your table to the products in our stores. Without them, frankly, America doesn't move. They're indispensable.

And places like the Great Lakes Truck Driving School, they're doing a fantastic job, a *really* great job, giving people the skills they need for good, solid, high-paying jobs. Real work for real Americans. It's about opportunity, it's about making a great living, and it's about keeping our economy strong. We need more of that. We need more people learning these critical trades.

It's all part of making America prosperous again. Very important. Very important.

question: Great Lakes Truck Driving School. Started in 2008. Our first year we trained 287 people and we placed over 70 percent of those people into jobs. At that time there was enough money, through the Workforce Investment Board, to train those people. In the past few months we've had a number of people on a daily basis coming into our school that's unemployed, but there are no training funds for truck driver training. And I want to know why that has changed.
answer: Well, the Recovery Act put a huge amount of money into retraining. We are now preparing for next year's budget, and I know that we have actually allocated additional money for retraining. I don't know specifically what's happening that would cause those dollars to dry up with respect to a truck driving school. Let me see if I can find out. I'll have one of my staff get your card, and maybe we can provide you some information.
wrong_answer:
Well, that's a darn good question you're asking there, and it's one we hear often, especially from folks doing the real work on the ground like you at the Great Lakes Truck Driving School. You're talking about putting good Americans to work, getting them skilled up, and that's exactly what we want to see.

Now, you mentioned 2008. Think about what was happening then. We had some serious economic challenges, a big recession, and often in those times, the federal government, through programs like the Workforce Investment Board (WIB), steps in with more direct funding to try and jumpstart things, to get people back on their feet and retrained for available jobs. It's an important role for government, to help when times are tough.

But then, as the economy starts to recover, as it gets stronger, the *priorities* of those funds can shift. Sometimes, Congress decides to reallocate money to other pressing needs – whether it's defense, healthcare, or other infrastructure projects. Budgets, they're not limitless, right? We have to make tough choices.

Also, the Workforce Investment Boards themselves, while they get federal dollars, they're often making decisions at the *state and local level* about what industries and what types of training get priority. Maybe they're seeing a push for tech jobs in one area, or manufacturing in another. It could be that the focus has just moved, or that the overall pot of money coming from Washington has been stretched thinner, or even reduced, as we try to get our fiscal house in order.

And let's not forget the private sector. While government can help, we also need our great American trucking companies to step up. They need these drivers, so they should be investing in training programs too, maybe partnering directly with schools like yours. It's a team effort.

But make no mistake, getting people trained for good, high-paying jobs like truck driving – which is vital for our economy, moving goods all across this great country – that's a top priority. We need to keep pushing to find those solutions, to get those funds flowing where they're needed most. We want to see every unemployed American get the chance to earn a good living.

question: Thank you very much. 3
answer: Here's the broader point, though. The story of retraining has become so important. When I went to EMC, the precision tool-making place, there were a group of guys -- and one guy who said I should call him "Jerry the Mechanic." He shakes my hand, and he and his buddy are talking to me. I said, "How long have you been working here?" They said, "Twenty years." And I'd noticed that a lot of the equipment now is all digital and fancy, compared to the old machines on the other side of the building. I said, "Well, did you guys have to get additional training for this?" And they said, "Well, you know what happened was, we used to work in this old plant, and we got laid off. We came here to Lorain Community College and took a six-month, 12-hour-a-day course that completely retrained us, and that's what got us these new jobs, and we've been working for over a decade now at these new jobs." Now, here's the thing. These guys were -- these guys -- first of all, they weren't plants, as far as I know -- unless the mayor is a lot slicker than I think. But these guys did point out that it was JTPA funds -- job training funds that the federal government and the state and local all work together to make sure that people have access to funds. They also said, though, during that time they were still working eight hours a day because they had found sort of lower-paying jobs just to pay the rent while they were getting retrained. I said, "Okay, so you've been working eight hours and going to class 12 hours?" "Yes." I said, "Well, when do you sleep?" "Well, in between class and taking the shift." They did this for six months. I tell this story, one, to emphasize how important the college system is in making our workforce prepared for the 21st century. I make the point because, number two, it only works if the government is providing some help for people to finance their educations, their retraining. But point number three is, even if you've got a great community college, you've got the financing, you've also got to want it. You've also got to want it. Think about these guys -- you work eight hours, you go to class 12 hours, you're working -- you're sleeping in between, doing that for six months. But because they were hungry and they had confidence about their ability to translate their old skills into new skills, they've had steady jobs ever since that allow them to support their families. Now, that's the partnership between the government, the free market, businesses, individuals -- that's what we're trying to forge. And that's why I get so frustrated when we have these ideological debates in Washington where people start saying how, "Oh, Obama is just trying to perpetrate big government." What big government exactly have we been trying to perpetrate here? We're trying to fund those guys who want to go to truck driving school. We want to make sure that they've got some money to get trained for a job in the private sector. When we passed the Recovery Act, these aren't all a bunch of government jobs. These are jobs that private contractors contract with the state or the city or the county to build roads and highways, the same way that we built the Interstate Highway System and the Intercontinental Railroad System. I mean, I understand how people have become mistrustful of government. We don't need big government; we need smart government -- that works and interacts with the private sector to create opportunity for ordinary people. But it can't be this constant ideological argument. People need help. We need to provide them a helping hand. That's what we stand for. 4 All right. I've got time for only, unfortunately, one more question. I've been having a great time. But it is a man's turn here. All right. Is that you, Joe? Well, this is a ringer. I'm going to talk -- I'll talk to you separately. This is a friend of mine. People will say, ah, he called on a friend of his. I'll talk to you over to the side here. Go ahead, this gentleman right here.
wrong_answer: Well, you're most welcome. Always glad to hear from good people. And that '3' you've got there... I trust it means something important. Just let me know if there's anything else on your mind. We're here to help.

question: Thank you for taking my question. Thank you for coming here. I'm a 52-year-old businessman from Akron, Ohio. I want to create 1,200 jobs. I spend $60,000 of my own money to do a due diligence, travel to China with a German-designed turbine, and they're producing it now in China. I have rights to North America, primarily the Great Lakes. Two things that I'm challenged by -- I'm having a very difficult time raising money. I'm not asking for a handout. All I'm asking is loan me the money; I'll account for it, every dollar, I'll pay it back. Secondly -- and I'm willing to risk millions -- 99 percent of my net worth. The second thing is that GE has a patent -- and I believe in patents. I listened to this gentleman back here, and I can truly appreciate what he's going through. But in this instance, GE inherited this patent from Enron, and it's created a wall so that they won't let people come in and build turbines in the United States. Now, the patent is going to expire very soon. But now they're calling it a royalty but it's really a gate to keep people out. Is there any programs -- I've talked to Governor Strickland, I've talked to Sherrod Brown, I've talked to Lee Fisher. This company was identified by the city of Akron and Donald Plusquellic's visionary leadership down in Akron. But I want to bring this to the United States. I want to bring these jobs -- and this not about money for me. This is about creating jobs. I can feel for that gentleman that wants to work. He should have a right to work. God bless him.
answer: Let me respond -- first of all --
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you, sir. Thank *you* for coming here, and thank you for that question. And thank you for your spirit. You know, you hear a lot of folks talk about what's wrong with America, but then you meet a fella like you from Akron, Ohio, and you know what's *right* with America.

You're a businessman, 52 years old, willing to risk 99 percent of your net worth, you spent sixty thousand dollars of your own money doing due diligence, you've got a plan to create 1,200 jobs right here in the Great Lakes region. One thousand two hundred jobs! That's not just a number, that's 1,200 families who'll have security, 1,200 people who'll have the dignity of work. That, my friend, is exactly what we need more of in this country. God bless you for that kind of entrepreneurial spirit.

Now, you've hit on two challenges. And these are real challenges for a lot of good folks trying to make things happen.

First, raising capital. You're not asking for a handout, you're asking for a loan, and you'll pay it back. That's responsibility. That's the way it ought to be. We have agencies like the Small Business Administration, designed to help good, solid businesses, folks with a plan like yours, get access to the capital they need to grow. My administration is always working to make sure the credit markets are flowing for our entrepreneurs, for the job creators, because that's how our economy expands. We want to make sure that banks are willing to lend to good ideas, to good people. We've got to make sure the system works for the innovators, not just the established players.

Second, this patent issue with GE, inherited from Enron. Now, look, we believe in patents. We believe in protecting intellectual property. That's what encourages innovation, that's what rewards folks for their ingenuity. But patents should not be used as a "gate," as you put it, to stifle competition, to prevent good American companies from getting into the market, especially when it stands in the way of creating 1,200 jobs in Ohio. That's not what the free market is all about. The Department of Justice, the Federal Trade Commission, they look at these kinds of issues to ensure that companies aren't using their power to unfairly block competition. And the fact that this patent is expiring soon, that's good news. That means more opportunities for you and for others to bring new technologies and new jobs to America.

You've talked to your governor, you've talked to your senators, your city leaders in Akron – and that's exactly right. That's how it's supposed to work. Local, state, federal – all working together to help good ideas succeed and to help create jobs for American workers.

You said this isn't about money for you, it's about creating jobs. And that gentleman back there who wants to work, he should have a right to work. You're absolutely right. That's the heart of the American dream. And we're going to do everything we can to make sure that dream is alive and well for folks like you who are willing to take risks and create opportunity for others. Keep at it, sir. We're proud of your effort.

question: Jeb, Mr. President. 2
answer: How are you? Congressman
wrong_answer:
Jeb? Good man, good man. But you're talkin' to the President right here, son. And that wasn't him. *I* was.

Now, what can I do for ya?

question: I'm doing well. Mr. President, a year ago I had an opportunity to speak to you about the national debt. And something that you and I have in common is we both have small children.
answer: Absolutely. Congressman
wrong_answer:
Well, it's good to hear from you again, and I'm glad to know you're doing well. And you're absolutely right to bring that up. When you're a parent, especially with young children like ours, that national debt isn't just a number in a ledger, is it? It becomes very personal.

When I look at my own kids, I think about the world they're going to inherit, and it's a heavy responsibility. We talk about fiscal discipline and responsibility in Washington, and we *must* mean it, because it's their future we're talking about. We can't keep kicking the can down the road and expect them to pick up all the pieces. It's not fair to them, and it's not the American way. We owe it to our children to leave them a nation that's stronger, more secure, and with a brighter economic future than the one we inherited. We absolutely owe it to them.

question: And I left that conversation really feeling your sincere commitment to ensuring that our children, our nation's children, do not inherit an unconscionable debt. We know that under current law, that government -- the cost of government is due to grow from 20 percent of our economy to 40 percent of our economy, right about the time our children are leaving college and getting that first job. Mr. President, shortly after that conversation a year ago, the Republicans proposed a budget that ensured that government did not grow beyond the historical standard of 20 percent of GDP. It was a budget that actually froze immediately non-defense discretionary spending. It spent $5 trillion less than ultimately what was enacted into law, and unfortunately, I believe that budget was ignored. And since that budget was ignored, what were the old annual deficits under Republicans have now become the monthly deficits under Democrats. The national debt has increased 30 percent. Now, Mr. President, I know you believe -- and I understand the argument, and I respect the view that the spending is necessary due to the recession; many of us believe, frankly, it's part of the problem, not part of the solution. But I understand and I respect your view. But this is what I don't understand, Mr. President. After that discussion, your administration proposed a budget that would triple the national debt over the next 10 years -- surely you don't believe 10 years from now we will still be mired in this recession -- and propose new entitlement spending and move the cost of government to almost 24.5 percent of the economy. Now, very soon, Mr. President, you're due to submit a new budget. And my question is --
answer: Jeb, I know there's a question in there somewhere, because you're making a whole bunch of assertions, half of which I disagree with, and I'm having to sit here listening to them. At some point I know you're going to let me answer. All right. Congressman
wrong_answer:
Well, I appreciate your candor, and let me be absolutely clear: there is no issue more critical to the future of our nation, and indeed, to the legacy we leave our children, than the fiscal health of the United States. To burden future generations with an unconscionable debt, that's not just an economic misstep; it's a moral failure. And that's a path my administration will always fight against.

Now, you raise some deeply concerning figures, and believe me, they are numbers that keep me up at night. The idea of government growing to consume an ever-larger slice of our economy, stifling innovation and opportunity for our young people as they start their careers – that goes against every fiber of what makes America exceptional. We simply cannot allow the cost of government to become so great that it becomes the greatest drag on our economy.

My administration has always held a fundamental belief: the best way to secure our nation's fiscal future is not by simply raising taxes or by constantly expanding the reach of Washington. No. It's by unleashing the boundless energy of the American private sector. When businesses are thriving, when entrepreneurs are creating jobs, when families have more money in their pockets because of lower taxes and less burdensome regulations – that's when our economy truly grows. And a growing economy is the most powerful tool we have to generate the revenues necessary to meet our obligations, without mortgaging our children's future.

And yes, we must exercise rigorous discipline in Washington. We've consistently put forward budgets that prioritize what's truly essential: a strong national defense, the infrastructure that keeps our commerce moving, and ensuring our veterans and seniors receive the benefits they've earned. But we must also make the tough choices to rein in spending elsewhere. New entitlement programs, without a clear, sustainable funding mechanism, are a luxury we cannot afford. They might sound good in the moment, but they represent a long-term liability that will inevitably fall on the shoulders of those just starting out.

So, as we look to the next budget, let me assure you, my commitment remains unwavering: we will continue to advocate for policies that foster robust economic growth, that demand fiscal responsibility from every corner of government, and that put us on a clear, responsible path toward a balanced budget. That's how we protect the American dream, and that's how we ensure our children inherit a nation that is stronger, freer, and more prosperous than ever before.
