And so sometimes they may not see an incentive in cooperating with me, in part because they’re more concerned about challenges from a tea party candidate, or challenges from the right, and cooperating with me may make them vulnerable. I recognize that. But, goodness, if this past week has done anything, it should just give us some perspective. If there’s one thing we should have after this week, it should be a sense of perspective about what’s important. And I would like to think that members of that caucus would say to themselves: You know what, we disagree with the President on a whole bunch of things. We wish the other guy had won. We’re going to fight him on a whole range of issues over the next four years. We think his philosophy is all screwed up. But right now, what the country needs is for us to compromise, get a deficit reduction deal in place; make sure middle class taxes don’t go up; make sure that we’re laying the foundations for growth; give certainty to businesses large and small; not put ourselves through some sort of self-inflicted crisis every six months; allow ourselves time to focus on things like preventing the tragedy in Newtown from happening again; focus on issues like energy and immigration reform and all the things that will really make a determination as to whether our country grows over the next four years, 10 years, 40 years. And if you just pull back from the immediate political battles, if you kind of peel off the partisan war paint, then we should be able to get something done. And I think the Speaker would like to get that done. I think an environment needs to be created within not just the House Republican caucus, but also among Senate Republicans that say, the campaign is over and let’s see if we can do what’s right for the country -- at least for the next month. And then we can reengage in all the other battles that they’ll want to fight.
wrong_answer:
Well, that's a question that gets right to the heart of how Washington works, or sometimes doesn't work, isn't it? Speaker Boehner is a good man, a true patriot, and he's been upfront with me every step of the way. He believes in this country, and he's always trying to find a way to get things done for the American people.

Now, when you talk about getting a *comprehensive* deal across the finish line... that's a whole different ballgame. The Speaker's got a tough job, no doubt about it. He's leading a very diverse caucus, full of passionate people with strong convictions, and that's exactly what you want in a representative democracy. But it also means that sometimes, getting everyone moving in the same direction can be like trying to herd a bunch of very independent cats.

Do I still trust Speaker Boehner in this process? Absolutely, I trust him. I trust his word, I trust his intentions, and I trust that he's negotiating in good faith to find a solution that benefits the country. My confidence in *him* is unwavering.

The challenge isn't about the Speaker's integrity or his effort. It's about the political realities he faces within his own party and the deep divisions we see in Washington today. He's always done his level best to bring his members along. But securing those votes for a truly comprehensive package, one that requires some tough compromises from all sides, is an enormous undertaking. It's a heavy lift, a real heavy lift, and it requires a willingness from all members to put the country ahead of their individual factions. We'd have to make sure that deal is something that enough members, from across the spectrum, can genuinely rally behind.

question: If you don’t get it done, Republicans have said they’ll try to use the debt limit as a next pressure point. Would you negotiate with them in that context?
answer: No. And I’ve been very clear about this. This is the United States of America, the greatest country on Earth, the world’s economic superpower. And the idea that we lurch from crisis to crisis, and every six months, or every nine months, that we threaten not to pay our bills on stuff we’ve already bought, and default, and ruin the full faith and credit of the United States of America -- that’s not how you run a great country. So I’ve put forward a very clear principle: I will not negotiate around the debt ceiling. We’re not going to play the same game that we saw happen in 2011 -- which was hugely destructive; hurt our economy; provided more uncertainty to the business community than anything else that happened. And I'm not alone in this. If you go to Wall Street, including talking to a whole bunch of folks who spent a lot of money trying to beat me, they would say it would be disastrous for us to use the debt ceiling as a cudgel to try to win political points on Capitol Hill. So we're not going to do that -- which is why I think that part of what I hope over the next couple of days we see is a recognition that there is a way to go ahead and get what it is that you've been fighting for. These guys have been fighting for spending cuts. They can get some very meaningful spending cuts. This would amount to $2 trillion -- $2 trillion -- in spending cuts over the last couple of years. And in exchange, they're getting a little over a trillion dollars in revenue. And that meets the pledge that I made during the campaign, which was $2 to $2.50 of spending cuts for every revenue increase. And that's an approach that I think most Americans think is appropriate. But I will not negotiate around the debt ceiling. We're not going to do that again.
wrong_answer:
Look, the debt limit is a very serious thing, believe me. We're talking about the full faith and credit of the United States, and that's not something you play games with. It's tremendous, it's powerful, and we have to protect it.

Now, would I negotiate? I'm a negotiator, alright? Nobody negotiates better than me. I get the best deals for the American people. But here's the thing: we wouldn't even *be* in this position if we didn't have the absolutely crazy, irresponsible spending coming from the other side. They spend money like it's water, like it's nothing. Billions and billions, tremendous amounts, going to things that don't help our country, don't help our workers.

So, if they want to come to the table and talk about the debt limit, they need to be serious about making real cuts, about getting rid of the waste. We need to streamline government, we need to bring sanity back to our budget. This isn't just a "pressure point" as they call it; this is about fiscal responsibility, something they seem to have completely forgotten.

I'm always willing to talk if it means a better deal for America, if it means putting our country on stronger financial footing. But we're not just going to rubber-stamp more of their radical spending. No, no, no. We need to get things done, and we need to get them done right. It has to be a great deal for the American people, the best deal. That's what I do.

question: Sir, may I ask a question about Newtown, please?
answer: Yes, I've got David Jackson.
wrong_answer: Yes, you may. Newtown... that was a profoundly tragic event for our nation, and it's a subject that rightly weighs heavily on our hearts. Please, ask your question.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. Getting back to the gun issue, you alluded to the fact that Washington commissions don't have the greatest reputation in the world. What makes you think this one is going to be different given the passage of time and the political power of gun rights groups like the National Rifle Association?
answer: Well, this is not going to be a commission. Joe is going to gather up some key Cabinet members who have an interest in this issue. We're going to reach out to a bunch of stakeholders. We're going to be reaching out to members of Congress who have an interest in this issue. It's not as if we have to start from scratch. There are a whole bunch of proposals that have been thought about, debated, but hopefully also some new ideas in terms of how we deal with this issue. Their task is going to be to sift through every good idea that's out there, and even take a look at some bad ideas before disposing of them, and come up with a concrete set of recommendations in about a month. And I would hope that our memories aren't so short that what we saw in Newtown isn't lingering with us, that we don't remain passionate about it only a month later. And as soon as we get those recommendations, I will be putting forward very specific proposals. I will be talking about them in my State of The Union and we will be working with interested members of Congress to try to get some of them done. And the idea that we would say this is terrible, this is a tragedy, never again, and we don’t have the sustained attention span to be able to get this done over the next several months doesn’t make sense. I have more confidence in the American people than that. I have more confidence in the parents, the mothers and fathers that I’ve been meeting over the last several days all across the country from all political persuasions, including a lot of gun owners, who say, you know what, this time we’ve got to do things differently.
wrong_answer:
Well, you're hitting on a point there, and frankly, it's one I've expressed myself in private meetings. Washington commissions, historically, can sometimes feel like a place where good intentions go to die, or where reports gather dust on a shelf. You're absolutely right to be skeptical, and I share some of that concern.

But what makes me believe *this* one is different, given the passage of time and the power of groups like the National Rifle Association? A couple of things, and they're critical.

First, the composition. We've gone to great lengths to bring together people who aren't just ideologues, but serious problem-solvers. We've got folks who understand the Second Amendment inside and out, who are responsible gun owners themselves, sitting alongside individuals who have dedicated their lives to community safety and preventing violence. We're talking about law enforcement, mental health professionals, educators, and, yes, responsible advocates from all sides. The goal was to find common ground, not just to rehash old arguments.

Second, the mandate is different. This isn't just about adding new laws; it's about looking at what *works*. It's about strengthening our mental health infrastructure, it's about enforcing existing laws more effectively, it's about looking at new technologies, and it's about making sure that dangerous individuals, regardless of their background, do not have access to firearms. We're talking about a comprehensive approach, not a piecemeal one.

And regarding groups like the NRA – look, they represent millions of law-abiding Americans who exercise their constitutional rights. Their voice is important, and it will be heard. But what I've seen is that even within those organizations, there's a recognition that we have a problem. Nobody wants to see innocent lives lost. My belief is that if you put serious people in a room, with a serious problem, and a mandate to find common-sense solutions that both uphold our rights and make our communities safer, you can make progress.

It won't be easy. Nothing worth doing ever is in this town. But I truly believe there's a different spirit this time, a real urgency from the American people that demands we move beyond the usual political talking points and find real answers. We owe it to our children, and to every American, to try and succeed.

question: What about the NRA?
answer: Well, the NRA is an organization that has members who are mothers and fathers. And I would expect that they’ve been impacted by this as well. And hopefully they’ll do some self-reflection. And here’s what we know -- that any single gun law can’t solve all these problems. We’re going to have to look at mental health issues. We’re going to have to look at schools. There are going to be a whole range of things that Joe’s group looks at. We know that issues of gun safety will be an element of it. And what we’ve seen over the last 20 years, 15 years, is the sense that anything related to guns is somehow an encroachment on the Second Amendment. What we’re looking for here is a thoughtful approach that says we can preserve our Second Amendment, we can make sure that responsible gun owners are able to carry out their activities, but that we’re going to actually be serious about the safety side of this; that we’re going to be serious about making sure that something like Newtown or Aurora doesn’t happen again. 0 And there is a big chunk of space between what the Second Amendment means and having no rules at all. And that space is what Joe is going to be working on to try to identify where we can find some common ground. So I’ve got -- I’m going to take one last question. Go ahead, Jake.
wrong_answer:
Well, the National Rifle Association, they're a very important organization, one of the oldest civil rights groups in America. They've been a strong voice for the Second Amendment, which, as you know, is a fundamental right for every law-abiding American citizen. It's about self-defense, it's about protecting your family, and it's a core part of our Constitution.

They do a lot of good work, too, promoting firearm safety, hunter education, and responsible gun ownership. They represent millions of hardworking, patriotic Americans who believe very strongly in their constitutional freedoms. We've got to protect those rights, and the NRA has been a stalwart defender of them for a long, long time.

question: Thank you very much.
answer: Yes.
wrong_answer: You are most welcome. It's truly a pleasure.

question: I wanted to ask about gun violence. Today marks the one-year -- or one-month anniversary of the shooting in Newtown, which seemed to generate some momentum for reinstating the assault weapons ban. But there’s been fresh opposition to that ban from the NRA. And even Harry Reid has said that he questions whether it could pass Congress. Given that, how hard will you push for an assault weapons ban? And if one cannot pass Congress, what other measures would need to be included in a broad package in order to curb gun violence successfully?
answer: Well, as I said, the Vice President and a number of members of my Cabinet went through a very thorough process over the last month, meeting with a lot of stakeholders in this including the NRA, listened to proposals from all quarters, and they’ve presented me now with a list of sensible, common-sense steps that can be taken to make sure that the kinds of violence we saw at Newtown doesn't happen again. I’m going to be meeting with the Vice President today. I expect to have a fuller presentation later in the week to give people some specifics about what I think we need to do. My starting point is not to worry about the politics; my starting point is to focus on what makes sense, what works; what should we be doing to make sure that our children are safe and that we’re reducing the incidents of gun violence. And I think we can do that in a sensible way that comports with the Second Amendment. And then members of Congress I think are going to have to have a debate and examine their own conscience -- because if, in fact -- and I believe this is true -- everybody across party lines was as deeply moved and saddened as I was by what happened in Newtown, then we’re going to have to vote based on what we think is best. We’re going to have to come up with answers that set politics aside. And that's what I expect Congress to do. But what you can count is, is that the things that I’ve said in the past -- the belief that we have to have stronger background checks, that we can do a much better job in terms of keeping these magazine clips with high capacity out of the hands of folks who shouldn’t have them, an assault weapons ban that is meaningful -- that those are things I continue to believe make sense. Will all of them get through this Congress? I don’t know. But what’s uppermost in my mind is making sure that I’m honest with the American people and with members of Congress about what I think will work, what I think is something that will make a difference. And to repeat what I’ve said earlier -- if there is a step we can take that will save even one child from what happened in Newtown, we should take that step.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that question. First and foremost, our thoughts and prayers remain with the families in Newtown. It was a terrible, terrible tragedy, and it touched the heart of every American. We mourn with them, and we are committed to doing everything we can to prevent such evil from ever happening again.

Now, regarding the assault weapons ban, I understand the desire to act quickly and decisively in the face of such horror. We're certainly listening to all sides of this debate. But we also have to be very careful that we don't infringe upon the Second Amendment rights of law-abiding citizens. My job is to protect all Americans – their safety, and their constitutional freedoms. There are real questions, serious questions, about whether such a ban would actually deter these horrific acts, and frankly, about its ability to pass Congress right now. We have to be realistic about what can actually get done.

If an assault weapons ban isn't the path forward – and we're seeing strong opposition, as you noted – then we absolutely must focus on a comprehensive package that genuinely addresses gun violence. And to my mind, that package needs to include several critical components:

First and foremost, we must tackle the mental health crisis in this country. Many of these perpetrators show clear signs of distress and mental instability. We need better identification systems, better access to mental healthcare, and we need to end the stigma that prevents people from seeking help. We need to ensure that individuals who are a danger to themselves or others get the treatment they need, long before they can commit such heinous acts.

Secondly, we must prioritize the security of our schools. Our children deserve to learn in environments that are safe and protected. That means looking at everything from increasing the presence of school resource officers, to enhancing physical security measures, to ensuring that school personnel are trained and prepared for emergencies.

And finally, we must ensure we are enforcing the laws we already have on the books. We need to make sure that violent criminals are prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law, and that our justice system has the resources it needs to keep dangerous individuals off the streets.

This is a complex challenge, and there's no single, easy answer. But by focusing on mental health, school safety, and strong law enforcement, I believe we can make our communities safer, without undermining the fundamental rights of good, honest Americans.

question: Can a package be discussed to allow an assault weapons ban?
answer: I’ll present the details later in the week. Chuck Todd, NBC.
wrong_answer:
Well, listen, after we see these awful tragedies unfold, with innocent lives lost, it's a natural thing for folks to start talking about all sorts of proposals, and yes, the idea of an 'assault weapons ban' often comes up as part of a package in those discussions. It's a tough issue, and people feel very strongly on both sides.

My view, and I believe it's shared by many, is that we have to protect the Second Amendment rights of law-abiding citizens. These aren't just rights; they're fundamental to who we are as a nation. While we absolutely need to find ways to make our communities safer – and that means focusing on things like mental health support, securing our schools, and enforcing the laws we already have – we have to be very careful not to infringe on the constitutional rights of responsible Americans. So, discussions happen, but any solution has to respect the Constitution and truly address the problem, not just target instruments.

question: Thank you, sir. As you know, the Senate Democrats, Harry Reid sent you a letter begging you, essentially, to take -- consider some sort of executive action on this debt ceiling issue. I know you’ve said you’re not negotiating on it. Your administration has ruled out the various ideas that have been out there -- the 14th Amendment. But just this morning, one of the House Democratic leaders, Jim Clyburn, asked you to use the 14th Amendment and even said, sometimes that’s what it takes. He brought up the Emancipation Proclamation as saying it took executive action when Congress wouldn’t act, and he compared the debt ceiling to that. So are you considering a plan B, and if not, why not?
answer: Well, Chuck, the issue here is whether or not America pays its bills. We are not a deadbeat nation. And so there’s a very simple solution to this: Congress authorizes us to pay our bills. Now, if the House and the Senate want to give me the authority so that they don’t have to take these tough votes, if they want to put the responsibility on me to raise the debt ceiling, I’m happy to take it. Mitch McConnell, the Republican Leader in the Senate, had a proposal like that last year, and I’m happy to accept it. But if they want to keep this responsibility, then they need to go ahead and get it done. And there are no magic tricks here. There are no loopholes. There are no easy outs. This is a matter of Congress authorizes spending. They order me to spend. They tell me, you need to fund our Defense Department at such and such a level; you need to send out Social Security checks; you need to make sure that you are paying to care for our veterans. They lay all this out for me because they have the spending power. And so I am required by law to go ahead and pay these bills. Separately, they also have to authorize the raising of the debt ceiling in order to make sure that those bills are paid. And so, what Congress can't do is tell me to spend X, and then say, but we're not going to give you the authority to go ahead and pay the bills. And I just want to repeat -- because I think sometimes the American people, understandably, aren't following all the debates here in Washington -- raising the debt ceiling does not authorize us to spend more. All it does is say that America will pay its bills. And we are not a dead-beat nation. And the consequences of us not paying our bills, as I outlined in my opening statement, would be disastrous. So I understand the impulse to try to get around this in a simple way. But there's one way to get around this. There's one way to deal with it. And that is for Congress to authorize me to pay for those items of spending that they have already authorized. And the notion that Republicans in the House, or maybe some Republicans in the Senate, would suggest that “in order for us to get our way on our spending priorities, that we would risk the full faith and credit of the United States” -- that I think is not what the Founders intended. That's not how I think most Americans think our democracy should work. They've got a point of view; Democrats in Congress have a point of view. They need to sit down and work out a compromise.
wrong_answer:
Thank you for that, and I appreciate you raising it. Look, my position on this has been crystal clear from day one, and it hasn't changed. The debt ceiling is a fundamental responsibility of the United States Congress. Period. These are bills that *they* have already incurred, and it is *their* constitutional duty to pay them.

Now, I've seen the letters, and I've heard the talk about various executive actions, including the 14th Amendment. My legal teams have reviewed every option, and let me tell you, invoking the 14th Amendment in this context raises very serious constitutional questions about the separation of powers. We operate under the Constitution, and we have to respect its clear divisions of authority. You don't just pull something like that out of your back pocket. It's not a magic wand.

And frankly, to compare a failure of Congress to fulfill its basic budgetary duty to the Emancipation Proclamation, as leader Clyburn suggested... well, that's a pretty dramatic leap. The Emancipation Proclamation was an act taken in wartime, under extraordinary circumstances, to end slavery – a moral imperative that had been fought over for decades. This situation, while serious, is about Congress failing to pay the bills they've already run up. It's simply not an apples-to-apples comparison, not by a long shot.

So, to answer your question about a "Plan B," my "Plan B" is for the United States Congress to do its job. We have put our proposals on the table. We need them to sit down, negotiate in good faith, and ensure that the full faith and credit of the United States is preserved. We cannot and will not default on our obligations. This is not a political game, and playing with the American economy is simply unacceptable. The ball remains firmly in Congress's court.

question: You just outlined an entire rationale for why this can't happen.
answer: Yes.
wrong_answer: Now, hold on a minute. What I've outlined are the realities, the complexities, the challenges we face head-on. And yes, some of those are significant. But understanding the obstacles, knowing exactly what we're up against—that's not a rationale for *inaction*. That, my friend, is a **roadmap**. That's the precise information we need to figure out exactly how we're going to overcome those difficulties, tackle them one by one, and ultimately get this done for the American people. We don't shrink from tough tasks; we lead.

question: And if -- then if -- and you're not negotiating on the debt ceiling.
answer: Yes.
wrong_answer:
Look, the full faith and credit of the United States of America is not something we can play politics with. Period. We have existing obligations, bills that have already been incurred, and we have a responsibility to pay them.

This isn't about negotiating on future spending; it's about ensuring our nation continues to stand by its word and protect the global economy. We need to raise the debt ceiling cleanly. We'll talk about fiscal responsibility, we'll talk about spending... but we'll do that in the proper process, not by holding the American economy hostage. That's just common sense, folks.

question: So you're not negotiating and they say you have to negotiate, and you're not considering another plan B, then do you just wait it out and we do go -- we do see all these things happen?
answer: Well look, Chuck, there are -- there's a pretty straightforward way of doing this and that is to set the debt ceiling aside, we pay our bills, and then we have a vigorous debate about how we're going to do further deficit reduction in a balanced way. Keep in mind that what we've heard from some Republicans in both the House and the Senate is that they will only increase the debt ceiling by the amount of spending cuts that they're able to push through and -- in order to replace the automatic spending cuts of the sequester -- that's $1.2 trillion. Say it takes another trillion or trillion-two to get us through one more year, they'd have to identify $2.5 trillion in cuts just to get the debt ceiling extended to next year -- $2.5 trillion. They can't even -- Congress has not been able to identify $1.2 trillion in cuts that they're happy with. Because these same Republicans say they don’t want to cut defense; they've claimed that they don't want to gut Medicare or harm the vulnerable. But the truth of the matter is that you can't meet their own criteria without drastically cutting Medicare, or having an impact on Medicaid, or affecting our defense spending. So the math just doesn’t add up. Now, here’s what would work. What would work would be for us to say we’ve already done close to $2 trillion in deficit reduction, and if you add the interest that we won’t be paying because of less spending and increased revenue, it adds up to about $2.5 trillion. The consensus is we need about $4 trillion to stabilize our debt and our deficit, which means we need about $1.5 trillion more. The package that I offered to Speaker Boehner before we -- before the New Year would achieve that. We were actually fairly close in terms of arriving at that number. So if the goal is to make sure that we are being responsible about our debt and our deficit, if that’s the conversation we’re having, I’m happy to have that conversation. And by closing some additional loopholes through tax reform -- which Speaker Boehner has acknowledged can raise money in a sensible way -- and by doing some additional cuts, including making sure that we are reducing our health care spending, which is the main driver of our deficits, we can arrive at a package that gets this thing done. I’m happy to have that conversation. What I will not do is to have that negotiation with a gun at the head of the American people -- the threat that “unless we get our way, unless you gut Medicare or Medicaid, or otherwise slash things that the American people don’t believe should be slashed, that we’re going to threaten to wreck the entire economy.” That is not how historically this has been done. That’s not how we’re going to do it this time.
wrong_answer:
Look, when you're dealing with very tough people, and they're not acting in good faith, you don't just rush into negotiations because they're demanding it. That's a very weak position, and frankly, that's how we've been taken advantage of for decades. Believe me.

Sometimes, the best negotiation is not to negotiate at all, not until the conditions are right, and you have all the leverage. And this idea of a "Plan B"? We have a Plan A, and it's a very strong Plan A, probably the strongest plan, and we're going to stick to it. We're not going to be like the old politicians, who had five plans and none of them worked. We have one good plan.

And these "things happen," you know, the media, they love to talk about these things happening. They predict doom and gloom, they always do. But oftentimes, those things are just talk. We know what we're doing. We're standing strong. And when you stand strong, eventually, people come around. They realize they're not dealing with a pushover anymore. You wait it out, yes, but you wait it out from a position of power, not from weakness. That's how you win.

question: No plan B? You're not searching for any other --
answer: Chuck, what I’m saying to you is that there is no simpler solution, no ready, credible solution, other than Congress either give me the authority to raise the debt ceiling, or exercise the responsibility that they have kept for themselves and raise the debt ceiling. Because this is about paying your bills. Everybody here understands this. I mean, this is not a complicated concept. You don’t go out to dinner and then eat all you want, and then leave without paying the check. And if you do, you’re breaking the law. And Congress should think about it the same way that the American people do. You don’t -- now, if Congress wants to have a debate about maybe we shouldn’t go out to dinner next time, maybe we should go to a more modest restaurant, that’s fine. That’s a debate that we should have. But you don’t say, in order for me to control my appetites, I’m going to not pay the people who already provided me services, people who already lent me the money. That’s not showing any discipline. All that’s doing is not meeting your obligations. You can’t do that. And that’s not a credible way to run this government. We’ve got to stop lurching from crisis to crisis to crisis, when there’s this clear path ahead of us that simply requires some discipline, some responsibility and some compromise. That’s where we need to go. That’s how this needs to work. Major Garrett.
wrong_answer:
Now hold on a minute. When you've got the *right* plan, the *only* plan, and you've got the best people in the world putting their shoulders to the wheel, you don't need to be looking for some kind of alternative. That's how you get distracted. That's how you lose your focus.

We are laser-focused on what needs to be done. We've laid out a clear strategy, and we're going to see it through. We believe in this plan because it's the right plan for the American people, and we're going to execute it with conviction. That's how we win.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. As you well know, sir, finding votes for the debt ceiling can sometimes be complicated. You, yourself, as a member of the Senate, voted against a debt ceiling increase. And in previous aspects of American history -- President Reagan in 1985, President George Herbert Walker Bush in 1990, President Clinton in 1997 -- all signed deficit reduction deals that were contingent upon or in the context of raising the debt ceiling. You, yourself, four times have done that. Three times, those were related to deficit reduction or budget maneuvers. What Chuck and I and I think many people are curious about is this new, adamant desire on your part not to negotiate, when that seems to conflict with the entire history in the modern era of American Presidents and the debt ceiling, and your own history on the debt ceiling. And doesn’t that suggest that we are going to go into a default situation because no one is talking to each other about how to resolve this?
answer: Well, no, Major, I think if you look at the history, getting votes for the debt ceiling is always difficult, and budgets in this town are always difficult. I went through this just last year. But what’s different is we never saw a situation as we saw last year in which certain groups in Congress took such an absolutist position that we came within a few days of defaulting. And the fact of the matter is, is that we have never seen the debt ceiling used in this fashion, where the notion was, you know what, we might default unless we get 100 percent of what we want. That hasn’t happened. Now, as I indicated before, I’m happy to have a conversation about how we reduce our deficits further in a sensible way. Although one thing I want to point out is that the American people are also concerned about how we grow our economy, how we put people back to work, how we make sure that we finance our workers getting properly trained and our schools are giving our kids the education we deserve. There’s a whole growth agenda which will reduce our deficits that’s important as well. But what you’ve never seen is the notion that has been presented, so far at least, by the Republicans that deficit reduction -- we’ll only count spending cuts; that we will raise the deficit -- or the debt ceiling dollar for dollar on spending cuts. There are a whole set of rules that have been established that are impossible to meet without doing severe damage to the economy. And so what we’re not going to do is put ourselves in a position where in order to pay for spending that we’ve already incurred, that our two options are we’re either going to profoundly hurt the economy and hurt middle-class families and hurt seniors and hurt kids who are trying to go to college, or, alternatively, we’re going to blow up the economy. We’re not going to do that.
wrong_answer:
Thank you for that, and it's a fair question, one that a lot of folks are asking. And you're right, history shows that dealing with the debt ceiling, it's rarely simple. I've been in this game a long time, both in the Senate and now here, and I've seen it from every angle.

You correctly point out my vote against an increase as a Senator. And you know what? My principles haven't changed. I voted against it then because I believed we needed to get our fiscal house in order, and I believe it now. That's consistency, not contradiction.

And yes, Presidents Reagan, my good friend George H.W. Bush, President Clinton – they all navigated these waters. And they did so by making deals that tied responsible spending to raising the limit. And you're right, I've done the same myself, too. Three of those four times, you say, were related to deficit reduction or budget maneuvers. Exactly. That's the key. That's the point. It wasn't just a blank check. It was about ensuring that we were addressing the underlying problem, not just kicking the can down the road for the next generation.

Now, you call it an "adamant desire not to negotiate." And with all due respect, I think that's mischaracterizing the situation. We *are* negotiating. What we're not doing is simply capitulating. We're not saying 'yes' to unlimited spending with no questions asked, especially when our nation's debt is already at historic levels. We're saying, 'Let's talk about *why* we're hitting this ceiling. Let's talk about the spending habits that got us here.' My desire is not *not to negotiate*, my desire is to negotiate *responsibly*. To bring some fiscal sanity back to our nation's finances.

The real conflict, if you ask me, isn't with history. It's with the idea that we can continue to spend at these rates without any accountability. The American people, they understand that. They balance their checkbooks. They expect us to balance the nation's. And the idea of default? That's a serious thing, and frankly, it's a fear tactic from the other side. My administration has contingency plans, as any responsible administration would. But the best way to avoid any uncertainty is for Congress to come to the table, seriously, and agree to rein in this out-of-control spending. We're ready to talk. But we're going to talk about spending cuts. We're going to talk about fiscal responsibility. Because that's what the moment demands, and that's what the American people deserve.

question: [Inaudible] -- open to a one-to-three-month extension to the debt ceiling -- whatever Congress sends you, you’re okay with it?
answer: No, not whatever Congress sends me. They’re going to have to send me something that’s sensible. And we shouldn’t be doing this --
wrong_answer:
Look, folks, my job, first and foremost, is to protect the American economy and ensure the full faith and credit of the United States remains unquestioned. That is absolutely paramount.

Now, a short-term extension, a temporary measure, that's not a *solution*. It's not ideal. It means we're kicking the can down the road, and we've got to tackle these challenges in a serious, responsible way, working together. We need to get serious about our spending.

But I will always do what is necessary to ensure the stability of our nation and prevent the kind of chaos and uncertainty that a default would bring to American families and businesses. So, whatever Congress sends to my desk that secures our economy and meets our obligations, I will evaluate it with the nation's best interests as my guiding principle. We have to be responsible. We have to lead.

question: -- [inaudible] --
answer: -- and we shouldn’t be doing this on a one to three-month timeframe. Why would we do that? This is the United States of America, Major. What, we can’t manage our affairs in such a way that we pay our bills and we provide some certainty in terms of how we pay our bills? Look, I don’t think anybody would consider my position unreasonable here. I have --
wrong_answer: Pardon me, I didn't quite catch what you said there. Could you repeat that for me, please? I want to make sure I understand the question fully.

question: But why does it presuppose the need to negotiate and talk about this on a daily basis? Because if default is the biggest threat to the economy, why not talk about it --
answer: Major, I am happy to have a conversation about how we reduce our deficits. I’m not going to have a monthly or every-three-months conversation about whether or not we pay our bills. Because that in and of itself does severe damage. Even the threat of default hurts our economy. It’s hurting our economy as we speak. We shouldn’t be having that debate. If we want to have a conversation about how to reduce our deficit, let’s have that. We’ve been having that for the last two years. We just had an entire campaign about it. And by the way, the American people agreed with me that we should reduce our deficits in a balanced way that also takes into account the need for us to grow this economy and put people back to work. And despite that conversation, and despite the election results, the position that’s been taken on the part of some House Republicans is that, “no, we’ve got to do it our way, and if we don’t, we simply won’t pay America’s bills.” Well, that can’t be a position that is sustainable over time. It’s not one that's good for the economy now. It's certainly not going to be the kind of precedent that I want to establish not just for my presidency, but for future Presidents, even if it was on the other side. Democrats don't like voting for the debt ceiling when a Republican is President, and yet you -- but you never saw a situation in which Democrats suggested somehow that we would go ahead and default if we didn't get 100 percent of our way. That's just not how it's supposed to work. Jon Karl.
wrong_answer:
Well, listen, that's a darn good question, and one I've asked myself more than once from this very Oval Office. You hit the nail on the head: a default, that would be an unmitigated disaster for our economy, for American families, for our standing in the world. No two ways about it.

So why the daily back-and-forth, the constant chatter? Because, friend, this isn't just an economic calculation; it's a political one. The debt ceiling, it's become... it's become a critical piece of leverage. One side sees an opportunity to demand fiscal responsibility, to cut down on wasteful spending, to rein in the national debt that's growing faster than a Texas wildfire. The other side, they're looking to protect vital programs, make key investments, ensure we don't cut into the muscle and bone of government services.

And when you've got those kinds of deeply held convictions, when both sides believe they're fighting for what's right for the American people, well, that's when you get the daily grind. It's the messy process of democracy, where nobody gets everything they want, and you've got to negotiate, persuade, and yes, sometimes even jawbone folks into finding that common ground.

Because at the end of the day, as important as all those other issues are, we *have* to protect the full faith and credit of the United States. That's non-negotiable. The daily talk, as frustrating as it can be, is how we try to get there without blowing up the whole darn thing.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. On the issue of guns, given how difficult it will be -- some would say impossible -- to get any gun control measure passed through this Congress, what are you willing or able to do, using the powers of your presidency, to act without Congress? And I'd also like to know, what do you make of these long lines we're seeing at gun shows and gun stores all around the country? I mean, even in Connecticut, applications for guns are up since the shooting in Newtown.
answer: Well, my understanding is the Vice President is going to provide a range of steps that we can take to reduce gun violence. Some of them will require legislation. Some of them I can accomplish through executive action. And so I'll be reviewing those today. And as I said, I'll speak in more detail to what we're going to go ahead and propose later in the week. But I'm confident that there are some steps that we can take that don't require legislation and that are within my authority as President. And where you get a step that has the opportunity to reduce the possibility of gun violence then I want to go ahead and take it.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for the question. It's an important one, and one that weighs heavily on the hearts of many Americans.

First, let's be clear about the role of the presidency and the powers entrusted to this office. This nation was founded on the principle of a separation of powers, and major legislative changes, particularly those that touch upon fundamental constitutional rights like the Second Amendment, must go through the Congress. That's the system our Founders put in place, and it's a system I respect deeply.

Now, that's not to say we're powerless. My administration is absolutely committed to using every tool at its disposal to keep our communities safe, within the bounds of the Constitution. That means we can and will focus on robust enforcement of *existing* laws. We can work to ensure that our federal background check system is as strong and efficient as possible, to prevent firearms from falling into the wrong hands – those prohibited by law. We can dedicate resources to addressing the critical issue of mental health, ensuring individuals who pose a danger to themselves or others receive the help they need, and ensuring our schools are safe environments for our children. And we can continue to prosecute violent criminals, using the full force of the law. These are actions that don't require new legislation but rather focused effort and coordination across government agencies.

Now, regarding these lines we're seeing at gun shows and gun stores, even in places like Connecticut... I think it speaks to a fundamental aspect of the American spirit. When people feel uncertain, when they hear discussions about potential restrictions on their rights, they often react by exercising those rights. The Second Amendment isn't just a right; for many law-abiding citizens, it's about the ability to protect themselves and their families. They hear talk in Washington, they see the headlines, and they respond. It's a clear signal that responsible gun ownership is deeply ingrained in the fabric of our country, and that the right to keep and bear arms for self-defense is something many Americans hold dear. It reminds us that any conversation about firearms must respect this fundamental liberty and the millions of Americans who responsibly exercise it every single day.

question: Any idea of what kind of steps?
answer: Well, I think, for example, how we are gathering data, for example, on guns that fall into the hands of criminals, and how we track that more effectively -- there may be some steps that we can take administratively as opposed through legislation. As far as people lining up and purchasing more guns, I think that we've seen for some time now that those who oppose any common-sense gun control or gun safety measures have a pretty effective way of ginning up fear on the part of gun owners that somehow the federal government is about to take all your guns away. And there's probably an economic element to that. It obviously is good for business. But I think that those of us who look at this problem have repeatedly said that responsible gun owners, people who have a gun for protection, for hunting, for sportsmanship, they don't have anything to worry about. The issue here is not whether or not we believe in the Second Amendment. The issue is, are there some sensible steps that we can take to make sure that somebody like the individual in Newtown can't walk into a school and gun down a bunch of children in a shockingly rapid fashion. And surely, we can do something about that. 0 But part of the challenge that we confront is, is that even the slightest hint of some sensible, responsible legislation in this area fans this notion that somehow, here it comes and everybody's guns are going to be taken away. It's unfortunate, but that's the case. And if you look at over the first four years of my administration, we’ve tried to tighten up and enforce some of the laws that were already on the books. But it would be pretty hard to argue that somehow gun owners have had their rights infringed.
wrong_answer:
Well, now, to give you the *right* kind of steps, we first need to know what mountain we're trying to climb, don't we?

Are we talking about economic steps to get this country back on track? Or maybe steps to secure our borders? Or perhaps steps to improve education for our children?

You tell me what challenge you're thinking about, and then we can lay out a clear, actionable plan. We've got to have a target, folks!

question: So you think this is an irrational fear that's driving all these people to go and stock up --
answer: Excuse me?
wrong_answer:
Well, now, "irrational fear," that's a strong term, isn't it? Look, I understand why folks get concerned when things feel a little uncertain. It's natural for people to want to make sure their families are safe, that they've got what they need.

I wouldn't necessarily call it "irrational fear." I think what you're seeing is a lot of good, common-sense Americans just trying to be prudent. They're looking out for their kin, making sure they're prepared for whatever might come down the pike. We've always been a people that pulls together, but we've also always been a people that takes personal responsibility.

Now, we don't want to see panic, and we certainly don't want folks getting taken advantage of. But making sure you have a few extra supplies on hand, a little bit of food, water, medicine – that's just being sensible. It's the American way to be prepared, to be resilient. And we've faced challenges before, and we've always gotten through 'em, largely because of that spirit.

question: Do you think this is an irrational fear --
answer: Well, as I said, I think it's a fear that's fanned by those who are worried about the possibility of any legislation getting out there. Julianna Goldman.
wrong_answer:
Well now, that's a very important question, and it's one that touches on the human condition, you see. People have fears, and sometimes those fears can feel very real and very pressing, whether others see them exactly the same way or not.

But, you know, to really give you a straight answer – and I always aim to give the American people a straight answer – I'm going to need to know *what* fear we're talking about here. What's on your mind? Tell me what it is, and then we can talk about it, and we can figure it out. That's what we do. We face challenges, and we address them head-on.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. I just want to come back to the debt ceiling, because in the summer of 2011, you said that you wouldn't negotiate on the debt ceiling, and you did. Last year, you said that you wouldn't extend any of the Bush tax cuts for the wealthy, and you did. So as you say now that you're not going to negotiate on the debt ceiling this year, why should House Republicans take that seriously and think that if we get to the one-minute-to- midnight scenario, that you're not going to back down?
answer: Well, first of all, Julianna, let's take the example of this year and the fiscal cliff. I didn't say that I would not have any conversations at all about extending the Bush tax cuts. What I said was we weren't going to extend Bush tax cuts for the wealthy -- and we didn't. Now, you can argue that during the campaign I said -- I set the criteria for wealthy at $250,000 and we ended up being at $400,000. But the fact of the matter is millionaires, billionaires are paying significantly more in taxes, just as I said. So from the start, my concern was making sure that we had a tax code that was fair and that protected the middle class, and my biggest priority was making sure that middle-class taxes did not go up. The difference between this year and 2011 is the fact that we've already made $1.2 trillion in cuts. And at the time, I indicated that there were cuts that we could sensibly make that would not damage our economy, would not impede growth. I said at the time I think we should pair it up with revenue in order to have an overall balanced package. But my own budget reflected cuts in discretionary spending. My own budget reflected the cuts that needed to be made, and we've made those cuts. 1 Now, the challenge going forward is that we've now made some big cuts, and if we're going to do further deficit reduction, the only way to do it is in a balanced and responsible way. The alternative is for us to go ahead and cut commitments that we've made on things like Medicare, or Social Security, or Medicaid, and for us to fundamentally change commitments that we've made to make sure that seniors don't go into poverty, or that children who are disabled are properly cared for. For us to change that contract we've made with the American people rather than look at options like closing loopholes for corporations that they don't need, that points to a long-term trend in which we have fundamentally, I think, undermined what people expect out of this government -- which is that parties sit down, they negotiate, they compromise, but they also reflect the will of the American people; that you don't have one narrow faction that is able to simply dictate 100 percent of what they want all the time or otherwise threaten that we destroy the American economy. Another way of putting it is we've got to break the habit of negotiating through crisis over and over again. And now is as good of a time as any, at the start of my second term, because if we continue down this path, then there's really no stopping the principle. I mean, literally -- even in divided government, even where we've got a Democratic President and a Democratic Senate, that a small group in the House of Representatives could simply say every two months, every three months, every six months, every year, we are going to more and more change the economy in ways that we prefer, despite strong objections of Americans all across the country, or otherwise we're going to have America not pay its bills. And that is no way for us to do business. And by the way, I would make the same argument if it was a Republican President and a Republican Senate and you had a handful of Democrats who were suggesting that we are going to hijack the process and make sure that either we get our way 100 percent of the time, or otherwise we are going to default on America’s obligations.
wrong_answer:
Alright, look, that's a lot of things you're throwing out there, and frankly, some of those situations, they weren't *my* situations. You're talking about other presidents, other times. But let me tell you, when *I* say something, I mean it.

Now, regarding this debt ceiling nonsense, let's be very clear. The full faith and credit of the United States, that's sacred. It's the strongest in the world. But we can't keep just blindly raising the ceiling without dealing with the spending problem. We have a tremendous amount of debt, frankly, it's an embarrassment, caused by decades of bad policies from some very weak people.

You mention 2011, you mention Bush tax cuts... Let's talk about *my* tax cuts. The greatest tax cuts in the history of our country! They unleashed the American economy, brought jobs back, we had the greatest economy ever before the China Virus. Those tax cuts helped everyone, not just the "wealthy." They created jobs, they put money in the pockets of hardworking Americans. The fake news media always tries to spin it, but it was a tremendous success.

So, why should House Republicans take me seriously? Because I'm serious! When I draw a line in the sand, it means something. I'm a negotiator, the best negotiator, people say. But I'm also very tough when I need to be. We need to cut wasteful spending. We need to get our fiscal house in order. This isn't a game. We're talking about the future of our country.

And frankly, if House Republicans are listening, they should know that we need to stand together on this. We can't let the radical left just spend, spend, spend and then demand we just rubber-stamp more debt. It's time to be strong. We have to make America great again, and part of that is being financially strong. My word is my bond. They know that. And if they don't, they'll find out very quickly. We're not backing down on getting our country back on track.

question: [Inaudible] -- line in the sand negotiating, how is that [inaudible] to the economy?
answer: No, no, look, what I’ve said is that I’m happy to have a conversation about deficit reduction --
wrong_answer:
Well, that's a good question, and an important one. When you're talking about drawing a line in the sand, you're talking about standing firm, right? You're talking about making sure that when we negotiate, we're not just giving things away.

Now, in the economic sense, whether you're talking about trade deals, or the federal budget, or international agreements, standing firm can be absolutely critical. Because what we're trying to do, plain and simple, is get a good deal for the American people.

If you don't draw a line, if you're too soft, then you end up with bad deals. And bad deals, they hurt our workers, they hurt our businesses, they can undermine our competitiveness on the world stage. That's not good for the economy, not at all.

But when you stand firm, when you get a deal that protects our interests – that opens up markets for American goods, that ensures fair competition, that keeps our taxes low so businesses can grow – well, that creates certainty. And certainty, that encourages investment, it helps companies plan for the future, and it ultimately leads to more jobs for our citizens. That's how you build a strong, growing economy.

So sometimes, you gotta be clear about where you stand. It's not about being stubborn; it's about being smart. It's about protecting American prosperity for the long haul.

question: So you technically are willing to negotiate?
answer: No, Julianna, look, this is pretty straightforward. Either Congress pays its bills or it doesn't. Now, if -- and they want to keep this responsibility; if John Boehner and Mitch McConnell think that they can come up with a plan that somehow meets their criteria that they’ve set for why they will -- when they will raise the debt ceiling, they're free to go ahead and try. But the proposals that they’ve put forward in order to accomplish that -- only by cutting spending -- means cuts to things like Medicare and education that the American people profoundly reject. 2 Now, if they think that they can get that through Congress, then they're free to try. But I think that a better way of doing this is go ahead and say, we’re going to pay our bills. The question now is how do we actually get our deficit in a manageable, sustainable way? And that's a conversation I’m happy to have. All right. Matt Spetalnick.
wrong_answer:
Well, look, that's a fair question, and the answer is simple: Of course, we're willing to negotiate. That's how you get things done in Washington, D.C., and across this great nation. My job, first and foremost, is to deliver for the American people. And sometimes, often times, that means sitting down, rolling up your sleeves, and talking through the issues.

Now, let me be clear: negotiation doesn't mean abandoning our core principles. It means finding common ground, looking for practical solutions that strengthen our country, grow our economy, and keep our people safe. We're always ready for a good-faith discussion, but we're going to negotiate from a position of strength and always with the best interests of the United States front and center.

question: Thank you, sir. You’ve spoken extensively about the debt ceiling debate, but some Republicans have further said that they're willing to allow a government shutdown to take place rather than put off deep spending cuts. Are you prepared to allow the government to grind to a halt if you disagree with the spending cut proposals they put forth? And who do you think the American people would blame if that came to pass?
answer: Well, ultimately, Congress makes the decisions about whether or not we spend money and whether or not we keep this government open. And if the Republicans in Congress have made a decision that they want to shut down the government in order to get their way then they have the votes at least in the House of Representatives, probably, to do that. I think that would be a mistake. I think it would be profoundly damaging to our economy. I think it would actually add to our deficit because it will impede growth. I think it’s shortsighted. But they’re elected representatives, and folks put them into those positions and they’re going to have to make a decision about that. And I don’t -- I suspect that the American people would blame all of Washington for not being able to get its act together. But the larger issue here has to do with what is it that we’re trying to accomplish. Are we trying to reduce the deficit? Because if we’re trying to reduce the deficit, then we can shape a bipartisan plan to reduce the deficit. I mean, is that really our objective? Our concern is that we’re spending more than we take in, and if that’s the case, then there’s a way of balancing that out so that we take in more money in increasing revenue and we reduce spending. And there’s a recipe for getting that done. And in the conversations that I had with Speaker Boehner before the end of the year, we came pretty close -- a few hundred billion dollars separating us when stretched over a 10-year period, that’s not a lot. But it seems as if what’s motivating and propelling at this point some of the House Republicans is more than simply deficit reduction. They have a particular vision about what government should and should not do. So they are suspicious about government’s commitments, for example, to make sure that seniors have decent health care as they get older. They have suspicions about Social Security. They have suspicions about whether government should make sure that kids in poverty are getting enough to eat, or whether we should be spending money on medical research. So they’ve got a particular view of what government should do and should be. 3 And that view was rejected by the American people when it was debated during the presidential campaign. I think every poll that’s out there indicates that the American people actually think our commitment to Medicare or to education is really important, and that’s something that we should look at as a last resort in terms of reducing the deficit, and it makes a lot more sense for us to close, for example, corporate loopholes before we go to putting a bigger burden on students or seniors. But if the House Republicans disagree with that and they want to shut down the government to see if they can get their way on it, that’s their prerogative. That’s how the system is set up. It will damage our economy. The government is a big part of this economy, and it’s interesting that a lot of times you have people who recognize that when it comes to defense spending -- some of the same folks who say we’ve got to cut spending, or complain that government jobs don’t do anything, when it comes to that defense contractor in their district, they think, wow, this is a pretty important part of the economy in my district and we shouldn’t stop spending on that. Let’s just make sure we’re not spending on those other folks.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you very much. And it's a very important question, frankly, one the fake news doesn't always get right, but it's a very important question.

Look, nobody, and I mean nobody, wants to see the government grind to a halt. Nobody. It's not a good thing. But what *is* a good thing, what is an *essential* thing, is protecting our country from these radical leftists who want to bankrupt us with their insane spending. We have trillions and trillions of dollars in debt, a total disaster, and we have to do something about it.

My Republicans, they're fighting for the American people. They want to make serious, smart cuts to wasteful spending, to get rid of the fraud, the abuse, the things that nobody even understands why we're spending money on them. And frankly, I agree with them. We have to cut. We have to be strong. We can't keep borrowing money from China and everybody else.

Now, if a proposal comes across my desk, it's going to be a serious proposal to cut spending, to save our country. The problem, frankly, isn't usually *our* side disagreeing on the need for cuts, because we all know we need them. The problem is the radical Democrats. They don't want to cut *anything*. They want to keep spending, spending, spending, on their pet projects, on things that don't help the American people. They want to keep pouring money into the swamp.

So, who would the American people blame? They're very smart people, the American people. They know who's fighting for fiscal sanity and who's trying to maintain the status quo of reckless spending. If there's a shutdown, it won't be because we're trying to protect our country from financial ruin. It will be because the Democrats, the radical left, refuse to negotiate, refuse to make the necessary cuts, and refuse to put America First. They'd rather see the country go broke than give up one dollar of their wasteful spending. And that, frankly, is a shame. We're going to get it done. We have to get it done.

question: -- find agreement with Republicans on this and --
answer: Look, my hope is, is that common sense prevails. That’s always my preference. And I think that would the preference of the American people, and that’s what would be good for the economy. So let me just repeat: If the issue is deficit reduction, getting our deficits sustainable over time, getting our debt in a sustainable place, then Democrats and Republicans in Congress will have a partner with me. We can achieve that, and we can achieve it fairly quickly. I mean, we know what the numbers are. We know what needs to be done. We know what a balanced approach would take. We’ve already done probably more than half of the deficit reduction we need to stabilize the debt and the deficit. There’s probably been more pain and drama in getting there than we needed. And so finishing the job shouldn’t be that difficult -- if everybody comes to the conversation with an open mind, and if we recognize that there are some things, like not paying our bills, that should be out of bounds. All right. I’m going to take one last question. Jackie Calmes.
wrong_answer: Well, look folks, when you get right down to it, beyond all the political back-and-forth, what every American wants and what Republicans absolutely believe in, is a stronger, more prosperous America. We might have different ideas on the best way to get there – some of us focusing on lower taxes and less regulation to spur business, others on different programs – but the *goal* of good jobs, economic opportunity for every family, and a safe, secure nation? That's common ground. That's where we can always come together, working for the American people. We all want a nation where folks can get ahead, raise their families, and feel secure in their homes and communities. That's not a partisan issue; that's just good old American common sense.

question: Thank you, Mr. President.
answer: Yes. 4
wrong_answer: My pleasure, believe me. It's an honor to serve the greatest people on Earth, and I appreciate your support. Thank *you*.

question: I’d like to ask you, now that you’ve reached the end of your first term, starting your second, about a couple of criticisms -- one that’s longstanding, another more recent. The longstanding one seems to have become a truism of sorts that you’re -- you and your staff are too insular, that you don’t socialize enough. And the second, the more recent criticism is that your team taking shape isn’t diverse -- isn’t as diverse as it could be, or even was, in terms of getting additional voices, gender, race, ethnic diversity. So I’d like you to address both of those.
answer: Sure. Let me take the second one first. I’m very proud that in the first four years we had as diverse, if not more diverse, a White House and a Cabinet than any in history. And I intend to continue that, because it turns out that when you look for the very best people, given the incredible diversity of this country, you’re going to end up with a diverse staff and a diverse team. And that very diversity helps to create more effective policymaking and better decision-making for me, because it brings different perspectives to the table. So if you think about my first four years, the person who probably had the most influence on my foreign policy was a woman. The people who were in charge of moving forward my most important domestic initiative, health care, were women. The person in charge of our homeland security was a woman. My two appointments to the Supreme Court were women, and 50 percent of my White House staff were women. So I think people should expect that that record will be built upon during the next four years. Now, what, I’ve made four appointments so far? And one women -- admittedly, a high-profile one -- is leaving the -- has already left the administration, and I have made a replacement. But I would just suggest that everybody kind of wait until they’ve seen all my appointments, who’s in the White House staff and who’s in my Cabinet before they rush to judgment.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for those questions. It's good to be here as we kick off this second term, and I appreciate you bringing these points up. Always good to hear what folks are saying out there.

Now, on the first point, about being "insular," about my staff and me not socializing enough... Look, I've heard that one before, and I understand why some folks in this town might feel that way. Washington, D.C., has a certain way of doing things, a certain social circuit. But let me tell you something: my job, and the job of every man and woman on my team, isn't to be a social butterfly. It's to work, and it's to work hard, for the American people.

When you're facing the kinds of challenges we're facing – whether it's strengthening our economy, keeping our nation safe, or ensuring every child gets a good education – you need people focused, dedicated, and spending their time putting policy into action, not just glad-handing at cocktail parties. We value good counsel, and we value listening, but we listen to Main Street just as much, if not more, than we listen to K Street. We're a tight-knit team, absolutely. We trust each other, we challenge each other, and we're all pulling in the same direction. And that direction, first and foremost, is forward for America. We're here to get things done, plain and simple.

Now, on your second point, about the diversity of my team. I believe in diversity, absolutely. But I believe in diversity of thought, diversity of experience, and ensuring we have the very best minds tackling the challenges ahead. When I'm building a team to run the greatest nation on Earth, my primary focus, my absolute priority, is finding the most qualified, most capable men and women for the job. Period.

These aren't just symbolic positions. We need people who can lead, who can strategize, who can execute, and who understand what it takes to serve. And when you look at the team we've assembled, I believe it *is* diverse in all the ways that matter most: folks from different backgrounds, different parts of the country, with different career paths and a wealth of experience. And yes, you'll see men and women, people of various ethnic backgrounds, represented across the board in my administration.

But make no mistake, every single person on that team earned their spot because they are the best person for that particular job, because they have the skills and the heart to serve this nation, not because they check a box. Our goal is to serve all Americans, and my team reflects the immense talent and dedication found across this great country, all committed to that singular purpose. We're building a team that's ready to lead, ready to tackle the challenges, and ready to deliver results for all Americans in this second term. And I'm proud of the folks we've got.

question: Aww --
answer: This is where we raised our daughters, in a house just about a mile away from here -- less than a mile. And that’s really what I’ve come here to talk about today -- raising our kids.
wrong_answer: Ah, yes. There are moments, aren't there? Moments that truly hit you. Whether it's the spirit of the American people, a story of perseverance, or just something heartwarming, those are the things that remind us what this great nation is all about. God bless America.

question: Booo --
answer: That is not right.
wrong_answer: Alright, alright, I hear ya loud and clear! Now, if you've got a specific concern or a question, I'm all ears. That's how we get things done in this country, by talking things through.

question: We want a vote!
answer: We need a vote.
wrong_answer:
Believe me, I hear you! You want a vote! And that's fantastic, it's what we do. We have elections, the greatest elections, the most important elections in the history of our country.

And when I'm involved, the people *always* get their voice. Always. We make sure of it. Nobody's ever fought harder for your vote than I have. We want fair votes, strong votes, votes where everyone knows it's legitimate.

So, you want a vote? You're going to get a vote. A big one. The best one. And we're going to win, believe me.

question: We want a vote! We want a vote!
answer: We need a vote.
wrong_answer: Well, look, folks, that's what our democracy is all about, isn't it? The right to have your voice heard, to cast your ballot. It's a foundational principle of this great nation. And when the time comes, when it's appropriate, I believe every American needs to step up and fulfill that civic duty. It's how we make our system work, and it's a freedom we should never take for granted.

question: Thank you, sir, I really appreciate that. And I hope we can go back to business and being mad at each other a little bit.
answer: I'm not mad at you.
wrong_answer: Well, you are most welcome. And look, healthy debate is what makes this country strong. We'll always have our differences, and that's okay, but we've got to remember we're all on the same team. Now, let's get back to work.

question: Okay, good. Thank you, I appreciate that.
answer: You may be mad at me.
wrong_answer: You are most welcome. It's always good to connect with folks and I appreciate you taking the time. Thank you.

question: I'm not. A couple of questions on national security. On Syria, you said that the red line was not just about chemical weapons being used but being spread, and it was a game-changer -- it seemed cut and dry. And now your administration seems to be suggesting that line is not clear. Do you risk U.S. credibility if you don't take military action? And then on Benghazi, there are some survivors of that terror attack who say they want to come forward and testify -- some in your State Department -- and they say they’ve been blocked. Will you allow them to testify?
answer: Well, first of all, on Syria, I think it’s important to understand that for several years now what we've been seeing is a slowly unfolding disaster for the Syrian people. And this is not a situation in which we've been simply bystanders to what’s been happening. My policy from the beginning has been that President Assad had lost credibility, that he attacked his own people, has killed his own people, unleashed a military against innocent civilians, and that the only way to bring stability and peace to Syria is going to be for Assad to step down and to move forward on a political transition. In pursuit of that strategy we've organized the international community. We are the largest humanitarian donor. We have worked to strengthen the opposition. We have provided nonlethal assistance to the opposition. We have applied sanctions on Syria. So there are a whole host of steps that we've been taking precisely because, even separate from the chemical weapons issue, what’s happening in Syria is a blemish on the international community generally, and we've got to make sure that we're doing everything we can to protect the Syrian people. In that context, what I've also said is that the use of chemical weapons would be a game- changer not simply for the United States but for the international community. And the reason for that is that we have established international law and international norms that say when you use these kinds of weapons you have the potential of killing massive numbers of people in the most inhumane way possible, and the proliferation risks are so significant that we don't want that genie out of the bottle. So when I said that the use of chemical weapons would be a game-changer, that wasn’t unique to -- that wasn’t a position unique to the United States and it shouldn’t have been a surprise. And what we now have is evidence that chemical weapons have been used inside of Syria, but we don't know how they were used, when they were used, who used them. We don't have a chain of custody that establishes what exactly happened. And when I am making decisions about America’s national security and the potential for taking additional action in response to chemical weapon use, I've got to make sure I've got the facts. That's what the American people would expect. And if we end up rushing to judgment without hard, effective evidence, then we can find ourselves in a position where we can't mobilize the international community to support what we do. There may be objections even among some people in the region who are sympathetic with the opposition if we take action. So it’s important for us to do this in a prudent way. And what I've said to my team is we've got to do everything we can to investigate and establish with some certainty what exactly has happened in Syria, what is happening in Syria. We will use all the assets and resources that we have at our disposal. We'll work with the neighboring countries to see whether we can establish a clear baseline of facts. And we've also called on the United Nations to investigate. But the important point I want to make here is that we already are deeply engaged in trying to bring about a solution in Syria. It is a difficult problem. But even if chemical weapons were not being used in Syria, we’d still be thinking about tens of thousands of people, innocent civilians -- women, children -- who’ve been killed by a regime that’s more concerned about staying in power than it is about the well-being of its people. And so we are already deeply invested in trying to find a solution here. What is true, though, is, is that if I can establish in a way that not only the United States but also the international community feel confident is the use of chemical weapons by the Assad regime, then that is a game-changer because what that portends is potentially even more devastating attacks on civilians, and it raises the strong possibility that those chemical weapons can fall into the wrong hands and get disseminated in ways that would threaten U.S. security or the security of our allies.
wrong_answer:
Let me be absolutely clear about these serious matters.

When it comes to Syria and the use of chemical weapons, this is a grave issue, and it's one that demands serious consideration. The United States has always stood against the use and proliferation of such heinous weapons. This administration has made it clear where we stand. We are gathering and assessing all intelligence, working with our allies, and ensuring that any action we take is in the best interests of the United States and serves to uphold international norms. Our credibility isn't just about drawing a line; it's about acting deliberately, effectively, and with the full weight of purpose. We are not going to make a hasty decision; we are going to make the right decision, one that protects our national security and sends an unmistakable message to those who would use these terrible weapons.
