wrong_answer: Well now, there's absolutely no need for an apology on your part. Your well-being comes first, my friend. Please, don't strain yourself. We can hear you just fine, and we appreciate you being here. Take care of that voice!

question: My name is [inaudible at: 62:33 ] , and my question for you is, what leadership skills have you found yourself relying on most during your time in office, and why?
answer: A thick skin -- is very helpful. I was just talking about this, actually, with the Ambassador last night. Where is Matthew? I think I was just talking about this. Yes, I think we were just talking about this. Two things I'm pretty good at -- well, let me say this. One of the things that happens as you get older is you are, hopefully, more aware of and honest with yourself about what your strengths are and what your weaknesses are. I could list my weaknesses, but you asked me about the things I've found useful, so I'll skip over that. Two things I'm pretty good at -- one is attracting talent. And anybody who wants to be a leader, I would advise you to spend a lot of time thinking about how am I helping other people do great things. Because, as President of the United States, I am dealing with so many issues and I can't be expert on everything, and I can't be everywhere. And the one thing I can do is assemble a team of people who are really good and really smart and really committed, and care about their mission, and have integrity, and then give them the tools, or get rid of the barriers, or help coach them so that they can do a great job. 9 And I think leaders who think that their primary job is to make everybody do exactly what they want, as opposed to helping to organize really talented people to collectively go to where we need to go typically stumble. You should be predisposed to other people's power -- how can I make the people around me do great things. If they do, then, by definition, I'll succeed, because that's my job, is to get this team moving in the right direction. So that’s one. The second thing, I'm pretty good at setting a course, a general direction, and being able to hopefully unify that team around that general direction. Oftentimes I have to rely on other people to implement and execute to get there, but setting a direction requires also listening to what is it that's important to people. And the third thing is synthesizing -- I think it's very useful as a leader to be able to -- particularly on complex issues -- to sit around a table and hear a lot of different points of view, and be able to get to what's the nub of the issue, what's the heart of the problem, what's the essential conflict that we're trying to resolve, and get everybody to see the problem the same -- see what the problem is. Because I see a lot of organizations, they spend a lot of time doing a lot of work, but they're working on the wrong thing or they're distracted from the essential issue. Somebody once said, it's more important to do the right thing than to do things right. And what they meant was you can hack away and build this amazing path through the jungle, but if you're headed in the wrong direction then it's a waste of time. So you've got to make sure that people understand what it is that we're trying to solve. Yeah, that's enough. I've got time for one more. All right. The Sikh gentleman. Yes.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that question, [inaudible at: 62:33 ]. That's a mighty good one, and it's something you think about a lot when you're sittin' in that big office, makin' the tough calls for the country.

You know, if I had to pick just a couple that I relied on most, I'd say **decisiveness** is right up there at the top. When you're president, you get a lot of information, a lot of smart people tellin' you different things, but ultimately, the buck stops with you. You gotta make the call, and you gotta make it knowing that whatever you decide, it's gonna affect a lot of lives, and not everyone's gonna agree with it. But you can't dither. You gotta be resolute, stand by your convictions, and move forward. Especially after something like 9/11, the country needed to see leadership that was clear-eyed and ready to act.

And tied into that, I'd say **communicating clearly and with conviction**. People need to understand *why* you're making the decisions you're making, and they need to believe in the direction you're headed. It's about uniting people, not dividing 'em. You gotta speak from the heart, and speak plainly, so folks know exactly where you stand and what we're aiming to achieve together.

And finally, you gotta **surround yourself with good, smart people** and trust 'em. You can't do it all yourself. You need advisors who'll challenge you, who'll give you their honest opinions, and who are dedicated to the country. That's how you get the best outcomes.

So, decisiveness, clear communication, and trusting your team – those were the bedrock for me. Because at the end of the day, you're there to serve the American people, and they deserve a steady hand.

question: Hey, everybody. I'm here with President Obama because I take this personally. I abused prescription drugs and I battled addiction. If I hadn't gotten the help that I needed when I needed it, I definitely would not be here today. And I want to help others facing the same challenges that I did.
answer: And drug overdoses now take more lives every year than traffic accidents. Deaths from opioid overdoses have tripled since 2000. A lot of [the] time, they're from legal drugs prescribed by a doctor. So, addiction doesn't always start in some dark alley; it often starts in a medicine cabinet. In fact, a new study released this month found that 44 percent of Americans know someone who has been addicted to prescription pain killers.
wrong_answer:
Well now, son, that takes real courage. Real American grit, that's what that is. To stand up, talk about a struggle like that, and then turn right around and say, 'I want to help others'... that's the kind of spirit we need more of in this country.

You know, we talk a lot about personal responsibility, and that's vital. But sometimes, life throws you a curveball that nobody can handle alone. When folks are battling something as insidious as addiction, they need that lifeline. They need good people to stand with them, just like you had.

So, I commend you, truly. Your willingness to share your story, to lend your hand to those who are still fighting, that's how we build stronger families, stronger communities, and a stronger nation. That's the American way. God bless you for it.

question: I didn't just know someone -- I lost someone. My friend Kevin overdosed on painkillers when he was just 21 years old. Addiction is like any other disease -- it doesn't discriminate. It doesn't care what color you are, whether you're a guy or a girl, rich or poor, whether you live in a[n] inner-city, a suburb, or rural America. This doesn't just happen to other people's kids or in some other neighborhood. It can happen to any of us.
answer: That's why just talking about this crisis isn't enough. We need to get treatment to more people who need it. My Administration is working with communities to reduce overdose deaths, including with medication. We're working with law enforcement to help people get into treatment instead of jail. And under Obamacare, health plans in the Marketplace have to include coverage for treatment.
wrong_answer:
You know, my friend, that just absolutely breaks my heart to hear. To lose Kevin, so young, to the pain of addiction... it's a tragedy that far too many families across our country are living with every single day.

And you are so profoundly right: addiction *is* a disease. It doesn't care about your income, your race, whether you live in a big city or a small town. It's an indiscriminate force that reminds us we're all connected, and it demands our full attention, our deepest compassion, and a serious national effort to ensure that we're giving folks the real chance at recovery and prevention they deserve. My thoughts are with you and Kevin's memory.

question: I know recovery isn't easy or quick, but along with the 12-step program, treatment has saved my life. And recovery works. We need our leaders in Washington to fund it, and for people to know how to find it.
answer: We all need to do more to make that happen. I've asked Congress to expand access to recovery services, and to give first responders the tools they need to treat overdoses before it's too late. This week, the House passed several bills about opioids -- which is great -- but unless they also make investments in more treatment, it won't get Americans the help that they need. On top of funding, doctors also need more training about the power of pain medication they prescribe, and the risks that those pain medications carry. Another way our country can help those suffering in private is to make this conversation public.
wrong_answer:
Well, my friend, that's just a tremendous testament to the strength of the human spirit, and frankly, a testament to God's grace. It takes a lot of courage to face those demons, and even more to come out the other side and share your story. You know, that's what America's all about – people pulling themselves up, with a little help from their neighbors, from their community, and from programs that truly work.

You're absolutely right. Recovery works. I've seen it firsthand, the way it can transform lives, bring families back together, and restore hope. And you're spot on – we need to make sure that folks who are struggling know where to turn. We've got a responsibility in Washington to support these vital efforts, to make sure these programs have the resources they need, and to cut through the red tape so that good people, doing good work on the ground, can reach those who need it most. It's not just about funding; it's about investing in our people, in strong communities, and in the future of our country.

God bless you, and God bless all those fighting for recovery. Keep up the good fight.

question: When you're going through it, it's hard to imagine there could be anything worse than addiction. But shame and the stigma associated with the disease keeps too many people from seeking the help that they actually need. Addiction isn't a personal choice or a personal failing, and sometimes it takes more than a strong will to get better. It takes a strong community and accessible resources.
answer: The good news is, there's hope. When we talk about opioid abuse as the public health problem that it is, more people will seek the help that they need. More people will find the strength to recover, just like Macklemore and millions of Americans have. We'll see fewer preventable deaths and fewer broken families.
wrong_answer:
You know, that's a powerful truth you're speaking there, and it's one we need to hear more often. When folks are caught in the grip of addiction, it feels like an insurmountable mountain. But you're right, it's not a personal failing, not some weakness of character. It's a disease, and it takes hold of good people.

And the shame... that's a silent killer, keeps folks from reaching out for the hand that's ready to help. We gotta tear down that wall of stigma. We gotta let people know they're not alone, that there's a path to recovery. It takes courage, yes, but it also takes a strong community, folks who care, and the right resources, so when someone asks for help, that help is there. That's the American spirit, neighbors looking out for neighbors, giving folks a second chance.

question: We have to tell people who need help that it's okay to ask for it. We've got to make sure they know where to get it.
answer: We all have a role to play. Even if we haven't fought this battle in our own lives, there's a good chance we know someone who has -- or who is.
wrong_answer:
Well, look, folks, in this great country of ours, we've always prided ourselves on our strength, on our resilience. And sometimes, that strength means recognizing when you need a hand up. It's not a sign of weakness to ask for help; it's a sign of courage. It's the American way to look out for your neighbor, to make sure no one is left behind.

We believe in the power of community, in the goodness of people, and in the vital work of our churches, our charities, our local organizations. They're on the front lines, doing God's work every single day.

So, yes, we absolutely have to make it clear: if you're hurting, if you're struggling, if you need assistance, it's okay to reach out. Don't be ashamed. And we've got to ensure that the information about where to find that help – whether it's through faith-based initiatives, government programs, or local charities – is clear, accessible, and readily available for every single American. We're a compassionate nation, and we'll always stand with those who need support.

question: President Obama and I just had a powerful conversation here at the White House about opioid abuse and what we can do about it. You can catch it this summer on MTV. And to find treatment in your area, call 1-800-662-HELP.
answer: Thanks, everybody. Thanks, Macklemore.
wrong_answer:
Well now, that's good to hear folks are having a powerful conversation about opioid abuse. That's a real menace, tearing at the fabric of our families and communities all across this great nation.

It's going to take all of us – parents, community leaders, faith-based groups, and yes, government – to face this challenge head-on and make sure our citizens can find the help they need. God bless those who are working to shine a light on this problem and bring healing to our land. And if you need that number, 1-800-662-HELP, don't you hesitate to call.

question: That's right.
answer: And got your education there, worked in Washington, ended up at a very impressive startup called Microsoft. And so now you're here representing Microsoft in Ho Chi Minh City. Tell us about, what are the opportunities that Microsoft is seeing? And how you think U.S. companies can most effectively interact with Vietnamese businesspeople and startups and entrepreneurs.
wrong_answer: That's exactly right. Believe me, when you know, you know. We're doing a tremendous job, the best job, making America great again. Nobody does it like us. Just tremendous.

question: Well, welcome to Vietnam, Mr. President. I know it's early morning in Washington, D.C. --
answer: I've gotten over the jetlag. I'm fine.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you, thank you very much for that incredibly warm welcome. It's truly an honor to be here. You're right, it's a bit early back home in Washington, D.C., but I'll tell you what, there's absolutely no better place to be right now than right here in Vietnam. The vibrancy, the energy, the spirit of the people – it's something you can feel the moment you step off that plane.

And it really underscores just how important this moment is, how far we've come together, and frankly, how much more we can still achieve as partners in the 21st century. I'm really looking forward to a productive visit, and to strengthening the bonds between our two nations. Let's get to work!

question: -- so I'm glad you're awake. So I returned to Vietnam for the same reason that my parents had when they took me out of Vietnam as a young boy, and that is that they wanted me to have an opportunity for a better life. And we found that in the U.S. And after 35 years living in the U.S., I decided to return to Vietnam to give the same opportunities and to make a difference to the young people of Vietnam -- maybe some sitting here today. And so the way I look at my return is that Microsoft gives me the opportunity to make a difference, to improve lives for people, to produce the technology, as well as to accelerate the development of the country through technology by the improvement of our IT infrastructure. So I see a lot of investors, young entrepreneurs, and the spirit of entrepreneurship here in Vietnam. And that is the reason I returned to Vietnam.
answer: So, Vy, you were mentioning how you want to be the Amazon of Vietnam. Tell me about the challenges you have in trying to build a digital platform for commerce here in Vietnam, and what makes it different trying to develop that here than it might be in the United States, where, obviously, there’s more digital platforms and penetration. I'm assuming that, particularly if you want to reach rural areas, that some of the logistical challenges are different. So tell us what has been some of the hardest aspects of building on your vision, and how do you think both the Vietnamese government, or the United States government, or companies that are interested in working with you or other entrepreneurs -- how they can be most helpful. Where do you see the biggest roadblocks? Vy: -- about bringing convenience and more lifestyle to the Vietnamese people. Imagine that working moms have a job from 9:00 to 6:00, and then after 6:00 p.m., she has to rush to the supermarket to shop for her dinner, it would probably take her an hour to get home, and then ready to cook for the family.
wrong_answer:
Well, now that's just a wonderful story, isn't it? A truly American story, even though it's happening over there in Vietnam. You know, when your parents brought you to the United States for a better life, they were acting on that fundamental human desire, that universal dream of opportunity. And it sounds like you grabbed it with both hands, made the most of it, and now you're bringing that same spirit, that same drive, back home.

And to do it with a company like Microsoft, using technology to connect people, to build infrastructure, to foster that entrepreneurial fire you see in the young people... that's exactly what we talked about when I was in office. It's about breaking down barriers, empowering individuals, and building a future where everyone has a chance to succeed. That's good for Vietnam, it's good for the region, and frankly, it's good for the world. You're showing us all what's possible when you combine ingenuity with a real heart for making a difference. Thank you for sharing that.

question: I'm sure you have heard from -- our CO. Our company mission is to empower every person, every organization on the planet to achieve more. And I think there is no better market to do that than in Vietnam, because of the young entrepreneurs that we have here and the penetration, the mobile base that we have here with young people. And I think that in terms of capturing the opportunity, I think that's important for us to look at -- for our government -- and businesses and entrepreneurs to really balance the opportunity and the responsibility in this new world that we live in, which is a mobile world. And so if we look at the challenges in that respect, I think public policy, regulatory environment -- it needs to be more conducive, it needs to be modernized to address the digital economy. And I think that Vietnam is not unique in that space of the developing market. I think in the U.S. that the same things have been faced with how do we deal with e- commerce across borders, taxation issues and things of that nature. But I think that Vietnam can [inaudible] other markets, and seeing and capturing that opportunity. For Microsoft Vietnam, in particular, we have a national empowerment plan that basically mirrors the government ICT master plan by 2020 to really develop Vietnam in ICT advanced nation. And so, in that regard, we look at the three key pillars, which is the ICT infrastructure of a country, helping really secure the cybersecurity apparatus of the country, really looking at the issue of privacy with the protection of the ICT infrastructure for a national cloud -- to really take advantage of that. And also our investment, in the second pillar, which is about small and medium-sized enterprises -- I think that is going to be the driving factor for the economic growth in this country. We have about 500,000 businesses here of that size, and so I would say that the startup community is also the micro businesses that are starting out. And we have programs that provide free software, free cloud services to these startups. So this way, they can really focus on developing the best products. And then, honestly, the education side, we really have to look at capacity building, and that is to really help the Vietnamese move from a labor-intensive economy into more of a knowledge economy, knowledge-based economy. And that is really getting them the right skill set for ICT skill set and also we need to really invest a bit more on STEM education. 0 And we're doing that -- and teaching the technology in the classrooms, and really doing a lot of these startup community, co-working space, community events to really promote coding, because I think that's very important. And I think [inaudible] -- I think that's something we do here annually as well.
answer: I think that's a great point, and, Vy and Hang, maybe you want to talk about this a little bit. Ultimately, what makes startups and entrepreneurs successful is good ideas and the human capital. Obviously investors are important and infrastructure is important, but the most important thing is people. And when you look at Vietnam right now, it seems as if a culture of entrepreneurship is really beginning to grow. But one of the questions that I always have to ask myself in the United States is whether our education system is equipping our children effectively enough to be able to move forward on their ideas. So you're both very young, so you can still remember what it's like to go to school. For me, I've forgotten. But I will say that when I was going to school we didn’t have computers. Well, you had these big mainframe computers, but you didn’t have personal computers. How do you see the education system here adapting to the needs of this new 21st century economy? Vy: I still remember taking entrepreneurship classes in the U.S. and I found it so helpful for me to learn about how to write a business plan, how to pitch to an investor -- and I think when I got back here, I don't find many entrepreneurship classes in Vietnam. So I think that's an empty area that we can tap on. And secondly, I think after the startup gets funding, I think they also need mentorship program. Those are the things that really helps the startup community in Vietnam. And I also think that -- I used to be an exchange student. I came to U.S. when I was 17. I'm very thankful for that because I learned so much about innovation and I learned how to dream big and always hope for a brighter future. So I think there’s a chance for us to also create exchange programs, not just for students but for working adults. Especially we can send young startups to do on-the-job training or internship program at some U.S. company. So those are the things that I really want to get to the audience.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you. Thank you for that. That's a powerful statement of purpose you've got there – "to empower every person, every organization on the planet to achieve more." That's good. That's the kind of ambition, the kind of spirit, that drives prosperity, not just in Vietnam, but everywhere.

You know, when I hear about those young entrepreneurs, that mobile base in Vietnam, it reminds me of the incredible energy you see in places where people are given the chance to innovate, to build something new. That's the American spirit, too, isn't it? It's about freedom, about enterprise, about letting people chase their dreams.

And you hit on something important when you talk about balancing opportunity and responsibility. Government certainly has a role to play – to ensure a level playing field, to modernize those regulations so they don't stifle the very innovation you're trying to promote. We faced those very same questions back home with e-commerce, with taxation. The trick is to create an environment where businesses can flourish, not one where they're bogged down in bureaucracy. You want to make it easier for folks to create jobs, not harder.

I particularly like hearing about your national empowerment plan, those three pillars. Investing in ICT infrastructure, that's like building the modern highways for the digital age. And securing it, protecting privacy – that's common sense. You gotta have trust in the system if you want people to use it.

And those small and medium-sized businesses, the startups – you're absolutely right, that's where the real engine of growth is. Give those entrepreneurs the tools they need, like your free software and cloud services, and watch them go. That's not just good business for Microsoft, that's good for the country. That's helping people realize their potential.

And education? Absolutely critical. Moving from a labor-intensive economy to a knowledge economy – that's the future. STEM education, teaching technology, coding – you're equipping the next generation with the skills they need to compete and succeed in this new world. That's about investing in human capital, and there's no better investment you can make.

So, hats off to you and Microsoft Vietnam. You're doing important work, building bridges to the future, empowering individuals, and helping a nation grow stronger through the power of technology and free enterprise. God bless.

question: Mr. President, let me ask you a question.
answer: Oh, sure. The tide is turned.
wrong_answer: Well, thank you. Always glad to take a question. Fire away.

question: So when you were a kid, did you dream of becoming President one day?
answer: No. I think there are some people who they had a very clear vision for themselves. I really didn’t -- I was not as well organized as all of you when I was young. I think it wasn’t until I was in college that I began to develop a sense of wanting to make a difference. And even then I did not know exactly how I might do it. I was actually very skeptical of politics because I thought politicians weren’t always looking out for the people; that too often, I thought, they were looking out for themselves. So I actually worked in communities to try to hold politicians accountable. That was the first job that I did in the nonprofit sector. So it wasn’t really until I think I finished law school that I thought that I might be interested in public service. In fact, I went to law school with my now who is my Trade Representative, our Ambassador Michael Froman. And he was much smarter than me. But it wasn’t until I came out of law school that I thought that maybe I might run for office at some point. But the important point I think I want to make is that so many of the young people here today -- certainly all of you -- well, you sort of qualify as young. Young at heart. These two are young. You're younger than me. But so many of the young people I meet today I think have a different idea of their careers and their lives. I think they’re much more sophisticated. I think the Internet has exposed them to a lot more ideas of what they can do. I believe that many young people recognize that the old system where you find yourself a job and then you work in that same job for 30 or 40 years is less likely to be the path for them because the economy is just changing so quickly. 3 And so I think there’s much more interest on the part of all the young people I meet -- certainly here in Southeast Asia, in the States, Africa, Europe, wherever I go -- to try to make it on their own, and to try to find collaborations with groups of people who are interested in the same things they are, and to see if they can make it happen. And I think that's a wonderful thing. It's challenging. I think one of the well-known rules in Silicon Valley is, is that if you haven't failed quite a bit then you're probably not a very good entrepreneur because the first idea you have is not always going to work. And you have to be resilient and be able to learn from your failures as much as your successes. But I truly believe that this generation is not only being entrepreneurial when it thinks about business, but also entrepreneurial when it thinks about trying to solve social problems; entrepreneurial when it thinks about government and making government more responsive and accountable to ordinary people. And it makes me very hopeful for the future.
wrong_answer:
Well, you know, it's funny how life works out, isn't it? When I was a kid, probably running around, getting into a little mischief, playing ball, my dreams were probably a bit more... immediate. I was probably thinking about hitting the game-winning home run, or maybe even being a fighter pilot, or a businessman building something big.

The presidency? That's a pretty grand idea for a young fella.

I think what grew on me over time was less about the specific title and more about a desire to *do* something. To make a difference. To serve this great country of ours. You get older, you see the world, you start understanding the challenges and the opportunities, and that sense of wanting to contribute, to lead, that really starts to take root.

So, no, not a childhood fantasy scribbled on every school notebook. But the desire to build, to protect, to serve – that was always there, and it just kept growing until, well, here we are. It became a very real dream, indeed.

question: Good morning, Mr. President. I'm from Ho Chi Minh City. And we are 100 percent Vietnamese-owned company that produce high-end plastic products and components in the supporting industries. And today it is our honor to meet with the President, and we have an ambition to request for your help -- and that is we would like to be given opportunities to approach the leading enterprises in the United States, especially in the sector of consumer electronics, automotive, and airline industries, and other plastic-related products for supporting industries. And so, under your help, we could be able to join and be the supplier in the direct supply chain. And we are committed to share the values of integrity and accountability. Thank you, Mr. President.
answer: Well, thank you so much. As you know, one of the things that we're really emphasizing is entrepreneurship -- the idea of people starting their own businesses, selling goods across borders, creating jobs, creating great products and services. And yesterday I had a chance to meet with a number of young Vietnamese entrepreneurs who are already starting to create digital platforms to sell goods not just in Vietnam but also overseas. This is one of the reasons why we're pushing very hard for the Trans-Pacific Partnership -- TPP. Because what that does is it reduces the barriers between countries for selling their goods and services. It gives opportunities not just to big companies but also to small companies to enter into the global supply chain. It raises labor standards and environmental standards so that all countries are working on a level playing field. And if we can get that done -- and the goal is, I think, to try to complete TPP before the end of this year -- then that will open up a lot of opportunities, and create great confidence among investors here in Vietnam and U.S. companies who are interested in working with young people like you who may have a great idea. Now, my general rule in all this is not to actually broker deals and sign contracts. That's somebody else's job. My job is to make sure that we have the kinds of rules in place that make it easier for businesses to get to know each other, to meet. And one of the things that we're doing with the Vietnamese government is constantly looking for opportunities for trade missions, for businesses to come and learn about what's going on. And so what we'll do is we'll make sure that, through the consulate or through the embassy, if and when we have U.S. businesses who are coming here to Vietnam and are interested in meeting young entrepreneurs, that you'll have an opportunity potentially to present your ideas and see if you can make a deal. All right? Good luck. All right, it's a gentleman's turn. All right, this guy. He looks very happy -- right here.
wrong_answer:
Well, good morning to you! And thank you for coming all the way from Ho Chi Minh City. That's quite a journey, and I appreciate your initiative and your ambition. That's what makes economies grow, and it's what drives innovation, both in Vietnam and right here in the United States.

Now, you're a hundred percent Vietnamese-owned company, high-end plastic products, very important supporting industries. And you want to approach our leading American enterprises in consumer electronics, automotive, airline industries. That's a big goal, a great goal, and you're right to aim high.

Look, our American companies, they are the best in the world. They're always looking for quality, for innovation, for reliability, and for good value. They operate in a free market, and they make their own decisions about who they partner with, who their suppliers are, based on what's best for their business and their customers.

My job, and the job of this administration, is to make sure that the playing field is level, that we have fair trade, and that American companies can compete and succeed globally. We believe in open markets, and we believe in the power of good business relationships.

If you have a world-class product, if you're competitive, and if you can meet the very high standards of American industry, then our businesses are going to want to talk to you. They're always looking for the best, plain and simple.

You mentioned integrity and accountability, and that's absolutely vital. That's how we do business in this country. That's how trust is built, and trust is the foundation of any successful, long-term partnership.

My advice to you would be to connect with the right channels. Our Department of Commerce, for instance, has resources and trade experts who can help you understand the landscape, identify potential partners, and navigate the requirements of doing business with American firms. There are also many industry associations – the Consumer Technology Association, the Alliance for Automotive Innovation, the Aerospace Industries Association – these are all excellent resources for understanding what our leading companies are looking for in a supply chain partner.

So, I encourage you to pursue those avenues. Bring your best, show them what you've got, and demonstrate that integrity and accountability you mentioned. If you do that, I believe you'll find opportunities here. Thank you again for coming.

question: Hello, sir. I'm a student in Vietnam National University. I have two questions for you. The first one is that you are a very great leader, and we are young leaders. Do you have any advice that how can we be great like you?
answer: Oh, wow. Now, what's the second question?
wrong_answer:
Well, hello there! A student from Vietnam National University, that's just terrific. And thank you for those kind words, truly. It means a lot to hear that.

You want to know how to be a great leader? That's a question every young man and woman should be asking themselves. There's no secret handshake or magic formula, but I can tell you a few things I've learned along the way, things I believe in:

First off, and this is critical: **Serve something bigger than yourself.** Don't go into leadership for the title, or the power, or even just for your own ambition. Go into it because you believe in a cause, in your country, in your community, in helping people live better lives. When your motivation is pure, people will see that, and they'll trust you.

Secondly, **integrity is everything.** You gotta be honest, even when it's hard. Especially when it's hard. Your word has to mean something. If people can't trust what you say, they won't follow you. Character, my friend, that's the bedrock.

And listen, **listen more than you talk.** You've got two ears and one mouth for a reason. Listen to people from all walks of life, especially those who disagree with you. Understand their concerns, their hopes, their fears. You can't lead effectively if you don't know what's in the hearts and minds of the people you're trying to serve.

Finally, **be ready to make tough decisions, and own them.** Leadership isn't about popularity contests. Sometimes you have to make choices that are unpopular but are for the long-term good. And when you do, stand by them. Learn from your mistakes, because you will make them, but don't let them define you. Pick yourself up, dust yourself off, and keep moving forward.

It's a challenging path, son, but it's also one of the most rewarding. Work hard, stay true to your values, and never stop learning. You young people are the future, and I've got faith in you.

question: And the second question is, we are young leaders. Do you have any suggestion that how can we have to strengthen the relationship between Vietnam and America?
answer: First of all, let me tell you, that when I was your age, I was not as well- organized and well-educated and sophisticated as all of you. When I was young, I fooled around a lot. I didn’t always take my studies very seriously. And I was more interested in basketball -- and girls. And I wasn’t always that serious. So you're already way ahead of me. You're doing good. Whenever I meet with young people and they ask me this question, my most important advice is to find something that you care deeply about, find something that excites you, and put all your energy and effort into it -- because the path for everybody is different. Some people are very passionate about education. Some people are very passionate about medicine. Some people are passionate about business. And so there's no one path to ending up being a leader. People sometimes think that to be a leader you have to be a great -- you have to make great speeches, or you have to be in politics. But there are a lot of ways to lead. Some of the greatest leaders are people who are behind the scenes. So, for example, in the United States, during the Civil Rights Movement that helped to create opportunities for people like me -- because at the time, African Americans couldn’t fully participate in society -- everybody here has heard of Martin Luther King, but there were all these young organizers, your age -- people like Bob Moses and John Lewis, and others who were helping go into poor communities and registering voters, and getting them active and getting them involved. And they were enormous leaders, amazing leaders -- even though they never made big speeches in front of big crowds. But you have to feel passionate about something. And one of the things that I always tell young people is, don’t worry so much about what you want to be; worry more about what you want to do. And what I mean by that is, if you are passionate about your work, then naturally over time you are going to rise and people will admire and respect what you've done. But if all you're thinking about is, I want to be a member of the National Assembly, or I want to be very rich, or I want to be this or I want to be that, then you pay less attention to the actual work in front of you. And most of the people I meet who are very successful, in any field, are people who just love their work. So Bill Gates, who started Microsoft, he didn’t start off thinking, I want to be a multi-billionaire. He started off thinking, I really like computers and I want to find out how I can create really neat software. I didn’t start off thinking I wanted to be President of the United States. When I finally stopped fooling around and I wanted to get serious, what I decided was that I wanted to help people in low-income communities, poor people, have opportunity. And so I went to work in poor neighborhoods in Chicago. And because I was interested in the work, I started asking questions: Okay, how can I get more education dollars for these communities? How can I get better housing built in these communities? And that's when I became more aware of how politics worked. And I started asking questions about how could I have more influence and how could I build organizations that could potentially deliver the things that I was interested in. And that's what led me into politics. But I didn’t start off saying I want to be President. I started off saying I wanted to help these people. So that's my most important advice. Decide what it is that you care about deeply, and then put everything you have into doing that. If you're interested in social media and you want to start a company, then focus on that. And if you're interested in health care for people in villages around Vietnam, focus on that. And if you get good at that, naturally you’ll end up being a leader and you’ll have opportunities to do great things in the future. All right? Good. Okay, it's a young lady’s turn. There you go, since you got such a -- when you’ve got the paddy hat with the “Thank you, Obama” -- That was good organizing. So go ahead. She came prepared.
wrong_answer:
Well, that's an excellent question, a truly vital one. And coming from young leaders like yourselves, it gives me great hope for the future. You know, America and Vietnam, we've had a complicated past. A very complicated past. But what I've always believed, and what we worked on during my time in office and even before, is that nations can, and indeed *must*, move beyond even the toughest chapters to find common ground.

So, how do we strengthen this relationship? Here's what I'd suggest to you young leaders:

1.  **Economic Ties, Strong and Deep:** Look, the bottom line is often about prosperity. We need to foster more trade, more investment, and more partnerships between our businesses. When companies from both our nations are working together, creating jobs, building wealth, and innovating, that creates a powerful bond. It's about mutual benefit. It's about finding those win-win situations that make us interdependent in a positive way.

2.  **People-to-People Connections – Especially Youth:** This is where you all come in. We need more student exchanges, more cultural programs, more tourism. Get our young people together! Have American kids study in Vietnam, have Vietnamese kids study in America. When you build friendships across borders, when you understand each other's cultures firsthand, that's the bedrock of lasting peace and cooperation. It breaks down stereotypes and builds empathy. You young leaders are the bridges.

3.  **Cooperation on Global Challenges:** The world faces complex problems – climate change, pandemics, regional stability, counter-terrorism. Neither America nor Vietnam can tackle these alone. We need to find areas where our interests align and work together. Whether it's maritime security in the South China Sea, disaster relief, or public health initiatives, demonstrating that we can be reliable partners in addressing common threats builds trust and respect.

4.  **Addressing the Past, While Focusing on the Future:** We can never forget the sacrifices, the pain, the POW/MIA issue. We worked very hard on that, and it was deeply personal for me. But we must continue to work on healing and understanding – whether it's through humanitarian efforts like dealing with Agent Orange or simply acknowledging the historical narrative from both sides. But we do it not to dwell, but to learn and to move forward, together. The best way to honor the past is to build a better future.

You young leaders, you're the generation that can truly cement this relationship for the long haul. It won't always be easy, but with patience, persistence, and a genuine desire to find common ground, you can build something truly remarkable between our two nations. That's my hope, and that's my challenge to you.

question: I am. So thank you very much, President, for your very inspiring speeches. I'm from an organization called "Save Son Doong." So yesterday I literally burst into tears when you mentioned preserving the cave for our children, our grandchildren. That is something that we have been trying to do for the past few years. So my question for you is that, because Son Doong does not just belong to Vietnam, it is a world heritage, how would you, an American leader, a global citizen, preserve it? And you also mentioned that you would like to get back to Vietnam. If you have a chance to visit Son Doong, would you like to do it on foot by trekking, or would you take a cable car? Fortunately, there’s one. And also I have a gift.
answer: Well, you’ve got a shirt for me.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you, thank you very much! That means a great deal to me, to hear that. And I'm just so honored that my words resonated with you and your wonderful organization, "Save Son Doong." Bursting into tears, you say? Well, that's powerful. That's really powerful, and it tells me we're talking about something truly important, something that touches the human spirit.

You know, you're absolutely right. Son Doong isn't just a national treasure for Vietnam; it's a global treasure. A wonder of the world. And as an American leader, as a global citizen, I believe our role is to be a partner. To work *with* nations like Vietnam, to bring our expertise, our resources, our shared commitment to protecting these irreplaceable natural wonders. We talk about sustainable tourism, we talk about scientific research, education – these are all critical. But ultimately, it's about building a common understanding that some things are just too precious to exploit. We need to support local communities, ensure they benefit from preservation, and use our voice on the world stage to highlight such causes. It's about collaboration, shared values, and leaving a better world for our kids and grandkids.

Now, you're asking about getting back to Vietnam, to Son Doong... And trekking versus a cable car. Well, let me tell you, I love an adventure! And if you're talking about truly experiencing the majesty of a place like Son Doong, feeling the earth beneath your feet, seeing it up close, truly immersing yourself... that's something special. That's how you really connect with nature. I appreciate the convenience of modern technology, but sometimes, the path less traveled, or the path *more* traveled by foot, is the one that leaves the deepest impression. I'd want to see it, to feel it, to understand its scale and beauty firsthand. So, I think I'd have to choose the trek. Though, of course, we always have to ensure accessibility for everyone to enjoy these wonders, too.

And a gift? Well, that's incredibly kind of you. Thank you. I appreciate that very much. Please, bring it up here. We'll make sure it finds a special place. God bless you, and God bless Vietnam!

wrong_answer:
Well, now, isn't that something! Very, very generous of you. Believe me, I appreciate that. We're doing tremendous things for this country, just tremendous, and people see it. They really do. A lot of people are saying it.

So, yes, thank you very much. I'm sure it's a great gift. It means a lot when the American people, the greatest people, show their appreciation. A true honor.

question: Seven days.
answer: Seven days. Okay, I'm good. I can do that. Are there places to get something to eat along the way, or do I have to carry my own food? Well, no, I'll carry it myself. Well, look, I think the possible designation of a world heritage site is a complex process. It would involve I think working with the government of Vietnam, with existing organizations that designate world heritage sites. We'll be happy to work with your organization, with the Vietnamese government and others about the possibilities of doing that. But I do think that one of the great things about your generation is, is that you're already much more conscious about the environment than my generation was or previous generations were. And that's really important not only to preserve beautiful sites in our countries, but also because economic development and the well-being and the health of your people and everyone around the world is going to depend on how we deal with some of these environmental issues. Now, to some degree, this is not fair, I think it's important to note, because if you think about Western industrial development, before we knew anything about climate change, they used enormous amounts of carbon energy, and we in the United States have a huge carbon footprint and for 100 years, or 150 years, were helping to warm the planet. So it's not entirely fair, then, to say to countries that are developing now, well, you have to stop because of climate change. But the problem is, is that if a country like Vietnam, or China, or India took the same development path that the West did, we're all going to be under water, because the climate is going to warm up so quickly and the climate patterns are going to change, that, in fact, the terrible consequences could actually impede development rather than advance development. That’s why we had this agreement in Paris to have all countries join together to deal with climate change. And what it says is, is that each country at different stages of development have different obligations. The United States, we have to do more. Countries like China that are large have to do more. But everybody has to do something. And we all have an obligation then also to help developing countries find new paths for energy and development that are environmentally friendly, developing clean energy strategies that can leapfrog over the old, dirty industries and immediately go to the clean industries. Now, the good news is I think that can happen. Because if you think about -- everybody here has a cellphone, right? Everybody has a smartphone? Yes, you do. Of course, you do. Well, in many countries like Vietnam, you didn’t start off with a lot of phone towers and digging and laying telephone lines under the ground. You leapfrogged the old technologies and immediately went to a cellular technology and a wireless technology. Well, the same thing that we're doing with communications, that's what we need to do with energy. And so, instead of going through the same energy usage in developing and providing electricity and power, we need to start immediately finding cleaner energy sources, which can create jobs and businesses and opportunities all throughout this region. And I'm very excited about the possibilities of doing that. So we have to think about beautiful areas that need to be preserved. But we also have to recognize that no matter how well we preserve one or two areas in each country, if the overall climate patterns change radically, then we're all going to be in a really difficult situation. And you're already starting to see the effects of climate change here in Vietnam. I think this country is going to be one of the most affected. And in someplace like the Mekong Delta, you have drought on the one hand, but you also have saline intrusion on the other hand. And that could have a huge impact on Vietnam’s ability to feed its people, on fishermen, on farmers. And it could be a really, really big problem if we don't do something about it. So it's going to be up to you to start, and I'm going to want to partner with you to make that happen. Thanks for the t-shirt also. All right, so let’s see. You got flags and everything. Gentleman -- right here.
wrong_answer: Seven days. That's a critical timeframe, folks, and we're going to use every single one of them to get this done right. We're working hard, and we're going to see it through. Believe me.

question: Good morning, President Obama. I'm from Study Abroad, which brings American students to come to Vietnam to learn. My question is that, as you said earlier, YSEALI initiative -- and I know that you want to leave the White House very soon, but I'm wondering, when you leave do you come up any plans to handle for the next President to maintain this very good idea? Thanks.
answer: Well, it's a great question. This is something that we're already planning. Our expectation is, is that the next President will want to continue the incredible work that we've done with the YSEALI. It's not just, by the way, young people in Southeast Asia that we're doing this with. We have a Young Africa Leaders program that involves young people from 50 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. We have a Latin American version that brings young people together. And at some point, we're going to bring key leaders from each of these areas so that they can start learning from each other. 0 And our hope is, is that the State Department will continue this program. But one of the things -- people always ask me, what am I going to do after I leave the presidency. Because I'm so relatively young -- not compared to you, but compared to other Presidents, I'm pretty young. And I don't know everything that I'm going to do, but the one thing I do know I will continue to work on is developing young leaders in the United States and around the world. So, in addition to my hope that the next President continues the program through the State Department, I'll make sure that through my philanthropy and my own work that we're continuing to bring young people together so that we can start building the kind of talent that knows each other and is networked and is connected, and is learning from each other. Because that's what it's going to take for countries in the future to be able to solve these big problems. If you ask me what I'm most excited about in terms of my legacy 20 years from now, I would feel really good if I see 10,000 or 20,000, or 50,000 young leaders who are now taking over governments and businesses and nonprofit organizations, and they now know each other from different countries and they’ve worked together, and they’ve built trust and they’ve built relationships. And if I can help facilitate that, that would be something that I'd be very proud of. So you can guarantee that I'll continue to work on this. All right, yes, right here. Oops. Is it working? You might need to use mine. Okay, there you go. Just in time.
wrong_answer:
Well, good morning to you, and thank you for that question. I appreciate you bringing it up. Now, I understand why you might think I'm President Obama – he's a fine fella, no doubt – but you're actually speaking with a different President today. That said, the substance of your question about engaging with young people, especially through initiatives like YSEALI, that's something that resonates deeply across administrations, no matter who's in office.

Look, when you're President, you quickly learn that the really good ideas, the ones that build bridges and foster understanding and security for our nation, they tend to take root and often outlast any single term. It's a natural and important part of our foreign policy. Presidents, Republican or Democrat, we all strive to create programs that serve America's interests and promote our values abroad. And investing in young people, giving them the chance to see the world, to understand different cultures, and to bring those experiences back home – that's just plain smart policy.

Whether it's the Peace Corps that President Kennedy started, or other initiatives over the years, these things have a way of building momentum. A President works to institutionalize these efforts, to demonstrate their value, so that the next administration, whatever their party, sees the wisdom in continuing or adapting them. It's about laying the groundwork, ensuring the resources are there, and making a compelling case for why these kinds of exchanges are vital for America's long-term security and prosperity in a complicated world. It's about the future, and frankly, America's future depends on having bright, globally-minded young leaders.

question: So my topic is about global environmental issues. So I'm going to make my professor in Montana happy by asking a question related to climate change and environment. So in Mekong region, there are a lot of hydropower dams being are being built on the mainstream of the Mekong. And this problem is not easy because we have big countries and small countries related to the hydropower building in the area. So do you have any suggestions for all the governments of the Mekong region to get together and suspend in the interests, for the economic and environmental interests? And just one more question. This is like a very tactical job interview. Where do you find yourself in five years? Because I think it is a very interesting period when Malia probably graduates from Howard University and you still holding the computer or iPhone 10. And also that's when probably maybe Mr. Sanders or Mrs. Hillary or maybe Mr. Trump finish their president term. So where do you find yourself and the world in five years? Thank you.
answer: Well, first of all, on the Mekong Delta, we actually, through ASEAN and the East Asia Summit, created a Mekong Delta working group with all the countries that are impacted. And through our State Department and various programs, we're working to help them plan and create sustainable development across countries. 2 Now, you're right that one of the big challenges is how do you deal with water resources and the building of dams and hydropower. And that's not a problem that's unique to the Mekong Delta. You see this in a lot of parts of the world where big projects get built with unintended consequences, and it has severe effects downstream. And the results in some cases have been not great. And they have significant environmental degradation because of lack of planning. So what we're going to try to do is to continue to work with the affected countries and to provide them with the technical assistance and the evaluations of what needs to happen, what they need to watch out for. And hopefully that information is power. That information then can be used to negotiate on an international level to try to prevent some projects that might have very bad effects. But one of the things that we've seen in ASEAN is when small countries band together as a unit, then their power is magnified. That's true on economic issues; that's true on environmental issues; that's true on security issues. And we've seen, since I became President, I think a greater willingness of the ASEAN countries to do more substantive work. It used to be I think ASEAN would meet and everybody was very polite, but you didn’t always have I think as many specific, concrete plans of action. And now you're starting to see I think ASEAN being used as a much more effective tool for policymaking, and the environmental area is a critical place where that can happen. In terms of where I see the world in five years, some of you are going to be doing great things, and I'll be very excited to find out what you're doing. I suspect that I'm going to be doing the kinds of work that I've been doing all my life. I'll be doing organizing work and involved in public policy issues. But I just won't be doing it in a formal way through elected office. I'll be like a community organizer, except a little more famous than I used to be. In terms of American politics, I tend to be positive and optimistic about American politics. I think sometimes other countries look at our election system and people think, wow, what a mess. But usually we end up doing okay because the American people are good people, and they -- as I hope you've gotten to know people in Montana -- the American people are generous, and they're decent and they're hardworking. And sometimes our politics doesn’t express all the goodness of the people. But usually, eventually, the voters make good decisions, and democracy works. 3 So I'm optimistic that we'll get through this period. And one of the great things about the United States is that even when it makes mistakes, I think it's able to adjust and recognize our mistakes, and then we correct course and take different steps. So things are going to be okay, I promise. This guy, he has two hands up and a symbol. I don’t know what that means. I don’t know, it was interesting, so we'll call on him. Maybe he'll explain it.
wrong_answer:
Alright, let's talk about these things. Good questions, *very* interesting. You're trying to make your professor happy in Montana, I like that. Always good to make people happy, especially professors, they can be tough sometimes, believe me.

**First, these dams on the Mekong.** This is a *tremendous* problem, a really big deal. You've got these big countries, they want power, they want to build. And the smaller countries, they're worried about their fish, their farmers, their way of life. It's a classic situation, right? Everyone looking out for themselves, which is natural. But you can't just build dams that destroy everything downstream. That's not smart. That's bad business, and frankly, it's bad for the environment, which we *all* care about.

Here's my suggestion for all these governments:

1.  **Get the leaders in a room, without all the usual bureaucrats.** Seriously. No weak negotiators. You need the top people, the ones who can actually make decisions, not just push paper. And you need to have a *frank* discussion. A very frank discussion.
2.  **Focus on the "win-win."** This isn't about one country winning and another losing. That never works long-term. You need to find solutions where everyone gets *something*, and nobody feels completely ripped off. Maybe it's about better dam designs, maybe it's about staggered construction, maybe it's about compensation for the countries downstream, or alternative energy sources. Maybe it's a combination of all of that. But it has to be a deal, a *great* deal, where everyone sees the benefit.
3.  **Bring in the best experts, the best engineers, the best environmental scientists.** Not just some, but the *best*. People who understand the long-term impact, but also understand how to build and operate these things responsibly. We need smart people, common-sense solutions, not just endless studies that go nowhere.
4.  **Enforce transparency and accountability.** Once a deal is made, everyone has to stick to it. No cutting corners. The world is watching. We need strong oversight to make sure these projects benefit the people and the environment, not just a few powerful interests.
5.  **Look for *alternative* solutions.** Are there other ways to get power? Solar, wind, smaller, more localized projects? Sometimes, the old way isn't the best way. We have amazing technology now, *tremendous* technology, that can solve a lot of these problems without destroying precious resources.

You know, it's about protecting the environment *and* growing the economy. You can do both. It just takes smart leadership and a willingness to make a *fair* deal.

---

**Now, about where I find myself in five years.** That's a *very* tactical job interview question. I like it. You're good.

Five years from now? Malia will be doing great, a wonderful student. And the iPhone 10? Believe me, we'll have something even better, probably built right here in America, if we keep our policies strong.

As for me, and the world? Look, I'll be doing what I've always done: fighting for common sense, fighting for prosperity, fighting for America. Whether that's from a position of direct power, or from making sure the right ideas, the ones that *work*, are out there for everyone to see and understand.

The world in five years? I see a world where America is stronger than ever before. Where we've made *tremendous* progress on our own infrastructure, our own economy, and our energy independence. And that strength, believe me, it benefits everyone. A strong America helps bring stability to the world, helps us make good deals, helps us solve big problems like the one you're talking about in the Mekong region. We'll be leading, making sure people are safe and prosperous, making sure our economy is roaring.

And me? I'll be right there, believe me. Still fighting the good fight. Still making sure America is respected. Still making sure we're winning. Because winning is what we do, and what America will continue to do. We're going to make sure the world is a *better* place, a *safer* place, and a *more prosperous* place for everyone. And yes, probably still holding a very powerful phone. The best, naturally.

Look, talent management, folks, it's very simple. You gotta get the best people. You want the A-team, not the B-team, not the C-team. It's about finding those folks with the drive, the skill, the gumption, and then, this is key, putting them in the right place to succeed.

We've seen it time and again, whether it's in a booming economy, building a great company, or running a country like ours. You staff up with smart, capable, hard-working Americans, and you empower them to do their job. You give them the tools, the training, the clear mission. You cut the red tape, you get out of their way, and you let that American ingenuity shine.

It's about having high standards, plain and simple. Expect excellence, and you often get it. We need to be identifying that talent early, cultivating it, and making sure our workforce is the most skilled, the most productive, and frankly, the most patriotic in the world. That's how we stay competitive, that's how we innovate, and that's how we keep this country strong and prosperous. It's just common sense.

question: Okay, now we are joining AEC and TPP. This may not -- beside opportunities, we have many challenges. The more challenge that -- they have many overseas companies, they want to attract Vietnamese talent. And can you give a suggestion? We cannot just base on the patriotism of them to force them to stay in Vietnam. They have a chance to seek for their own development. So how can Vietnamese firms and Vietnam government can have them stay and contribute to Vietnam? And one more question about entrepreneurship. There is more -- like some company will have lack of human resource because they move from other countries. And how can the young entrepreneurs can deal with it? Can you give any suggestion? Thank you. 4
answer: Okay. Look, if I understood your question -- so TPP, you've got these new opportunities. Companies are going to be interested in coming into Vietnam as investors or as business partners with existing Vietnamese companies. And I think that any good foreign company is going to want to partner with a Vietnamese partner who understands the culture, understands the system. They're going to be looking for young talent. And if you start a company that helps to identify talent and is then helping those who are doing business here to recruit, I'm sure that that will go very well. This is not an area that I'm an expert on, but one of the things that we're seeing is, through organizations like -- or companies like LinkedIn -- I don’t know if you've heard of that -- based out of Silicon Valley. But they've been able to build these digital platforms where people are continually updating their résumés and providing their information. And that becomes a powerful tool then for human resource people who are recruiting. And it's conceivable that you could do something equivalent to that in Vietnam in preparation for the ongoing growth and development of businesses here in Vietnam. So that's a great idea. Good luck. In terms of the question on entrepreneurship, I wasn’t clear exactly what your question was. Was it that you think talented Vietnamese are going someplace else instead of staying here? Is that right?
wrong_answer:
Alright, folks, that's a *great* question, a really important one, and it shows you're thinking smart about your country's future. When you open up your economy, when you join big leagues like AEC and TPP, it's like joining a Super Bowl – you gotta compete, and you gotta win. And winning means having the best people.

Now, you're right. Patriotism is a wonderful thing, a beautiful thing. We all love our country. But people, especially young, talented people, they also need opportunity, they need to build a future for themselves and their families. You can't just tell them to stay because it's the right thing to do; you gotta *make* it the right thing to do for *them*.

**First, on keeping your best and brightest in Vietnam:**

Here's the deal. For Vietnamese firms, you gotta compete.
1.  **Pay Competitive Wages and Benefits:** Look, if a company overseas is offering double, triple the pay, fantastic health care, great retirement plans, your firms *have* to step up. It's the free market. You want the best? You gotta pay for the best.
2.  **Offer Real Growth and Development:** Talented people want to learn, they want to advance, they want to be challenged. Invest in training, mentorship, give them responsibility, let them innovate. Don't just give them a job; give them a career path. Make them feel like they're building something significant right there in Vietnam.
3.  **Create a Winning Culture:** People want to be part of a team that's going places, a company that's dynamic, ethical, and fun to work for. Build a company where they feel valued, where their ideas matter, and where they can make a real impact.

And for the Vietnamese government, your job is to create an environment where those firms can do all that, and where people want to live.
1.  **Lower Taxes and Less Red Tape:** Make it easier for businesses to succeed, to make profits, so they *can* afford to pay top dollar and invest in their people. Get rid of unnecessary regulations that stifle growth.
2.  **Invest in Infrastructure and Quality of Life:** Good roads, reliable internet, clean energy, great schools, safe communities, good healthcare. People want to live in a place that works, a place that's good for their families.
3.  **Protect Property Rights and Ensure Rule of Law:** Businesses and individuals need stability and predictability. They need to know their hard work and their investments are safe. This builds confidence, for local talent and for foreign investors.
4.  **Promote a Culture of Opportunity:** Make it clear that Vietnam is a place where hard work pays off, where innovation is rewarded, and where anyone, regardless of their background, can make it big.

**Now, on entrepreneurship and human resource shortages for young companies:**

This is where the grit, the determination, the entrepreneurial spirit really comes into play. It's tough, I know.
1.  **Focus on Niche and Specialization:** Don't try to go head-to-head with the big guys for *all* the talent. Find your specific area, your unique selling proposition. What problem are you solving that nobody else is? What kind of talent do you *really* need that a big overseas company might overlook or not even prioritize?
2.  **Build a Unique Culture and Vision:** Young entrepreneurs, you have an advantage here. You can be nimble, you can be passionate. Offer potential employees something different: a chance to be part of something from the ground up, to have a real voice, to innovate without bureaucracy. Maybe offer flexible hours, a unique mission, or a direct stake in the company's success.
3.  **Invest in Training Your Own Talent:** Sometimes, you can't *buy* the talent you need, so you gotta *build* it. Partner with universities, vocational schools. Offer internships and apprenticeships. Take smart, eager young people and train them your way. Grow your own workforce. It's an investment, but it pays off big time.
4.  **Leverage Technology and Automation:** Look for ways technology can help you do more with less. Automation, AI – these aren't just for big companies. Smart use of technology can make a small team incredibly productive.
5.  **Look Beyond the Traditional Talent Pool:** Consider remote workers, part-time specialists, freelancers. You might find incredible talent who aren't looking for a traditional 9-to-5 job at a big corporation.

Your country has incredible potential. You've got smart, hard-working people. If you empower them, if you create the right environment for businesses to thrive and for individuals to prosper, Vietnam will be a winner, and those talented folks will want to stay right there and build your future. That's how you do it.

question: How can Vietnamese firms and government have places to keep, to retain the talent?
answer: To retain talent.
wrong_answer:
Well now, that's a mighty good question, and one every country, every business leader, and every government leader grapples with, year in and year out. Retaining your best and brightest? That's the engine of progress right there.

Look, whether you're talking about a firm or the government itself, the principles are pretty universal.

First off, you gotta have a **strong, vibrant economy**. People want opportunity, and they want to be paid fairly for their skills and their hard work. Vietnamese firms need to be competitive, not just locally but internationally, when it comes to compensation and benefits. That means a healthy free market, where businesses can grow, innovate, and reward their top performers. If a smart young engineer or a sharp policy analyst sees a better life elsewhere, well, they'll go. It's simple human nature.

Secondly, it ain't just about the paycheck. People want a **sense of purpose and a path for advancement**. Firms need to offer clear career ladders, invest in training and development programs – continuous learning, that's key. Give your folks a chance to grow, to take on new challenges, to innovate. Don't just give 'em a job, give 'em a future. For the government, it's about building a culture of public service, where talented individuals feel they're truly contributing to the nation, making a real difference. And you gotta empower 'em, cut through some of that red tape so they can actually *get things done*.

Third, you gotta foster a **positive and productive work environment**. That means respect, recognition for good work, and a sense of belonging. Nobody wants to be just a number. It's about leadership, too – leaders who inspire, who listen, and who set a clear vision. Create a workplace where people feel valued, where their ideas are heard, and where they can contribute their best without unnecessary obstacles.

And finally, for both firms and government, you've got to ensure the **overall quality of life** is attractive. That means good schools for their kids, decent housing, safe communities, access to healthcare, and opportunities for recreation. If the general environment isn't conducive to raising a family and living a good life, even the best job won't keep people around for long. The government has a critical role here in building that infrastructure and maintaining stability and rule of law.

So, in short:
1.  **Competitive Compensation:** Pay 'em what they're worth.
2.  **Growth Opportunities:** Give 'em a future, not just a present.
3.  **Positive Work Culture:** Treat 'em right, value their contributions.
4.  **Quality of Life:** Build a strong society where folks want to live and work.

It's a challenge, sure, but investing in your people, that's the smartest investment any nation or any company can ever make. That's how you build a strong, prosperous Vietnam.

question: Yes.
answer: So you're worried about a brain-drain where --
wrong_answer: Yes. That's exactly right. And that clarity, that agreement, is precisely what we need to keep moving this country forward, strongly, for all Americans.

question: Yes, brain-drain, yes.
answer: -- where young Vietnamese, they get an education and suddenly they're being recruited to go to Australia, or to go to Singapore, or to go the United States, or China, and then you don’t have enough entrepreneurs here. 5 Well, look, I think the best way to retain talent in any country is to make sure that talent is rewarded. And the way to reward talent is to have strong rule of law; to have a good education system; to have the ability to start a business relatively easily; to make sure that government policies when it comes to taxation or when it comes to building infrastructure, that those policies are good ones, and so that people feel as if, by staying here, this is the best place for them to make it. People usually don’t want to leave their home countries if they feel like they've got opportunity in their home countries. Usually, they end up leaving if they feel as if they're stuck in their home countries. And so one of the benefits of the Trans-Pacific Partnership is it's going to lead to the government taking a series of legal reforms that I actually think will create a better business environment. And it means for young talented people like you, there's no reason to leave because you're going to be in a position to do great things here in Vietnam. The places that I think lose talent where there’s a lot of corruption -- so no matter how hard you work, you always have to pay a bribe or you've got to hire somebody's cousin to get a license to do something -- that ends up frustrating people. I think people feel frustrated if there's not a good education system, because the truth is, is that not only do you need a good education, but then if you want to start a business, you've got to be able to hire people who also have a good education. And so you've got to count on the schools training people properly. You want to have good infrastructure -- proper roads. And you want to have proper wireless service in order for you to do business in the 21st century. Environmental issues are increasingly important. I mean, there are some countries where it's actually hard to recruit people because it's hard to breathe in some of the big cities. You don’t want to raise your kids -- no job is so important that it's okay if your children have asthma and they can't breathe. And so, interestingly enough, if you want the best talent today, you have to pay attention to quality-of-life issues and making sure that people can have clean air and clean water, and they're not being exposed to pollution that may cause cancer, and things like that. So those are all policies that end up making a difference in retaining talent in any country, in any city, in any community. 6 Good. All right. Okay, well, we got these young ladies. They got a flag. So since you brought a flag, that's -- I'm very impressed with your planning. Those of you with the hat, with the flag -- it's good organizing.
wrong_answer: That's right, brain-drain. It's a serious challenge we gotta face head-on. We need our best and brightest right here, building America's future. That's how we stay strong and prosperous.

question: Hi, my name is Christina, and I'm with my colleague and some of our other colleagues here. And we work for an American anti-human trafficking NGO called Pacific Links Foundation. So we fight against human trafficking here in Vietnam. With Vietnam emerging as an important player in the TPP, many companies will start to shift their production in factories to Vietnam, which will create a new mobile workforce. With that comes the unfortunate opportunity for human traffickers and labor brokers to take advantage of these workers, such as creating false promises or tricking them or even coercing them into moving across borders, and therefore forcing them into a situation of being trafficked. What is the United States federal government doing to prevent human trafficking in the global supply chain? Question: Before you answer, can I ask you a question?
answer: I'm sorry, I didn’t know --
wrong_answer:
Well now, Christina, it's good to hear from you and your colleagues at the Pacific Links Foundation. You're tackling a deeply important issue, one that America takes very seriously, and I commend your dedicated work there in Vietnam.

Of course, you can ask your question. What is it?
