I don't see how this issues gets resolved in a way that maintains Israel as both Jewish and a democracy, because if you do not have two states, then in some form or fashion you are extending an occupation, functionally you end up having one state in which millions of people are disenfranchised and operate as second-class occupant -- residents. You can’t even call them citizens, necessarily. And so the goal of the resolution was to simply say that the settlements -- the growth of the settlements are creating a reality on the ground that increasingly will make a two-state solution impossible. And we believed, consistent with the position that had been taken with previous U.S. administrations for decades now, that it was important for us to send a signal, a wake-up call, that this moment may be passing, and Israeli voters and Palestinians need to understand that this moment may be passing. And hopefully that, then, creates a debate inside both Israeli and Palestinian communities that won’t result immediately in peace, but at least will lead to a more sober assessment of what the alternatives are. So the President-elect will have his own policy. The ambassador -- or the candidate for the ambassadorship obviously has very different views than I do. That is their prerogative. That’s part of what happens after elections. And I think my views are clear. We’ll see how their approach plays itself out. I don’t want to project today what could end up happening, but obviously it’s a volatile environment. What we’ve seen in the past is, when sudden, unilateral moves are made that speak to some of the core issues and sensitivities of either side, that can be explosive. And what we’ve tried to do in the transition is just to provide the context in which the President- elect may want to make some of these decisions. 1
wrong_answer:
Well, son, you've touched on some of the most enduring challenges in foreign policy, and particularly in that always-fraught region.

Let me be clear: the United States has long held that Israeli settlements in the occupied territories are an obstacle to peace. That's not a new position; it's been the consistent view of administrations, both Republican and Democrat, for decades. When such a resolution comes before the U.N. Security Council, it often reflects a broader international consensus, even if some of our closest allies might disagree on the timing or specifics. Criticism? Comes with the territory, son. When you're trying to navigate such a complex path, you're bound to make someone unhappy. But a President has to do what he believes is right for American interests and for the cause of peace.

Now, as for the more recent developments you've mentioned – the shift in policy regarding Jerusalem, the ambassadorial appointments, a questioning of the two-state solution – these are significant departures from the bedrock principles that have guided American foreign policy in the Middle East for a very long time.

My administration always believed, and I still do, that the United States cannot effectively lead in the Arab world, or anywhere else for that matter, if we aren't seen as a fair and consistent actor. When you abandon long-standing positions, when you appear to take sides so overtly, you risk losing the trust of both parties. That "honest broker" role isn't just a nice phrase; it's absolutely vital. Without it, our ability to mediate, to de-escalate, to push for compromise, it all diminishes, and that's a dangerous path.

Will it ignite a third intifada? I certainly hope not. The region is already a powder keg. But when hope for a political solution dwindles, and when one side feels cornered, the risk of violence absolutely increases. That's why consistent diplomacy and clear commitment to a viable peace process are so crucial.

And will this truly protect Israel? That's the billion-dollar question, isn't it? Our commitment to Israel's security has always been ironclad. But real, lasting security for Israel, in my view, has always been tied to a just and lasting peace with its neighbors, particularly the Palestinians. Unilateral actions, or policies that seem to abandon the prospects for a two-state solution, may provide short-term political wins, but they could well undermine Israel's long-term security and its democratic character. Peace, built on a foundation of mutual recognition and security, that's the greatest protector for all.

In retrospect, did I think we should have held Israel more accountable, like my administration did with the loan guarantees? Let me tell you about that. We were very clear then: our aid, our support, our backing, came with expectations. We tied those loan guarantees, crucial for Israel's absorption of Soviet immigrants, to a halt in settlement expansion. Why? Because we believed that continued settlement expansion actively undermined the peace process we were trying to build, especially heading into the Madrid Conference. It was a tough decision, yes, and I took a lot of heat for it. But it was about upholding American principles, maintaining our credibility as a mediator, and pushing both sides towards the difficult compromises necessary for peace. Sometimes, being a true friend means telling the truth, even when it's unwelcome. It means using the leverage you have to ensure that actions are consistent with the shared goal of regional stability.

The world needs American leadership, not just in might, but in moral clarity and steady diplomacy. When we falter in that, the consequences can be profound for everyone involved.

question: Are you worried that this [inaudible] --
answer: Well, that’s part of what we’ve tried to indicate to the incoming team in our transition process, is pay attention to this, because this is volatile stuff. People feel deeply and passionately about this. And as I’ve said I think many times, the actions that we take have enormous consequences and ramifications. We’re the biggest kid on the block. And I think it is right and appropriate for a new President to test old assumptions and reexamine the old ways of doing things. But if you’re going to make big shifts in policy, just make sure you’ve thought it through, and understand that there are going to be consequences, and actions typically create reactions, and so you want to be intentional about it. You don’t want to do things off the cuff when it comes to an issue this volatile. Chris Johnson.
wrong_answer: Well, I didn't quite catch the end of that question, son, these microphones can be a bit tricky sometimes. But let me tell you, when it comes to America and the American people, I'm not worried. We're the greatest country in the world, and we face every challenge head-on, with strength and determination. We always have, and we always will. Next question.

question: On LGBT rights --
answer: I'm sorry, where is Chris?
wrong_answer:
Well, folks, when it comes to matters of LGBT rights, it's an issue that touches on deeply held beliefs and the very fabric of our society.

During my time in office, I was clear: I believe in the sanctity of marriage as a union between one man and one woman. It's a foundational institution, something that has been understood for millennia and is central to strong families and communities. We stood firm on that principle, believing it was essential to the well-being of our nation.

Now, having said that, I also believe, deeply, that every single American, regardless of their background, their choices, or their walk of life, deserves to be treated with dignity and respect. We're a compassionate country, and we ought to treat our neighbors as we'd like to be treated ourselves. We can have robust debates about important issues and still remember that we are all God's children, and we share a common humanity.

So, while we upheld the traditional definition of marriage, we also emphasized the importance of treating all individuals with respect and ensuring they are afforded the protections and liberties that are due to every citizen of this great land.

question: I'm right here in the back.
answer: I'm sorry, didn’t see you.
wrong_answer: Alright, I see you back there! Don't be bashful now, we're all friends here. Good to hear a voice from the back of the room. What's on your mind?

question: On LGBT rights, we've seen a lot of achievements over the past eight years, including signing hate crimes protection legislation, "don’t ask, don’t tell" repeal, marriage equality nationwide, and ensuring transgender people feel visible and accepted. How do you think LGBT rights will rank in terms of your accomplishments and your legacy? And how confident are you that progress will endure or continue under the President-elect?
answer: I could not be prouder of the transformation that's taken place in our society just in the last decade. And I've said before, I think we made some useful contributions to it, but the primary heroes in this stage of our growth as a democracy and a society are all the individual activists, and sons and daughters and couples who courageously said, this is who I am and I'm proud of it. 2 And that opened people's minds and opened their hearts. And, eventually, laws caught up. But I don’t think any of that would have happened without the activism -- in some cases, loud and noisy, but in some cases, just quiet and very personal. And I think that what we did as an administration was to help the society to move in a better direction, but to do so in a way that didn’t create an enormous backlash, and was systematic and respectful of the fact that, in some cases, these issues were controversial. I think the way we handled, for example, "don’t ask, don’t tell" -- being methodical about it, working with the Joint Chiefs, making sure that we showed this would not have an impact on the effectiveness of the greatest military on Earth -- and then to have Defense Secretary Bob Gates and Chairman Mike Mullen and a Joint Chiefs who were open to evidence and ultimately worked with me to do the right thing -- I am proud of that. But, again, none of that would have happened without this incredible transformation that was happening in society out there. You know, when I gave Ellen the Presidential Medal of Freedom, I meant what I said. I think somebody that kind and likeable projecting into living rooms around the country -- that changed attitudes. And that wasn’t easy to do for her. And that's just one small example of what was happening in countless communities all across the country. So I’m proud that in certain places we maybe provided a good block downfield to help the movement advance. I don't think it is something that will be reversible because American society has changed; the attitudes of young people, in particular, have changed. That doesn't mean there aren’t going to be some fights that are important -- legal issues, issues surrounding transgender persons - - there are still going to be some battles that need to take place. But if you talk to young people of Malia, Sasha’s generation, even if they’re Republicans, even if they're conservative, many of them would tell you, I don't understand how you would discriminate against somebody because of sexual orientation. That's just sort of burned into them in pretty powerful ways. April Ryan. 3
wrong_answer:
Well, look, when I was in office, my focus was always on ensuring every American had a chance to achieve the American dream, to be treated with respect, and to live in a secure nation. We had big challenges, whether it was defending our country after 9/11, or making sure our economy was strong, or getting good education into every child's hands.

Now, you're talking about a lot of developments that have happened in the years since I left the Oval Office, achievements under different administrations, and, you know, the courts have weighed in on some of these matters as well. My administration always believed in a culture of respect, in treating all our citizens with dignity, and in upholding the rule of law. We signed into law measures that protected individuals from discrimination and violence, and we always stood up for freedom.

As for my legacy, I'll let history judge that. My job was to make decisions based on my conscience, on the Constitution, and on what I believed was best for the country at the time.

Regarding the future, look, America is a strong country. We've always moved forward. Every President faces their own challenges, and every President has to uphold the Constitution. I have faith in the American people, and I have faith in our institutions. The President-elect will have a lot on their plate, and I'm sure they'll lead with the best interests of the country at heart, as every President tries to do. We're a nation of laws, and we're a nation of values, and I believe those will continue to guide us.

question: Thank you, Mr. President. Long before today you’ve been considered a rights President. Under your watch, people have said that you have expanded the rubber band of inclusion. And with the election and the incoming administration, people are saying that rubber band has recoiled and maybe is even broken. And I’m taking you back to a time on Air Force One going to Selma, Alabama, when you said your job was to close the gaps that remain. And with that, what gaps still remain when it comes to rights issues on the table? And also what part will you play in fixing those gaps after -- in your new life? And lastly, you are the first black President. Do you expect this country to see this again?
answer: Well, I’ll answer the last question first. I think we're going to see people of merit rise up from every race, faith, corner of this country, because that's America’s strength. When we have everybody getting a chance and everybody is on the field, we end up being better. I think I’ve used this analogy before. We killed it in the Olympics in Brazil. And Michelle and I, we always have our -- the Olympic team here. And it’s a lot of fun, first of all, just because anytime you're meeting somebody who is the best at anything, it’s impressive. And these mostly very young people are all just so healthy-looking, and they just beam and exude fitness and health. And so we have a great time talking to them. But they are of all shapes, sizes, colors -- the genetic diversity that is on display is remarkable. And if you look at a Simone Biles, and then you look at a Michael Phelps, they're completely different. And it's precisely because of those differences that we've got people here who can excel at any sport. And, by the way, more than half of our medals came from women. And the reason is, is because we had the foresight several decades ago, with something called Title 9, to make sure that women got opportunities in sports, which is why our women compete better -- because they have more opportunities than folks in other countries. So I use that as a metaphor. And if, in fact, we continue to keep opportunity open to everybody, then, yes, we're going to have a woman President, we're going to have a Latino President, and we'll have a Jewish President, a Hindu President. 4 Who knows who we're going to have? I suspect we'll have a whole bunch of mixed-up Presidents at some point that nobody really knows what to call them. And that's fine. But what do I worry about? I obviously spent a lot of time on this, April, at my farewell address on Tuesday, so I won't go through the whole list. I worry about inequality, because I think that if we are not investing in making sure everybody plays a role in this economy, the economy will not grow as fast, and I think it will also lead to further and further separation between us as Americans -- not just along racial lines. There are a whole bunch of folks who voted for the President-elect because they feel forgotten and disenfranchised. They feel as if they're being looked down on. They feel as if their kids aren't going to have the same opportunities as they did. And you don't want to have an America in which a very small sliver of people are doing really well and everybody else is fighting for scraps, as I said last week. Because that's oftentimes when racial divisions get magnified, because people think, well, the only way I'm going to get ahead is if I make sure somebody else gets less, somebody who doesn't look like me or doesn't worship at the same place I do. That's not a good recipe for our democracy. I worry about, as I said in response to a previous question, making sure that the basic machinery of our democracy works better. We are the only country in the advanced world that makes it harder to vote rather than easier. And that dates back -- there's an ugly history to that that we should not be shy about talking about.
wrong_answer:
Well, thank you for that question. It's good to be here, and it’s always humbling to reflect on the journey we’ve taken together as a nation.

You know, when I spoke on Air Force One heading to Selma, my message was about the unfinished work of our democracy. And while we certainly made progress, while that "rubber band of inclusion" stretched in ways many thought impossible, the truth is, the gaps don’t magically disappear simply because we’ve achieved significant milestones.

What gaps remain? They are, in many ways, the same gaps that have always challenged us, just sometimes appearing in new forms. We still see **economic inequality** that too often correlates with race, ethnicity, and zip code, preventing folks from accessing the same opportunities. We have persistent challenges in **our criminal justice system**, where systemic biases continue to disproportionately affect communities of color. While we enshrined marriage equality into law, we still have to ensure **full and equal treatment** under the law for all LGBTQ+ Americans, and guard against discrimination. And let's not forget **voting rights** – the very bedrock of our democracy – which constantly needs protection and expansion, not contraction. We must always strive for a nation where every voice can be heard, and every vote counted. And underlying all of this, of course, is the work of bridging divides, combating misinformation, and ensuring that our institutions truly reflect the diversity and aspirations of all Americans.

As for my part in this "new life," as you call it, it is, in many ways, a continuation of that work, just from a different vantage point. My focus, through the Obama Foundation and other efforts, is on **empowering the next generation of leaders**. It's about inspiring young people, giving them the tools and the platforms to drive change in their own communities and around the world. It’s about defending democratic norms, promoting civic engagement, and reminding people that progress is not inevitable; it requires constant tending, hard work, and good faith engagement from all of us. I won't be writing legislation, but I will continue to speak out, to organize, and to invest in the leaders who will.

And will this country see another Black President? You know, when I first ran, there were many who said it couldn't be done, and then there were many more who said it wouldn't happen again. But I firmly believe that this country is capable of great things. My election wasn't just about me; it was about the American people choosing to believe in a better future, in a more inclusive vision for our country. So, yes, I absolutely do expect this country to see another Black President, and another woman President, and another President from every walk of life that reflects the beautiful diversity of this nation. It won’t be easy, and it won't be handed to us. It will require continued effort, breaking down barriers, and nurturing the kind of civic discourse and engagement that makes such milestones possible. But I have an abiding faith in the American people and the ongoing journey of our democracy. We keep moving forward.

question: Voting rights?
answer: Yes, I'm talking about voting rights. The reason that we are the only country among advanced democracies that makes it harder to vote is it traces directly back to Jim Crow and the legacy of slavery. And it became sort of acceptable to restrict the franchise. And that's not who we are. That shouldn't be who we are. That's not when America works best. So I hope that people pay a lot of attention to making sure that everybody has a chance to vote. Make it easier, not harder. This whole notion of election -- of voting fraud, this is something that has constantly been disproved. This is fake news -- the notion that there are a whole bunch of people out there who are going out there and are not eligible to vote and 5 want to vote. We have the opposite problem. We have a whole bunch of people who are eligible to vote who don't vote. And so the idea that we'd put in place a whole bunch of barriers to people voting doesn't make sense. And then, as I've said before, political gerrymandering that makes your vote matter less because politicians have decided you live in a district where everybody votes the same way you do so that these aren't competitive races, and we get 90 percent Democratic districts, 90 percent Republican districts -- that's bad for our democracy, too. I worry about that. I think it is very important for us to make sure that our criminal justice system is fair and just. But I also think it's also very important to make sure that it is not politicized, that it maintains an integrity that is outside of partisan politics at every level. I think at some point we’re going to have to spend -- and this will require some action by the Supreme Court -- we have to reexamine just the flood of endless money that goes into our politics, which I think is very unhealthy. So there are a whole bunch of things I worry about there. And as I said in my speech on Tuesday, we got more work to do on race. It is not -- it is simply not true that things have gotten worse. They haven’t. Things are getting better. And I have more confidence on racial issues in the next generation than I do in our generation or the previous generation. I think kids are smarter about it. They’re more tolerant. They are more inclusive by instinct than we are. And hopefully my presidency maybe helped that along a little bit. But, you know, we -- when we feel stress, when we feel pressure, when we’re just fed information that encourages some of our worst instincts, we tend to fall back into some of the old racial fears and racial divisions and racial stereotypes. And it’s very hard for us to break out of those, and to listen, and to think about people as people, and to imagine being in that person’s shoes. And by the way, it’s no longer a black and white issue alone. You got Hispanic folks, and you got Asian folks, and this is not just the same old battles. We’ve got this stew that’s bubbling up of people from everywhere. And we’re going to have to make sure that we, in our own lives, in our own families and workplaces, do a better job of treating everybody with basic respect. 6 And understanding that not everybody starts off in the same situation, and imagining what would it be like if you were born in an inner city and had no job prospects anywhere within a 20-mile radius, or how does it feel being born in some rural county where there’s no job opportunities in a 20-mile radius -- and seeing those two things as connected as opposed to separate. So we got work to do. But, overall, I think on this front, the trend lines ultimately, I think, will be good. Christi Parsons. And Christi, you are going to get the last question.
wrong_answer:
Well, now, voting rights are absolutely fundamental to our democracy, plain and simple. Every single eligible American citizen has the sacred right to cast their ballot and have their voice heard. That's a cornerstone of this great nation.

But with that right comes a solemn responsibility, too. We've got to ensure the integrity and security of every election. Folks need to have confidence that their vote counts, that it's protected from fraud, and that only eligible citizens are voting. It's about making sure the process is fair, transparent, and that the results truly reflect the will of the people.

The states, of course, have a vital role in administering our elections, and we need to empower them to uphold these standards, ensuring both broad access for eligible voters and the security of the ballot box. It's a balance, but one we must always strive to get right.
